text: What is a likely consequence of sudden braking?
options: There will be no consequences as the vehicle’s brake lights will come on.
The vehicle’s braking system could overheat.
The vehicle could be overtaken.
The vehicle could be hit from behind.
explanation: As well as reading the road ahead, you should also be aware of traffic travelling behind you. This will help you react correctly in a situation where you need to brake suddenly.

text: If the brake pedal of a vehicle feels soft or spongy when applied, what does this mean?
options: A fault in the brake fluid system.
The parking brake is on.
Worn brake pads.
A fault in the handbrake cable.
explanation: If the brake pedal feels soft or spongy when pressed, it could indicate that the brake fluid level is low and there is a fault in the system. Each time a driver sets out on a journey, they should test the brakes. If a fault is detected, have it checked by a competent person. Drivers should check brake fluid levels regularly.

text: Whilst driving, why might a driver suspect that the brake fluid level in their vehicle is low?
options: The brakes take longer than usual to release.
The brakes feel spongy and soft.
The brakes feel hard to press.
The brakes are unusually sharp.
explanation: If the brake pedal feels soft or spongy when pressed, it could indicate that the brake fluid level is low and there is a fault in the system. Each time a driver sets out on a journey, they should test the brakes. If a fault is detected, have it checked by a competent person. Drivers should check brake fluid levels regularly.

text: If a driver applies the footbrake and hears a scraping noise, what is the most likely cause?
options: One of the rear tyres is flat.
The brake linings or pads are worn.
The brake-pads are wet.
One of the front tyres is flat.
explanation: Drivers should test their brakes regularly and particularly before setting out on a journey. However, if when driving they hear a scraping noise when they press the brake, the most likely reason is that the brake linings or pads are worn. In this case, brakes wont work as well as they should and the driver should have them replaced by a competent person immediately.

text: What may indicate a problem with the vehicle’s braking system?
options: The vehicle’s parking brake is more effective.
The vehicle’s suspension is affected.
The vehicle’s stopping ability is affected.
The vehicle’s fuel consumption is reduced.
explanation: Drivers should test their brakes before setting out on a journey. If when driving they notice that it is taking longer than usual to bring the vehicle to a stop, they should have the brakes checked immediately by a competent person.

text: What can cause a vehicle to skid?
options: Coasting to a stop.
Stopping in fourth gear.
Controlled acceleration.
Excessive heavy braking.
explanation: Heavy braking can cause a vehicle to skid, particularly if the road surface is wet or uneven, or if the tyres are worn or incorrectly inflated. Read the road well ahead and try to avoid heavy braking, particularly in wet or slippery conditions.

text: The parking brake (handbrake) generally works on which wheels?
options: The rear wheels.
All the wheels.
The rear right-hand wheel.
The front wheels.
explanation: In most vehicles, the parking brake operates on the rear wheels only. The function of the parking brake (handbrake) is to stop the vehicle from moving when it is parked or when it is stopped on a hill. Drivers normally use the parking brake when the vehicle is already stationary and should generally not use it to stop the vehicle. It is even more important to use the parking brake when parked on a hill or when stationary in a vehicle with automatic transmission to prevent creep.

text: When should a driver have both hands on the steering wheel?
options: At all times except when using another vehicle control.
At all times except when on long straight roads.
Only when making a manoeuvre.
explanation: To maintain proper control of a vehicle drivers should have both hands on the steering wheel at all times except when using another vehicle control such as changing gear, using indicators, wipers or handbrake.

text: What is the outcome of late clutch use when stopping a vehicle?
options: Tyres will wear down quicker.
The vehicle may cut out.
It helps to save fuel.
explanation: Drivers should always make proper use of the clutch on the vehicle when changing gear, this will allow for smooth gear changes at all times. When a vehicle is coming to a stop, the clutch should be used in good time to avoid the vehicle cutting out.

text: What is the danger of sudden braking?
options: Driver’s airbag may deploy.
Vehicle may skid.
Handbrake may engage.
explanation: Drivers should always read the road ahead and drive at a distance that enables them to stop safely. Where a driver has to brake suddenly, they should be aware that they may lose control of the vehicle causing it to skid.

text: When braking, what determines how quickly the vehicle will slow down and stop?
options: The amount of downward pressure applied to the brake pedal.
The amount of upward pressure applied to the brake pedal.
The amount of downward pressure applied to the accelerator.
explanation: The amount of downward pressure put on the brake pedal determines how quickly the vehicle will slow down and stop. In the normal course of driving, drivers should read the road ahead and learn to brake in good time and progressively.

text: What should a driver be aware of when braking to slow down and stop?
options: An empty vehicle takes longer to stop.
A loaded vehicle takes longer to stop.
A shorter vehicle takes longer to stop.
explanation: When you are braking you need to take into account that a fully loaded vehicle, because of its additional weight takes a longer distance to come to a complete stop than an unladen vehicle.

text: What should a driver do when a vehicle starts to aquaplane?
options: Ease off the accelerator to slow down.
Maintain speed to avoid skidding.
Brake firmly in order to slow down.
explanation: Aquaplaning occurs when driving in wet weather in conditions and a film of water builds up between the road surface and the tyres, which in turn effects the handling of the vehicle. When the vehicle aquaplanes, the steering will seem very ‘loose’. Drivers should stay calm, ease off the accelerator to slow down, but avoid braking if possible. At a slower speed the water will be dispersed and the tyres will regain grip on the road surface.

text: What is the purpose of electronic stability control?
options: To keep the vehicle steady and prevent skidding.
To maintain speed when motorway driving.
To reduce fuel consumption.
explanation: Electronic Stability Control (ESC) is an active safety system which can be fitted to cars, buses, coaches and trucks. It is an extension of anti-lock brake technology, which has speed sensors and independent braking for each wheel. It aims to stabilise the vehicle and prevent skidding under all driving conditions and situations, within physical limits. It does so by identifying a critical driving situation and applying specific brake pressure on one or more wheels, as required. If necessary, the engine torque is also adjusted automatically.

text: What is the most common cause of skidding?
options: Excessive speed for the circumstances or conditions.
Hot brake pads from over use on downhill stretches.
Badly worn brake pads.
explanation: Excessive speed for the road conditions is a factor which can reduce the grip of tyres on the road and can cause or contribute to a skid. Drivers should adjust their speed to suit the road and traffic conditions and should be aware that wet or greasy roads, worn or improperly inflated tyres, mud, leaves, ice or snow can all cause a vehicle to skid.

text: When using the accelerator, how can a driver help reduce the vehicle’s fuel consumption?
options: A driver should accelerate smoothly to reach and maintain the appropriate speed.
A driver should accelerate quickly to reach the appropriate speed and then ease off to maintain pace.
A driver should accelerate smoothly only when the vehicle is laden.
explanation: Try to use the accelerator smoothly and progressively. Driving smoothly can reduce fuel consumption as well as reducing wear and tear on your vehicle. REMEMBER - The driver has the single biggest impact on both fuel consumption and safety.

text: Why should a tractor be driven more slowly on uneven road surfaces?
options: To maintain tyre pressure.
To reduce road noise.
To avoid severe bouncing.
To avoid fuel spilling from the tank.
explanation: Drivers should drive more slowly on an uneven road surface because driving a tractor at speed could cause the vehicle or the trailer to become unstable and difficult to control. During severe bouncing, the tractor’s wheels can lose contact with the road, negatively affecting steering and braking.

text: When should the handbrake be used to bring a vehicle to a halt?
options: Only when going downhill.
Normally never.
At any time.
Only when going uphill.
explanation: In general the handbrake should never be used to bring a vehicle to a halt. This practice is potentially dangerous, as the rear wheels could lock up and the vehicle could skid out of control. In addition, using the handbrake does not operate the rear brake lights to warn following traffic.

text: What is the danger associated with applying the handbrake (parking brake) when the vehicle is moving?
options: There is no danger - the vehicle will not skid as the handbrake can be released quickly.
The engine will stall once the handbrake is applied at speed.
The wheels could lock and cause the vehicle to skid.
The ABS could disconnect and cause the vehicle to skid.
explanation: Except in an emergency, the handbrake (parking brake) should never be used when the vehicle is moving. This practice is potentially dangerous, as the wheels could lock up and the vehicle could skid out of control. In addition there is no warning to following traffic from the brake lights.

text: What is the recommended method of driving a car with automatic transmission?
options: Operate the accelerator with the right foot and the brake with the left foot.
Operate the accelerator and brake with the left foot.
Use the handbrake to bring the vehicle to a halt.
Operate the accelerator and brake with the right foot.
explanation: When driving a car with automatic transmission, drivers should use the right foot to operate both the accelerator and the brake, just as in vehicles with a manual gear box. In general it is important to avoid using the accelerator and the brake at the same time.

text: What is the effect of an incorrectly adjusted driver’s seat?
options: It gives the driver a better view in the rear-view mirror.
It improves the driver’s ability to operate the clutch.
It enables the driver to relax more on a long journey.
It can delay the driver from operating a control.
explanation: Before starting a journey, you should adopt a suitable and comfortable driving position by adjusting the driver’s seat to a position where all the vehicle controls can be operated efficiently.

text: What type of noise might fast cornering create?
options: Exhaust backfire.
Engine backfire.
Tyre squeal.
Brake squeal.
explanation: If you drive around a corner too fast, the tyres begin to lose contact with the surface of the road, and this causes a squealing sound. If you continue driving in this way, you can lose control of the vehicle.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Trams emerging from left.
Tram lane on left.
No parking inside the white line.
Bus and tram lane on left.
explanation: This sign tells you there is a tram lane on the left. Be aware that there might be pedestrians in the area and crossing the road.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Radio transmission mast ahead.
Overhead electric cables.
Sharp corners ahead.
Crosswinds ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of electric cables overhead. Drivers with a high load should be particularly careful.

text: Who can use a signed cycle track accompanied by a continuous white line on the left-hand side?
options: Cyclists and users of motorised wheelchairs.
Drivers when overtaking a vehicle turning right.
Cyclists and motorcyclists.
Drivers, when it is not being used by a cyclist.
explanation: A cycle track is for the use of cyclists and motorised wheelchairs only. No other vehicles may cross into or over a mandatory cycle track unless this is necessary in order to leave or enter a side road or a property adjacent to the cycle track.

text: What lights indicate a zebra crossing?
options: Flashing amber beacons.
Flashing red beacons.
Continuously lit amber beacons.
Continuously lit red beacons.
explanation: A zebra crossing is indicated by amber flashing beacons on poles and black and white stripes on the road. You must stop for pedestrians on the crossing and for those about to cross.

text: What do temporary traffic lights at road works mean?
options: A driver must comply with the lights at all times.
A driver must comply with the lights when workers are on site only.
A driver need not comply if a convoy of traffic is going in the same direction.
A driver need only comply when there is oncoming traffic.
explanation: You must comply with any temporary traffic lights used to control vehicle movements at or near road works. It is an offence not to obey these lights.

text: What do these signs together mean?
options: Parking not allowed during times shown.
Access for buses and taxis only during times shown.
Pedestrianised street ahead - traffic not allowed except during times shown.
Clearway ahead - no stopping or parking during times shown.
explanation: When posted together these signs tells you that there is a pedestrianised street ahead and that traffic is not allowed to enter except during the times stated on the information plate.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Maximum permitted weight is 3 tonnes.
Minimum permitted weight is 3 tonnes.
3-axled vehicles are not permitted.
Only 3-axled vehicles are permitted.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must not enter this area if your vehicle is over 3 tonnes or 3,000 kg.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Passing other traffic that exceeds the weight shown is not allowed.
Parking in loading area is not allowed.
Parking of vehicles exceeding the weight shown is not allowed.
Parking of vehicles under the weight shown is not allowed.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must not park in this area if your vehicle is over the weight limit indicated.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: No overtaking.
No stopping/parking on the right.
End of dual carriageway.
Double parking not allowed.
explanation: This sign tells you that overtaking is prohibited. These signs are usually found in places where overtaking may be dangerous, such as in areas with reduced visibility.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Only cyclists and buses are allowed to use the lane during the times indicated.
Only buses, cyclists and taxis are allowed to use the lane outside the hours indicated.
Only buses and cyclists may park during the times indicated.
Only buses, cyclists and taxis are allowed to use the lane ahead during the hours indicated.
explanation: This sign tells you there is a with-flow nearside bus lane ahead on the left – that is, one where the buses move in the same direction as the traffic to their right. The information plate tells the times when the bus lane is in operation. Only buses, taxis and cyclists may use the bus lane during those hours.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Only double-decker buses and cyclists may use lane.
Cyclists and buses must turn left.
With-flow bus and cycle lane ahead on left.
Only buses and cyclists may park.
explanation: This sign tells you there is a with-flow nearside bus lane ahead to the left. Only buses, taxis and cyclists may use the bus lane during the stated operational hours.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Cyclists must give way to buses ahead.
Buses must give way to other traffic ahead.
Buses must give way to cyclists ahead.
Bus and cycle lane ahead on right.
explanation: This sign tells you that there is an offside bus lane ahead on the right. Only buses, taxis and cyclists may use the bus lane during the stated operational hours.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Buses may block the driver’s view of cyclists.
With-flow bus lane on the left.
Contra-flow bus lane ahead.
With-flow bus lane on the right.
explanation: This sign indicates a with-flow offside bus lane on the right. Only buses, taxis and cyclists may use the bus lane during the stated operational hours.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Cycle track may be crossed by buses.
With-flow bus lane to right.
Contra-flow bus lane on the right.
Buses emerging from right.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must drive on the left and not use the contra-flow bus lane day or night. A contraflow bus lane is one where the buses are going in the opposite direction.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Contra-flow bus lane.
With-flow bus lane.
Double-decker buses only.
Two-way traffic system.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must drive on the left and not use the contra-flow bus lane day or night. A contra-flow bus lane is one where the buses are going in the opposite direction.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Tram lane on left.
Tram lane on right.
Parking only inside the white line.
With-flow bus lane ahead.
explanation: This sign tells you there is an offside tram lane on the right. Drivers should also be aware that there might be pedestrians in the area.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Y-junction where main road bears to the left.
Y-junction where heavy vehicles must go left.
Y-junction where vehicles must go left.
Y-junction where main road bears to the right.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a Y-junction with a minor road ahead. The wider arm of the Y indicates the course of the main road.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Junction ahead with dual carriageway.
Y-junction ahead with roads of lesser importance.
Y-junction ahead with roads of equal importance.
Minor road ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a Y-junction ahead with roads of equal importance. Approach such a junction with caution and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: T-junction ahead with roads of major importance.
Crossroads with major road ahead.
Crossroads with dual carriageway ahead.
Road passing under a bridge ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a crossroads junction with a major road ahead. Be prepared to stop.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: T-junction ahead with a road of minor importance.
T-junction ahead with a road of major importance.
Cul-de-sac to the right.
Cul-de-sac to the left and right.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a T-junction ahead with a major road. Be prepared to yield or stop as necessary.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: T-junction with crossroads ahead.
Unguarded level crossing ahead.
Level crossing ahead guarded by gates.
Crossroads with dual carriageway ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a crossroads junction at a dual carriageway ahead. Drivers need to be observant, taking extra care for traffic coming from each direction. Yield and/or stop as appropriate.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Guarded level crossing ahead.
Unguarded level crossing ahead.
T-junction with dual carriageway ahead.
Low bridge ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a T-junction at a dual carriageway ahead. Drivers need to be observant, taking extra care for traffic coming from each direction. Yield and/or stop as appropriate.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Traffic merging from the right.
End of dual carriageway ahead.
Traffic merging from the left.
Traffic from the left has priority.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of traffic merging from the left. You should expect vehicles to join from the left. You may need to slow down, allowing them to merge safely.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Traffic merging/diverging ahead.
Road narrows briefly ahead.
Yield to merging/diverging traffic ahead.
Diversion at junction ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of roads both merging (entering onto the main road) and diverging (exiting the main road). Drivers should be prepared for traffic changing speed and direction as vehicles enter or exit at the junctions on the left ahead.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Dangerous corner ahead.
One-way street ahead.
Junction to the left.
Dangerous bend ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a dangerous corner to the left. You may need to slow down and react to any changes in the traffic situation ahead.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Sharp change of direction to the right.
Series of speed ramps ahead.
Road closed - drivers must turn back.
Sharp change of direction to the left.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a sharp change of direction to the right. You should slow down as you approach the hazard.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Road narrows on the left.
Merging traffic from the left.
End of dual carriageway.
The driver must overtake on the right only.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that the road narrows on the left ahead. You should show caution and prepare to adjust your road position.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Tramline ahead.
Overtake only on the left ahead.
Road divides ahead.
Railway tunnel ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that the road divides ahead. You should prepare to move to the left.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Steep descent ahead.
Steep ascent ahead.
River or unprotected quay ahead.
Uneven road surface ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a steep descent/downward slope ahead. You should react accordingly by adjusting speed and selecting the appropriate gear.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Low bridge up ahead.
Restricted road width ahead.
Restricted weight limit for road segment indicated.
Road narrows ahead - maximum length of vehicle is indicated.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that you are approaching a low bridge, with restricted headroom as shown on the sign.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Railway bridge ahead.
Level crossing ahead unprotected by lights and barriers.
Level crossing ahead protected by lights and barriers.
Railway station ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a railway level crossing ahead protected by lights and barriers. The crossing may also have an audible warning alarm. You should be prepared to stop.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Road divides ahead - pass on the left or right.
Road damaged ahead.
Road flooded ahead.
Sharp depression or dip ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a dip or depression in the road ahead which may be hidden and could obscure your view of oncoming traffic. You should reduce your speed accordingly and be aware that overtaking is dangerous in these areas.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Series of rumble strips ahead.
Road works ahead.
Series of bumps or hollows ahead.
Steep hills ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a series of bumps or hollows ahead. Be prepared to reduce your speed as necessary.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Slippery road ahead.
Road narrows from right.
Steep hill ahead.
Series of bends ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of the potential danger of slippery road surfaces ahead.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: School children crossing ahead.
Traffic signals ahead.
Railway level crossing ahead.
Stop at zebra crossing.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a traffic light controlled junction ahead. This sign is generally found in areas where the lights may not be visible to drivers in good time – for example, following a bend in the road.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Picnic area ahead.
School ahead.
Children’s play area ahead.
Pedestrian crossing ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a school ahead. You should adjust your speed and react accordingly as there may be children in the area.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Golf course ahead.
Falling rocks ahead.
Crosswinds ahead.
Airport ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be crosswinds ahead. Crosswinds can affect the stability of your vehicle on the road. Be prepared to slow down if necessary.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Low bridge 500 metres ahead.
Motorway ends 500 metres ahead.
No overtaking for 500 metres.
Bridge repair 500 metres ahead.
explanation: This is a motorway information sign that tells you that the motorway will end in 500 metres ahead. Motorway rules will no longer apply, for example a lower speed limit may be applicable.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: End of overhead bridge area.
End of motorway.
No bridges ahead.
No overtaking.
explanation: This sign indicates the end of the motorway. You are leaving the motorway and its rules will no longer apply.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Overtaking lane ends ahead.
A driver may overtake on the right only.
Road narrows from right.
Right-hand lane has an uneven surface.
explanation: Where there are roadworks up ahead, this warning sign tells you that the road narrows from the right creating a potential hazard.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: End of dual carriageway ahead.
Road narrows on both sides.
Traffic merging from both sides.
End of obstruction between lanes.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the road narrows on both sides creating a potential hazard. Be prepared to slow down and drive with extra care.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Flagman ahead.
Hitch-hiking permitted.
Football stadium ahead.
Pedestrian crossing to right.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the traffic flow ahead is controlled manually by a flagman. Be aware and follow directions given by the flagman.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Traffic may not stop.
Dual carriageway ahead.
One-way street.
Two-way traffic.
explanation: This warning sign tells you that during roadworks there will be two-way traffic in operation ahead. Continue to drive with extra care.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Nearside lane of two closed.
T-junction ahead in the left lane.
Offside lane of two closed.
Traffic in nearside lane must turn left.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the nearside (left-hand) lane is closed ahead. If you are in this lane you will need to move to the offside (right-hand) lane when it is safe to do so.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: End of dual carriageway.
Corner ahead on offside lane.
Offside lane closed ahead.
No stopping, except in offside lane.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the offside (right-hand) lane of three is closed ahead. Drivers in the nearside or centre lanes should be aware that traffic may merge from the right.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Bend in the road to the left ahead.
Lay-by ahead.
Traffic should cross back to the left-hand lane ahead.
Slow lane ahead for heavy traffic.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the course of the road will return to the left ahead. This usually appears after a stretch where traffic was diverted to a right-hand lane.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Traffic should cross out to the right-hand lane ahead.
Bend in the road to the right ahead.
Traffic calming measures ahead.
End of “no overtaking” zone.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the course of the road will divert to the right ahead.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Tunnel ends ahead.
Dual carriageway ends ahead.
End of central reserve or obstruction.
Beware of vehicle with a wide load.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that traffic previously separated by the central reserve or an obstruction will revert to two-way traffic.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The cyclist intends to stop.
The cyclist intends to slow down.
The cyclist intends to move out or turn right.
The cyclist intends to move in or turn left.
explanation: This hand signal tells other road users that the cyclist intends to either move out or make a right-hand turn. Drivers should be aware that cyclists could move out into the path of their vehicle without looking.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The cyclist is signalling following traffic to overtake.
The cyclist intends to slow down or stop.
The cyclist intends to move out.
The cyclist intends to turn left.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that cyclist intends to slow down or stop. This may indicate that the cyclist is aware of some hazard ahead, so drive with extra care.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The driver intends to proceed straight ahead.
The driver intends to turn left.
The driver intends to slow down or stop.
The driver intends to reverse.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users or a Garda directing traffic that the driver intends to proceed straight ahead.

text: What does this traffic light mean?
options: Traffic turning left should prepare for full green to move off.
Traffic is not allowed to turn left.
All traffic must turn left only.
Traffic turning left may proceed if the way is clear.
explanation: A green arrow (filter light) means that traffic may proceed in the direction of the arrow if it is safe to do so.

text: When traffic lights are green, when should a driver not proceed?
options: When oncoming traffic is waiting to turn left.
When traffic is stopped waiting to turn from the road on the right.
When it would be unsafe to do so.
When traffic is stopped waiting to turn from the road on the left.
explanation: Although a green traffic light means proceed with caution, you should not enter a junction if the way is not clear or if by doing so you would cause an obstruction to other road users.

text: Where is a driver allowed to park?
options: On a footpath.
Where there is a continuous white line along the centre of the road.
At road works.
Where the driver is not blocking other road users their view of traffic signals or the road ahead.
explanation: It is an offence to park at the side of a road that has a single or double continuous white line along its centre. Parking on such a road could create an obstruction and may cause inconvenience or danger to other road users.

text: What distance before a zebra crossing is parking prohibited?
options: 15 metres.
10 metres.
20 metres.
5 metres.
explanation: It is an offence to park 15 metres before or 5 metres after a pedestrian crossing. Parking in this manner may restrict the zone of vision of drivers approaching the crossing and endanger pedestrians.

text: Within what distance of a road junction is parking prohibited?
options: 15 metres, unless parking spaces are clearly marked.
10 metres, unless parking spaces are clearly marked.
5 metres, unless parking spaces are clearly marked.
20 metres, unless parking spaces are clearly marked.
explanation: It is an offence to park within 5 metres of a road junction unless parking spaces are clearly marked. Parking in that area may restrict the zone of vision of drivers approaching the junction and may cause an obstruction to large vehicles wishing to turn.

text: Is a driver permitted to park at an entrance to a property?
options: Yes, outside business hours.
Yes, for 1 hour between 07:00 hrs to 23:30 hrs.
Yes, with the property owner’s consent.
Yes, for 1 hour between 23:30 hrs to 07:00 hrs.
explanation: You may park across the entrance to a property only with the owner’s consent. Parking across an entrance may cause inconvenience and danger to persons entering or leaving the property.

text: When is parking permitted on a footpath?
options: It is never permitted to park on a footpath.
When cars are parked on both sides of the road.
When at least half of the footpath remains free for pedestrians.
When no more than half of the vehicle is on the footpath.
explanation: It is an offence to park on a footpath. Where a vehicle is parked on a footpath, pedestrians may have to step onto the road to go around the vehicle and so place themselves in danger.

text: When is double parking permitted?
options: When there is a hard shoulder.
When there are double yellow lines.
It is never permitted.
When there are double white lines.
explanation: Double parking is never permitted. Parking is never permitted where it might interfere in any way with the normal flow of traffic or obstruct or endanger other road users.

text: When is parking permitted at a taxi rank?
options: Parking at a taxi rank is prohibited unless driving a taxi.
When the rank is unoccupied.
When waiting to collect passengers from a taxi.
When parking for less than 15 minutes.
explanation: Stopping or parking within an area marked as a taxi rank is prohibited as this may obstruct taxis entering or leaving the rank.

text: When is parking permitted at a sharp bend?
options: Parking is never permitted at a sharp bend.
When drivers coming from behind can see the parked vehicle.
When the hazard warning lights of the parked vehicle are on.
When parking no more than 45 centimetres from the kerb or edge of the road.
explanation: Parking is never permitted where it might interfere in any way with the normal flow of traffic or obstruct or endanger other road users – for example, by forcing other drivers into the path of oncoming traffic.

text: When is parking permitted on the brow of a hill?
options: Only when there is no traffic on the road.
Parking is never permitted on the brow of a hill.
Parking is permitted when a vehicle has an efficient handbrake.
When the driver angles the wheels towards the kerb.
explanation: Parking on the brow of a hill or on a humpbacked bridge is prohibited. Parking in such a place may restrict the zone of vision of drivers approaching the hill and force them into the path of oncoming traffic.

text: What is the purpose of traffic calming measures?
options: To alert drivers to road flooding ahead.
To slow down traffic in the vicinity.
To inform the driver of an increased speed limit ahead.
To prioritise heavy goods traffic.
explanation: The purpose of traffic calming measures is to slow down fast-moving traffic to a speed more suitable for the area they are entering. These measures are usually found in rural areas on the entry points to towns or villages.

text: When may a trailer be towed on a public road without a rear number plate?
options: When the tailboard is removed.
When carrying a load that overhangs the trailer.
Never, a number plate must always be displayed.
When being towed by an agricultural tractor.
explanation: The law requires all motorised vehicles to display a rear number plate that is clean and legible.

text: What traffic may use a cycle lane accompanied by a continuous white line?
options: Cyclists and motorised wheelchairs.
Cyclists and taxis.
Cyclists and motorcyclists.
Buses and cyclists.
explanation: A cycle track is for the use of cyclists and motorised wheelchairs. No other vehicles may cross into or over a mandatory cycle track unless this is necessary in order to leave a side road or a property adjacent to the cycle track.

text: Apart from cyclists and motorised wheelchairs, what other road users may use an unoccupied cycle lane accompanied by a broken white line?
options: Only moped riders and motorcyclists.
Only buses and taxis.
All drivers may make temporary use.
Only hackneys and taxis.
explanation: Drivers may make temporary use of a cycle track with a broken white line on the right-hand side if it is not occupied.

text: When must drivers stop at an automated railway level crossing with barriers and red flashing lights?
options: Stop safely when the amber light shows, or when red lights start to flash.
When there are no lights visible.
When the red and amber lights stop flashing.
When the barrier is fully up.
explanation: You must stop safely when the amber light shows. Flashing red lights have the same meaning as a steady red traffic light - stop safely when they show.

text: At a railway level crossing with unattended gates, what should a car driver do?
options: Telephone the nearest railway station before opening a gate.
Open both gates and after passing the first, stop and close it.
Open both gates before proceeding to cross.
Drive halfway across and close the first gate before opening the second.
explanation: At a level crossing with unattended gates a driver must stop, look for trains and listen for the sound of a horn or approaching trains. If it is safe, open both gates, complete the crossing and then close both gates.

text: What do flashing amber arrows indicate at a junction?
options: When safe, drivers should proceed in the direction indicated.
It is prohibited to proceed in the direction indicated.
Proceed smartly through junction to avoid delay.
The direction indicated is a cul-de-sac.
explanation: When you meet a flashing amber arrow at a junction, you should proceed in the direction indicated provided it is safe to do so.

text: When do temporary speed limits apply at roadworks?
options: During business hours only.
Only when road workers are on site.
Only when there is oncoming traffic.
For the duration of the roadworks.
explanation: Temporary speed limits at road works apply for the duration of the works. When road works are completed, normal speed limits apply.

text: What does a continuous white line along the centre of the road mean?
options: Traffic can overtake.
Parking allowed during business hours.
U-turn allowed during daylight hours.
No U-turn allowed.
explanation: You must never do a U-turn on any stretch of road with a continuous white line along its centre. The restricted vision at such places would make doing a U-turn very unsafe.

text: When wanting to stop temporarily in a congested area where should the driver park?
options: Double park in a convenient place with your hazard lights on.
Park on the footpath so as not to impede the free flow of traffic in the road.
Park slightly up on the footpath with the hazard lights on.
Park in a safe, legal and convenient place.
explanation: You should park only where it is safe, legal and convenient to do so. Your parked vehicle must not cause a danger or an obstruction to other road users. The use of hazard warning lights does not excuse unsafe or illegal parking.

text: What is a clearway?
options: An area that is strictly reserved for the loading and unloading of HGVs.
An area where stopping and parking is not permitted during certain times.
An area where stopping and parking is reserved for buses and taxis only.
An area that is reserved for pedestrians and motorised wheelchairs.
explanation: A clearway is an area of road that must be kept clear for moving traffic during certain times of the day (usually busy periods). The times when stopping or parking is prohibited are shown on an information plate under the sign.

text: What does this sign mean when displayed on the approach to a toll plaza?
options: This lane closed - keep left.
Service station ahead.
Toll collector operating lane.
Garda checkpoint to the left.
explanation: This sign is used at toll plazas to direct traffic into a lane where the toll charge may be paid directly to a cashier. This lane would normally be used by motorists who have neither the exact change nor an electronic tag on their vehicle.

text: What does this sign mean when displayed on the approach to a toll plaza?
options: Cashier in this lane.
Ticket dispenser in this lane.
Coin basket in this lane.
Electronic toll collection.
explanation: This sign is used at toll plazas to direct traffic into a lane where the toll charge may be paid by putting the exact change into an automatic coin machine. This lane usually has a height barrier fitted to prevent large vehicles using it.

text: What does this sign mean when displayed on the approach to a toll plaza?
options: Electronic toll accepted in any lane.
Electronic toll not accepted in this lane.
Electronic toll out of order in this lane.
Payment in euros only in this lane.
explanation: This sign is used at toll plazas to direct traffic into a lane where the toll charge is collected electronically. When the vehicle passes through the plaza it is identified by means of an electronic tag fitted to the front windscreen. Payment will be collected via the users account. Only vehicles fitted with the tags are allowed to use those lanes.

text: What does a flashing amber arrow pointing left at a traffic light mean?
options: A driver may proceed before traffic on the other road.
The driver must wait until the traffic lights turn green.
A driver may turn left but must yield to traffic on the other road.
A driver must not proceed in this direction.
explanation: A flashing left amber arrow at a junction means you may proceed left but must give way to pedestrians and traffic already coming through the junction on the other road.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Bridge ahead.
Entry to motorway.
End of motorway.
explanation: This road sign informs road users that they are entering the motorway and must obey motorway rules. Before driving on the motorway users must familiarise themselves with motorway rules.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Minor road ahead.
Start of dual carriageway.
Y-junction ahead with roads of equal importance.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a Y-junction hazard ahead with a road of equal importance. Be prepared to yield to other road users.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Roundabout ahead.
Ring road ahead.
Loop road ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a roundabout ahead. You must be prepared to yield to other road users already on the roundabout or coming from the right.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Mini-roundabout ahead.
Roadworks ahead, diversion in operation.
Loop road ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a mini-roundabout ahead. You must be prepared to yield to other road users already on the roundabout or coming from the right.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Automatic level crossing ahead.
Unguarded level crossing ahead.
Attended level crossing ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of an automatic level crossing ahead. Drivers should approach with caution and be prepared to slow down or stop as necessary.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Steep descent ahead.
Unprotected quay, canal or river ahead.
Road likely to flood.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of an unprotected area of water ahead. You should be cautious due to the extreme danger.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Deer or wild animals ahead.
Cattle and farm animals ahead.
Stag hunting ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be deer or other wild animals coming onto the roadway. Be prepared to slow down or stop suddenly if required.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Roadworks ahead.
Building site ahead.
Flagman ahead.
explanation: This warning sign tells you that there are roadworks ahead. You should approach with caution and be alert for a change in the road surface, and for the presence of machinery and road workers.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: With-flow bus and cycle lane on left.
Cycle track ahead may be crossed by buses only.
Parking for buses and bicycles on left.
explanation: This sign indicates a nearside with-flow bus lane on the left. Only buses, taxis and cyclists may use the bus lane during the stated operational hours.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Crossroads ahead with roads of lesser importance.
Crossroads ahead with roads of equal importance.
Major road ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a crossroad junction ahead where the roads are of equal importance. At this type of junction you should yield to traffic approaching from the right and traffic already turning.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Dangerous corner ahead.
Dangerous bend ahead.
Turn left.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a dangerous bend to the left. You may need to slow down and react to any changes in the traffic situation ahead.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Series of dangerous bends ahead.
Overhead electric cables.
Series of dangerous corners ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a series of dangerous corners ahead. You should slow down and react to any changes in the traffic situation.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Slippery road ahead.
Series of dangerous corners ahead.
Series of dangerous bends ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a series of dangerous bends ahead. You should slow down and react to any changes in the traffic situation.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Road narrows on both sides.
End of dual carriageway.
Dual carriageway ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that the road is narrowing on both sides ahead. You should show caution and prepare to slow down.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Two-way traffic ahead.
One-way street ahead.
Dual carriageway ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of two-way traffic ahead, with oncoming traffic in the opposite lane.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Humpback bridge ahead.
Steep descent ahead.
Steep ascent ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a steep ascent/upward hill ahead. You should react by selecting the appropriate gear.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Level crossing ahead with pedestrian walkway.
Playground ahead.
School children crossing ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be school children crossing the road ahead, slow down if required and be prepared to stop.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: School playground ahead.
Children’s play area ahead.
School children crossing ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be school children crossing the road ahead, slow down if required and be prepared to stop.

text: What do these signs together mean?
options: Slippery road - children may fall.
Loose chippings on the road ahead.
Beware of children crossing.
explanation: These signs are usually displayed in residential areas, and they give advance warning that children might be crossing ahead. You should proceed cautiously and be prepared to stop suddenly.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Livestock mart ahead.
Cattle grid ahead.
Possibility of cattle or farm animals ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be cattle or other farm animals on the road ahead. Slow down if required and be prepared to stop.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Sheep market ahead.
Abattoir ahead.
Possibility of sheep ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be sheep on the road ahead. Slow down if required and be prepared to stop.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Historic site ahead.
Tunnel ahead.
Low bridge ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a tunnel ahead. You should be aware of the procedures to follow when entering a tunnel – which include keeping a safe distance from the vehicle ahead or removing sunglasses.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Rugged coast ahead.
Danger of falling rocks ahead.
Steep descent ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there is a danger of rocks and other debris falling onto the road. Drive with caution.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Direction of prevailing wind.
Possibility of low flying aircraft.
Airport ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be low-flying aircraft in the area. Low-flying aircraft can cause distraction due to a sudden loud noise.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: A driver must merge from the left.
A driver must drive on the left-hand side.
A driver must overtake on the left-hand side.
explanation: This sign is generally in areas where tourists might be travelling and reminds motorists to drive on the left. These signs are commonly found around airports and ferry ports.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Road narrows from the right.
Slippery road.
Series of bends ahead.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the surface ahead is slippery due to mud or debris and there is an increased risk of skidding.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Left-hand lane has an uneven surface.
Slow lane ends ahead.
Road narrows from left.
explanation: This warning sign tells you that there are roadworks up ahead where the road narrows from the left creating a potential hazard.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: School children crossing ahead.
Temporary traffic signals ahead.
Railway crossing ahead.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that temporary traffic signals are in use ahead. You should prepare to slow down, approach with caution and comply with the signal displayed.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Overtaking permitted, except on the left lane.
Do not drive on the hard shoulder.
Nearside lane of three closed.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the nearside (left-hand) lane of three is closed up ahead. If you are in this lane you will need to move to the centre (middle) lane when it is safe to do so.

text: At roadworks, what does this sign mean?
options: Proceed with caution.
Proceed using hand signals only.
Proceed only when beckoned to do so.
explanation: This traffic control sign tells you that you may proceed with caution through road works.

text: At roadworks, what does this sign mean?
options: Stop only if faced by oncoming traffic.
Stop before or at the sign.
Stop for school warden.
explanation: This traffic control sign at roadworks means you must stop.

text: What do these signs together mean?
options: End of road.
End of road works.
End of detour.
explanation: Together these two signs indicate that a detour has ended.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The cyclist intends to stop.
The cyclist intends to turn right.
The cyclist intends to turn left.
explanation: This hand signal tells other road users that the cyclist intends to either move out or make a right-hand turn. Drivers should be aware that cyclists could cross the path of their vehicle.

text: What distance after a pedestrian crossing can a driver park to make a delivery?
options: 15 metres
5 metres
10 metres
explanation: Make sure you do not interfere with normal traffic flow and that your vehicle does not disturb, block or endanger other road users. A driver must not park 15 metres before or 5 metres after a pedestrian crossing or traffic lights.

text: Unless otherwise indicated, what is the maximum speed allowed for a car towing a trailer on national roads?
options: 60 km/h.
80 km/h.
explanation: When towing a trailer on a national road, it is illegal to exceed 80 km/h – exceeding this speed will make the vehicle unstable.

text: What does a continuous white line in the centre of the road mean?
options: Vehicles may perform a U-turn.
Vehicles may park during daylight hours only.
Vehicles may not cross or drive over the line.
Vehicles may cross the line for a short time.
explanation: You must not cross or straddle a continuous white line in the centre of the road unless you wish to enter land or premises and it is safe to do so.

text: What lights are recommended to be used when parking or leaving a vehicle for a short period of time on the side of the road at night?
options: Rear fog lights in order to alert other road users to the vehicle’s size.
Front and rear side lights to alert other road users to the vehicle’s presence.
Front dipped headlights in order to alert other road users to the vehicle’s location.
explanation: Drivers can quickly become dazzled and disorientated by headlights or fog lights of parked vehicles. If you need to have lights on in these circumstances, you should use only side or parking lights. You should not leave headlights on when parked.

text: What should a driver check when parking their vehicle?
options: That the roadway is adequately lit.
That the vehicle is at least 15 centimetres from the kerb.
That they comply with mandatory road markings and signs.
explanation: Drivers should ensure when parking their vehicle on a roadway that they comply with all relevant road markings and road signs posted, e.g. a driver should not park opposite a continuous white line.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Bus and tramway crossing ahead.
Tramway crossing ahead.
Railway station.
Level crossing ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning sign of a tram crossing ahead. You should be prepared to stop and yield to the tram, if required.

text: What must a driver do when this sign is NOT accompanied by a white stop line on the road?
options: Stop no more than one car length past the sign.
Stop at the sign.
Stop only if there is traffic on the major road.
Stop past the sign.
explanation: Where a STOP sign is not accompanied by a white stop line, you must stop at the sign.

text: What does this sign mean at a junction?
options: Yield to traffic coming from your right only.
Slow down and yield to pedestrians.
Yield to all heavy goods vehicles.
Yield to traffic on the major road.
explanation: At a junction, the YIELD sign tells you that you must give way to traffic on a major road ahead. This means that you must slow down and be prepared to stop.

text: What does this sign mean at a roundabout?
options: Yield to traffic coming from the left.
Yield to cyclists and motorcyclists only.
Yield to traffic coming from the right, or already on the roundabout.
Yield to buses and trucks only.
explanation: At a roundabout, the YIELD sign tells you that you must slow down and be prepared to stop. You must yield (give way) to traffic already on the roundabout or coming from the right.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Traffic from the right has priority.
Motorway to the left.
Diversion ahead to the left.
Turn left only.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must turn left. It is usually displayed at a junction where all traffic must turn left – for example, in a one-way system that incorporates a junction.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Overtake only on the right.
Turn right only.
Major road joining from the left.
Diversion ahead to the right.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must turn right. It is usually displayed at a junction where all traffic must turn right – for example, in a one-way system that incorporates a junction.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Diversion to the left ahead.
Sharp corner to the left ahead.
Turn left ahead.
One-way traffic to the left ahead.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must turn left ahead. It is usually displayed on the approach to a one-way system.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: One-way traffic to the right ahead.
You must turn right ahead.
Diversion to the right ahead.
Sharp bend to the right ahead.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must turn right ahead. It is usually displayed on the approach to a one-way system.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Pass either side.
Dual carriageway ahead.
One-way street.
Two-way traffic ahead.
explanation: This sign tells you that traffic may pass on either side of the traffic island.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Entry to tunnel prohibited.
Two-way traffic prohibited.
U-turn not permitted.
Reversing not permitted.
explanation: This sign tells you that you are not permitted to make a U-turn. It is commonly displayed on approach to junctions on dual carriageways. Drivers should also be aware that U-turns are also not permitted anywhere there is a continuous white line along the centre of the road or on a one-way street.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Parking is prohibited during the hours shown.
Disc parking operates except during the hours shown.
Disc parking operates during the time shown.
Parking without a disc is allowed during the hours shown.
explanation: This sign tells you that vehicles must display a parking disc when parked during the hours shown on the information plate.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Private parking is permitted when the taxi rank is empty.
Only taxis may turn right or left.
Private vehicles may pick up or set down passengers.
Designated rank for taxis.
explanation: A taxi rank sign indicates that this is an area reserved for taxis, and parking or stopping by other road users is not permitted.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Cyclists must dismount ahead.
Track reserved for motorcyclist.
Start of cycle track.
Bicycle race track.
explanation: This sign indicates the start of a cycle track. If the track is bounded by a broken white line, other road users should avoid using it wherever possible. If it is bounded by a continuous white line, drivers of cars and other vehicles must not drive on it.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Junction ahead with roads of greater importance.
Junction ahead with roads of lesser importance.
Junction ahead with railway crossing.
Junction ahead with roads of equal importance.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a junction ahead with minor roads on either side. Be aware that vehicles may be emerging from the minor roads.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: T-junction ahead with road of less importance.
T-junction ahead with roads of equal importance.
T-junction ahead with merging traffic.
T-junction ahead with dual carriageway.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a T-junction ahead with a road of equal importance. You must give way to traffic already on the road you are joining.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Major roadworks ahead.
Level crossing ahead unguarded by gates or barriers.
End of major roadworks ahead.
Level crossing ahead guarded by gates or barriers.
explanation: This sign gives advanced warning of an unguarded level crossing ahead. This is a crossing without gates or barriers and you should cross it with extreme caution.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Private grounds - no entry.
Level crossing ahead guarded by gates or barriers.
Road fencing ahead.
Farm machinery crossing ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a railway crossing ahead that is protected by gates or lifting barriers. You should be prepared to stop and follow the required procedure.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Series of bumps or hollows ahead.
Road falls from centre to left and right.
Traffic island ahead.
Sharp rise in the road ahead - for example, a humpback bridge.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a hump in the road. You should adjust your speed accordingly.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Riding path - no vehicles allowed.
Entrance to horse riding school.
Racecourse ahead.
Accompanied horses and ponies ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be horses on the road ahead. You should show due regard for horses and their riders.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: School ahead.
Pedestrian crossing ahead.
Lane reserved for pedestrians.
Beware of pedestrians at night.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a pedestrian crossing ahead. You should show caution and be prepared to stop.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Sharp descent in 200 metres.
No overtaking for 200 metres.
Dual carriageway crossing ahead.
200 metres to the next exit.
explanation: This is a motorway information sign that tells you that the next exit off the motorway is 200 metres ahead.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Mini-roundabout ahead.
Heavy vehicles have priority.
Start of central reserve or obstruction.
Dual carriageway ahead.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that two-way traffic will separate to avoid an obstruction.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The cyclist intends to stop.
The cyclist intends to turn left.
The cyclist intends to go straight on.
The cyclist is giving way to other traffic.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the cyclist intends to proceed straight ahead at a junction and drivers should show caution.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The driver intends to go straight ahead.
The driver intends to turn left.
The driver intends to slow down or stop.
The driver intends to turn right.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the driver intends to turn left and the vehicle will change direction.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The driver intends to move out or turn right.
The driver intends to do a U-turn.
The driver intends to turn left.
The driver intends to stop ahead.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the driver intends to move out or turn right and the vehicle will change direction.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The driver intends to slow down or stop.
The driver intends to begin a U-turn.
The driver intends to turn right.
The driver intends to turn left.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the driver intends to slow down or stop and following traffic should be prepared to slow down also.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The driver intends to turn left.
The driver intends to stop.
The driver intends to slow down.
The driver intends to turn right.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users or a Garda directing traffic (facing this vehicle), that the driver intends to make a left-hand turn.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The driver intends to turn left.
The driver will begin to reverse.
The driver intends to slow down.
The driver intends to turn right.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users or a Garda directing traffic (facing this vehicle) that the driver intends to turn right.

text: What does this Garda signal mean?
options: Turn right.
Stop if approaching from front.
Stop if approaching from behind.
Turn left.
explanation: When approaching a Garda giving this signal you must stop.

text: What does this Garda signal mean?
options: Turn left.
Stop if approaching from either the front or behind.
Turn right.
Proceed if approaching from the front.
explanation: When approaching a Garda giving this signal you must stop.

text: What does this Garda signal mean?
options: The Garda is beckoning on traffic from the front.
The driver must not proceed to the right.
The driver must not proceed to the left.
The Garda is beckoning on traffic approaching from either side.
explanation: When approaching a Garda giving this signal you may proceed.

text: What does this Garda signal mean?
options: Traffic approaching from the front must stop.
Traffic approaching from the right may proceed.
Traffic approaching from the front may proceed.
Traffic approaching from behind must stop.
explanation: When approaching a Garda giving this signal you may proceed.

text: What does this road marking indicate?
options: No entry.
Speed control ramp.
Pelican crossing.
Zebra crossing.
explanation: A zebra crossing is a designated area for pedestrians to cross the road. As a driver you must always yield to pedestrians on a zebra crossing.

text: What does this road marking mean?
options: A driver may overtake in this area.
Road surface is uneven.
No parking in this area.
Set down area only.
explanation: White zigzag lines indicate that you are approaching a pedestrian crossing. You must not park or overtake within this area.

text: What does this road marking mean?
options: Traffic entering a box junction may have right of way over traffic from both right and left.
Traffic entering a box junction from right and left has the right of way unless continuing straight on.
Traffic must not enter unless they can clear the box junction without stopping, or when turning right.
Taxi set-down area.
explanation: You must not enter the yellow box junction unless you can clear it without stopping or unless you are turning right and are prevented from doing so by oncoming traffic.

text: What does this road marking mean?
options: Road narrows ahead.
A driver is approaching a STOP sign.
All traffic must keep to the left of the white line.
A driver may overtake.
explanation: Where there is a continuous white line in the centre of the road, you are not permitted to: 1. Straddle or cross the white line; 2. Overtake another vehicle; 3. Perform a U-turn; or 4. Park on the road.

text: What does this road marking and information plate together mean?
options: Parking only at times and days shown.
Parking not allowed at the times and days shown.
Taxi parking only at the times and days shown.
Taxi parking only outside the times and days shown.
explanation: A single yellow line along the edge of a road means that you must not park there during the times shown on the accompanying information plate.

text: What does this road marking and information plate together mean?
options: Taxi rank at times shown.
No parking at any time.
Parking not allowed at the times shown.
Loading bay at times shown.
explanation: A single yellow line along the edge of a road means that you must not park there during the times shown on the accompanying information plate.

text: What does this road marking mean?
options: A driver may not overtake along this road.
A driver must not cross the broken white line unless it is safe to do so.
A driver may overtake provided they do not cross the broken white line.
A driver may not park along this road.
explanation: A broken white line along the centre of the road means you must not cross the line unless it is safe to do so when overtaking or passing.

text: What do these road markings mean?
options: No parking allowed.
Dual carriageway ahead.
No overtaking allowed.
Continuous white lines ahead.
explanation: Double broken white lines along the centre of the road alert you to continuous white lines ahead. Do not cross them unless it is safe to do so.

text: If driving from A to B, what do these road markings mean?
options: A driver may overtake if it is safe to do so.
Road narrows ahead.
Dual carriageway ahead.
A driver may not overtake.
explanation: Where there is a broken white line and a continuous white line along the centre of the road, you must obey the line that is nearest to you. In this case you may cross the lines as long as it is safe to do so.

text: If driving from A to B, what do these road markings mean?
options: A driver may not cross the lines to overtake.
A driver may cross the lines to overtake.
Oncoming traffic may not cross the lines to overtake.
Only motorcyclists may cross the lines to overtake.
explanation: Where there is a broken white line and a continuous white line along the centre of the road, you must obey the line that is nearest to you. In this case you may not cross the lines.

text: What does this road marking mean?
options: No entry.
Pedestrian crossing.
The road ahead is a cul-de-sac.
Private vehicles not allowed.
explanation: This road marking indicates a one-way street. You may not enter this street.

text: What does this road marking mean?
options: Parking prohibited at all times.
Taxi parking only.
Keep outside the yellow lines.
Parking prohibited during business hours.
explanation: A double yellow line along the edge of the road means parking is not allowed at any time.

text: What does this road marking mean?
options: Drivers must keep left of the continuous white line.
Only motorcyclists may cross the lines to overtake.
Oncoming traffic may cross the line to overtake.
Drivers may cross the line to overtake.
explanation: A single continuous white line along the centre of the road means all traffic must keep to the left of the line. You are not permitted to overtake or perform a U-turn on this section of road.

text: What does the broken yellow line road marking mean?
options: The edge of the carriageway or hard shoulder.
No stopping for any reason except in an emergency.
Parking prohibited at all times.
Slow lane for heavy vehicles only.
explanation: A single broken yellow line along the side of the road marks the edge of the carriageway/hard shoulder. This is normally for the use of pedestrians and cyclists. As a driver, however, you may use it briefly to allow faster traffic to overtake, but only where it is safe to do so.

text: What does this traffic light mean?
options: Proceed if the way is clear.
The traffic lights are out of order.
Stop, unless it is unsafe to do so.
Prepare to move off.
explanation: When the traffic light is showing amber you must not go beyond the stop line unless you so close to the traffic lights that stopping would be dangerous.

text: What does this traffic light mean?
options: Traffic must stop at the traffic light.
Traffic may proceed but not turn right.
Give way to any oncoming traffic turning right.
Traffic may proceed if the way is clear.
explanation: You may proceed on a green traffic light if it is safe to do so.

text: What colour traffic light comes on after the green?
options: Flashing amber.
Green arrow.
Red only.
Amber only.
explanation: The normal sequence of traffic lights is red–green–amber.

text: What colour traffic light comes on after a non-flashing amber light?
options: Red only.
Flashing red light.
Green only.
Flashing amber light.
explanation: The normal sequence of traffic lights is red–green–amber.

text: What do flashing amber lights at a pelican crossing mean?
options: Danger ahead. A driver must stop and wait until the light stops flashing.
Drivers have right of way.
Stop and give way to pedestrians - proceed if the way is clear.
A driver is entering a special speed limit area.
explanation: A flashing amber light at a pelican crossing means you must yield to pedestrians. You may proceed, however, if the crossing is clear.

text: Which car, if any, is parked incorrectly?
options: Neither car.
Both cars.
The green car.
The red car.
explanation: It is an offence to park within 15 metres before or 5 metres after a pedestrian crossing. Parking in this manner may restrict the zone of vision of drivers approaching the crossing and endanger pedestrians.

text: What should a driver do when approaching traffic lights that change from green to amber?
options: Accelerate to clear the junction.
Stop the vehicle immediately.
Sound the horn while proceeding through the junction.
Stop, unless it is unsafe to do so.
explanation: When you are approaching a set of traffic lights showing green, you should take care and be prepared to stop if the amber light comes on.

text: What should a driver do at an amber traffic light?
options: Continue only if sure that the junction is clear of pedestrians.
Continue as there is no traffic at the junction.
Stop at the line unless it is not safe to do so.
Make sure to pass the lights before they turn red.
explanation: By law you must stop at an amber traffic light if it is safe to do so.

text: What restriction applies to a driver’s full licence if they have passed their test on a vehicle with automatic transmission?
options: They must continue to display L plates.
They may not drive on motorways.
They may not drive at speeds of more that 80 km/h.
They may not drive vehicles with manual transmission.
explanation: If you pass your driving test in a vehicle fitted with automatic transmission, a code 78 will be noted on the full licence in the restrictions/information column.

text: What roads are learner permit holders allowed to drive on?
options: All roads except national roads.
All roads except dual-carriageways.
All roads except motorways and dual-carriageways.
All roads except motorways.
explanation: A learner permit holder must not drive on a motorway. It is a serious offence to do so.

text: How should an L plate be composed?
options: A green L on a white background.
A red L on a transparent background.
A white L on a red background.
A red L on a white background.
explanation: L plates should be displayed front and rear. The plates should be a red L on a white background and should be not less than 15 cm high with a border of at least 2 cm. A learner motorcyclist must wear a yellow tabard displaying L plates front and rear. The L plates must be not less than 15 cm high on a white background.

text: Which roads are learner permit holders not allowed to drive on?
options: They may not drive on national roads.
They may not drive on dual carriageways.
They may not drive on rural roads.
They may not drive on motorways.
explanation: A learner permit holder must not drive on a motorway. It is a serious offence to do so.

text: Is it permitted to use a vehicle in a public place without a current tax disc displayed?
options: No, only vintage vehicles are exempt from displaying a tax disc.
Yes, but for not more than 10 days after the expiry of the previous disc.
Yes, but for not more than one month after the expiry of the previous disc.
No, all motor vehicles must display a current tax disc.
explanation: A motor vehicle must be taxed and must display the up-to-date tax disk before it may be taken on the road.

text: If a driver wishes to drive a vehicle but the tax disc is expired, what should they do?
options: They should tax it immediately.
They should drive it only in case of an emergency.
They should contact the Gardaí for approval.
They should renew it within 10 days of expiry.
explanation: A motor vehicle must be taxed and must display the up-to-date tax disc before it may be taken on the road.

text: If a driver wishes to drive another vehicle which is not currently taxed, would they be allowed to transfer the current tax disc from their own vehicle onto it?
options: Under circumstances when the proper form has been completed and sent to the local Motor Tax Office.
Under no circumstances should a tax disc be transferred to another vehicle.
Yes, provided their own vehicle is not being used at the same time.
Only on a temporary basis if the other vehicle is subject to a lower rate of tax.
explanation: A motor vehicle must be taxed and must display its own current tax disc before it may be taken on the road. The tax disc includes information about the vehicle, including its make and model, colour and registration number.

text: When a vehicle is being driven by a person who is not the owner, who is responsible for ensuring that the vehicle is taxed and that a current tax disc is displayed?
options: The owner is the only one responsible.
The driver is the only one responsible.
The Gardaí have total responsibility in this area.
The driver and/or the owner of the vehicle are responsible.
explanation: If you are the owner or the driver of a vehicle, you must ensure that it is taxed and that it displays an up-to-date tax disc before you take it on the road.

text: When must a current tax disc be displayed on a new vehicle on a public road?
options: At all times when the vehicle is on a public road.
Not later than 1 month after registration.
Only when driving on motorways.
Not later than 10 days after registration.
explanation: A motor vehicle must be taxed before it may be taken on the road, and it must always display an up-to-date tax disc.

text: If a vehicle is being driven by someone who is not the owner but has the owner’s consent, who should ensure that the driver is properly insured?
options: The insurance company.
The driver and the vehicle owner.
The vehicle owner only.
The driver only.
explanation: All drivers must have insurance covering them to drive a vehicle on a public road. It is a serious offence to drive a vehicle that is not insured. It is also an offence to allow a vehicle that you own to be driven by an uninsured driver.

text: Is a driver still insured to drive their vehicle after their insurance policy has expired?
options: The driver is insured up to 7 days after the expiry of the policy.
The driver is not insured after the expiry of the policy.
The driver is insured up to 14 days after the expiry of the policy.
The driver is insured up to 10 days after the expiry of the policy.
explanation: All drivers must have insurance covering them to drive a vehicle on a public road. The vehicle must display an up-to-date insurance disc.

text: If a driver wishes to drive another privately-owned vehicle but they are uncertain if they are insured to drive that vehicle, what should they do?
options: A driver should contact their own insurer to confirm whether or not their insurance policy covers the driving of other vehicles.
Drive if there is an insurance disc on the vehicle.
Transfer the insurance disc from their own vehicle on to the vehicle they wish to drive.
Drive it provided that they tell their insurance company within 10 days and agree to pay any additional premium.
explanation: If you are in any doubt about your insurance cover, you should discuss the matter with your insurance company. It is a serious offence to drive without insurance.

text: When a driver wishes to drive a vehicle and they are not sure if they are covered by insurance, what should they do?
options: They should check with their local Motor Taxation Office to see if they are insured.
They should check with their local Garda station to see if they are insured.
They should not drive until their insurance company confirms that they are insured.
They should check with their local NDLS office to see if they are insured.
explanation: If you are in any doubt about your insurance cover, you should discuss the matter with your insurance company. It is a serious offence to drive without insurance.

text: What is the minimum insurance cover a driver needs to drive on a public road?
options: Third party.
Third party, fire and theft.
Comprehensive.
Personal accident.
explanation: As a motorist, you must have a minimum of third party insurance.

text: If a driver passes their test using a vehicle with automatic transmission, which vehicles are they licensed to drive?
options: Only manual vehicles in the licence category.
All vehicles in the licence category.
All vehicles in the licence category but only automatic vehicles on a motorway.
Only automatic vehicles in the licence category.
explanation: If you pass your driving test in an automatic or adapted vehicle, your full licence will apply to that type of vehicle only. A licence restricted to automatic vehicles will have a code 78 indicated in the restrictions/information column of the licence.

text: Which vehicle is exempt from speed limits when being used in an emergency?
options: Doctor on call.
Fire Brigade.
Breakdown recovery.
Mountain rescue.
explanation: In the course of their duty Gardaí, Fire Brigade and Ambulance personnel are exempt from some traffic laws including speed limits, as long as they do not put other road users in danger. If you hear or see a Garda or emergency vehicle approaching under emergency conditions, be extra careful and give way, if it is safe to do so.

text: Where can drivers locate the Maximum Authorised Mass (MAM) of their vehicle?
options: On a metal plate on the vehicle.
On the tax disc.
On the NCT disc.
On the insurance disc.
