explanation: The plate displaying the Maximum Authorised Mass (MAM) of a vehicle is normally located under the bonnet or in the passenger compartment. If you are not sure where it is located on your vehicle, check the driver’s handbook supplied with the vehicle.

text: Which vehicle is exempt from speed limits when being used in an emergency?
options: Mountain rescue.
Doctor on call.
Breakdown recovery.
Ambulance.
explanation: In the course of their duty Gardaí, Fire Brigade and Ambulance personnel are exempt from some traffic laws including speed limits, as long as they do not put other road users in danger. If you hear or see a Garda or emergency vehicle approaching under emergency conditions, be extra careful and give way, if it is safe to do so.

text: Which vehicle is exempt from speed limits when being used in an emergency?
options: Garda.
Breakdown recovery.
Mountain rescue.
Doctor on call.
explanation: In the course of their duty Gardaí, Fire Brigade and Ambulance personnel are exempt from some traffic laws including speed limits, as long as they do not put other road users in danger. If you hear or see a Garda or emergency vehicle approaching under emergency conditions, be extra careful and give way, if it is safe to do so.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Traffic queues likely ahead.
Three vehicles may queue ahead.
Parking for works vehicles on left.
Steep incline ahead.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that there may be traffic queues ahead, possibly due to temporary traffic lights at the works. Proceed with caution.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Uneven surface.
Soft margin on left.
Parking on left only.
Slippery surface.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the road surface may be uneven, possibly due to the resurfacing of part of a lane. Proceed with caution.

text: Where should L plates be displayed on cars?
options: On the front only.
On the rear only.
Both front and rear.
On the driver’s side only.
explanation: The holder of a learner permit must display L plates on the front and rear of their car at all times when driving on public roads.

text: How would a driver calculate the maximum overall permitted weight of their vehicle?
options: By calculating the unladen weight of the vehicle plus the weight of the fuel.
By adding the unladen weight of the vehicle to the load permitted to be carried.
By checking the unladen weight of the vehicle.
By checking the weight of the load which may be carried.
explanation: The maximum permitted weight of a vehicle is the sum of the unladen weight of the vehicle plus the maximum load that may be carried in it. It is an offence to overload a vehicle, as it reduces your ability to control it effectively.

text: What is the Maximum Authorised Mass (MAM) of a car that may be driven by the holder of a Category B driving licence?
options: 3,000 kilograms.
4,000 kilograms.
3,500 kilograms.
3,750 kilograms.
explanation: The holder of a Category B driving licence is not permitted to drive a vehicle with a MAM of more than 3,500 kg. This restriction is noted on the licence.

text: What is the maximum number of passengers that may be carried in a vehicle driven by the holder of a Category B driving licence?
options: 9 passengers.
10 passengers.
7 passengers.
8 passengers.
explanation: The holder of a Category B driving licence is not permitted to drive a vehicle that has seating for more than 8 passengers excluding the driver.

text: When can the holder of a Category W learner permit carry a passenger?
options: Only when the passenger also holds a Category W driving licence and the vehicle is designed to carry a passenger.
Only when the passenger holds a Category AM driving licence.
Only when the passenger also holds a Category W driving licence.
Only when the passenger holds a Category AM driving licence and the vehicle is designed to carry a passenger.
explanation: The holder of a Category W learner permit may carry a passenger in the vehicle only if: The vehicle is designed to take a passenger, and the passenger has held a full driving licence in Category W for two or more years.

text: Is a driver allowed to use rebated (green) diesel fuel in a car on a public road?
options: Green diesel may be used in a car only in winter months.
Green diesel may be used in a car only if the car is a taxis.
Green diesel may never be used in a car.
Green diesel may be used in a car only in summer months.
explanation: If, in its normal use, a vehicle is used on a public road, it must use unmarked (white) diesel, as the appropriate excise duties are included in the purchase price. Drivers can be prosecuted for using green diesel in a vehicle on a public road.

text: When must a tractor or works vehicle be fitted with a rear-view mirror?
options: A rear-view mirror is not required in a tractor or works vehicle.
A rear-view mirror must be fitted only when towing a trailer over 8 metres long.
A rear-view mirror must always be fitted.
A rear-view mirror must be fitted only when towing a trailer.
explanation: All vehicles used on a public road must have a rear-view mirror. The mirror should be used to enable the driver to see the traffic and road conditions behind and to each side.

text: What is the maximum gross weight of a vehicle that may be driven by the holder of a Category B driving licence?
options: 3,450 kilograms
3,250 kilograms
3,000 kilograms
3,500 kilograms
explanation: The holder of a Category B driving licence is not permitted to drive a vehicle with a design gross vehicle weight of more than 3,500 kg. This restriction is noted on the licence.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: The driver must stop for school crossing ahead.
The driver must stop their vehicle.
The driver must give way to traffic coming from the right.
explanation: This sign appears at junctions where a minor road joins a major road. You must stop your vehicle completely at a STOP sign.

text: What must a driver do when this sign is accompanied by a white stop line on the road?
options: Stop at the line only if you see traffic approaching.
Stop past the line.
Stop at the line.
explanation: When accompanied by a STOP sign, the white stop line indicates the point at which you must stop your vehicle.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: No height restriction ahead.
No entry ahead.
Cul-de-sac ahead.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must not proceed in the direction of the arrow. This is displayed to prevent traffic going in the wrong direction – for example, the wrong way up a one-way street.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: No right turn.
Cul-de-sac to the right.
Turn right only.
explanation: This sign is displayed at a junction where you must not turn right.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Maximum speed is 30 km/h.
Minimum speed is 30 km/h.
Speed limit continues for 30 kilometres.
explanation: This sign tells you that the maximum legal speed limit permitted for this section of road is 30 km/h. These signs are commonly found in slow zones in residential areas.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Speed limit continues for 50 kilometres.
Minimum speed is 50 km/h.
Maximum speed is 50 km/h.
explanation: This sign tells you that the maximum legal speed limit permitted for this section of road is 50 km/h.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Minimum speed is 60 km/h.
Maximum speed is 60 km/h.
Speed limit continues for 60 metres.
explanation: This sign tells you that the maximum legal speed limit permitted for this section of road is 60 km/h.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Speed limit continues for 80 metres.
Maximum speed is 80 km/h.
Minimum speed is 80 km/h.
explanation: This sign tells you that the maximum legal speed limit permitted for this section of road is 80 km/h.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Minimum speed is 100 km/h.
Maximum speed is 100 km/h.
Speed limit continues for 100 metres.
explanation: This sign tells you that the maximum legal speed limit permitted for this section of road is 100 km/h.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Parking is not allowed.
Private vehicles parking only.
Public service vehicles parking only.
explanation: This sign tells you that parking is prohibited in both directions.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Stop and wait for green light before proceeding.
The driver must stop when red lights show.
Stop and wait for amber light before proceeding.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that you must stop when red lights show. This sign may be displayed at a railway level crossing.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The cyclist intends to turn right.
The cyclist intends to stop.
The cyclist intends to turn left.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the cyclist intends to make a left-hand turn.

text: What does this traffic light mean?
options: The driver must stop and wait until the full green light appears.
The driver may proceed in the direction of the green arrow if the way is clear.
The driver must divert to the right.
explanation: A green arrow (filter light) means that traffic may proceed in the direction of the arrow if it is safe to do so.

text: What does this traffic light mean?
options: Traffic must proceed if safe to do so.
Traffic may stop if safe to do so.
Traffic must stop at the traffic light.
explanation: A red light means STOP. You must not go beyond the stop line or (if there is no stop line) beyond the light.

text: What road users must comply with traffic lights (including pedestrian lights)?
options: All road users.
Drivers and cyclists only.
Drivers and pedestrians only.
explanation: All road users including pedestrians must comply with traffic controls. Drivers should be aware that traffic lights and pedestrian lights can be combined at junctions and should show caution and consideration to pedestrians.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Slippery road up ahead.
Uneven surface on left.
Loose chippings on road.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the road ahead has been resurfaced and there may be loose chippings. You should reduce speed while driving through this area as the loose chippings could affect your vehicle’s road holding and braking.

text: When must the holder of a learner permit display L plates on their car?
options: When driving unaccompanied by a full licence holder.
When driving on their first learner permit.
At all times when driving.
explanation: The holder of a learner permit must display L plates on the front and rear of their car at all times when driving on public roads.

text: When can a child under the age of sixteen drive a tractor on a public road?
options: Children under 16 are not allowed to drive a tractor on a public road.
A child under 16 is allowed to drive a tractor on a public road when they hold a learner permit.
A child under 16 is allowed to drive a tractor on a public road when accompanied by a fully licensed driver.
explanation: Persons under 16 years of age are not permitted to drive a tractor in a public place.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Pass on the left.
Steep decline to the left.
Keep left.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must keep left. It is usually displayed at a traffic island in the centre of the road and also used on occasion to control traffic at roadworks.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Steep decline from the left.
Traffic crossing from the left.
Keep right.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must keep right. It is usually found in a one-way system where the traffic is required to keep to the right and also used on occasion to control traffic at roadworks.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: No right turn.
Turn right ahead.
Dangerous bend to the right ahead.
explanation: This sign is displayed at a junction where you may not turn right.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: No left turn.
Turn right only.
No right turn.
explanation: This sign is displayed at a junction where you may not turn left.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Traffic merging at 120 metres ahead.
Minimum speed is 120 km/h.
Maximum speed is 120 km/h.
explanation: This sign tells you that the maximum legal speed limit permitted for this section of road is 120 km/h.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Parking prohibited at the times shown.
Parking permitted during the times shown.
Maximum parking for one hour during times shown.
explanation: These signs tells you that parking is permitted in both directions, but only at the times shown on the information plate.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Road closed during the times shown.
Pedestrianised street - no access for vehicles.
Clearway - no stopping or parking during the times shown.
explanation: A clearway sign means that stopping or parking is not permitted in this area during the times shown on the information plate.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Roads closed ahead to both left and right.
Cul-de-sac to both left and right.
Staggered crossroads ahead with roads of equal importance.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a staggered junction ahead with roads to the left and right. Be aware that vehicles may be emerging from these roads.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Dual carriageway ends.
Road narrows ahead.
Tunnel ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of the end of a dual carriageway. You will soon be entering a 2-way road.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Three lanes ahead.
Crossing traffic ahead.
Three hundred meters to the next exit.
explanation: This is a motorway information sign that tells you that the next exit off the motorway is 300 metres ahead.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: 100 metres to the next exit.
Sharp descent for 100 metres.
Low bridge ahead.
explanation: This is a motorway information sign that tells you that the next exit off the motorway is 100 metres ahead.

text: What does this hand signal mean?
options: The cyclist intends to stop.
The cyclist intends to cross the road.
The cyclist intends to turn left.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the cyclist intends to turn left.

text: What does this Garda signal mean?
options: Stop if approaching from the front.
Stop if approaching from behind.
Proceed if approaching from the front.
explanation: When approaching a Garda giving this signal you must stop.

text: What does this road marking indicate?
options: Traffic calming.
Pedestrian island.
Zebra crossing.
explanation: A zebra crossing is a designated area for pedestrians to cross the road. As a driver you must always yield to pedestrians on a zebra crossing.

text: What is the maximum speed allowed for cars and motorcycles on motorways?
options: 80 km/h.
60 km/h.
explanation: It is illegal to exceed 120 km/h when driving on a motorway.

text: Unless otherwise indicated, what is the maximum speed allowed for cars or motorcycles on national roads?
options: 80 km/h.
60 km/h.
explanation: It is illegal to exceed 100 km/h when driving on a single carriageway national road.

text: Unless otherwise indicated, what is the maximum speed allowed for a car towing a caravan on national roads?
options: 60 km/h.
80 km/h.
explanation: When towing a caravan on a national road, it is illegal to exceed 80 km/h – excessive speed will make such a vehicle unstable.

text: Unless otherwise indicated, what is the maximum speed allowed for a car towing a caravan on a motorway?
options: 90 km/h.
80 km/h.
explanation: When towing a caravan on a motorway it is illegal to exceed 80 km/h – excessive speed will make such a vehicle unstable.

text: Unless otherwise indicated, what is the maximum speed allowed for a car towing a trailer on a motorway?
options: 60 km/h.
80 km/h.
explanation: When towing a trailer on a motorway it is illegal to exceed 80 km/h – excessive speed will make such a vehicle unstable.

text: Who is authorized to see a driver’s vehicle registration document?
options: A member of the car recovery company or anyone assisting in the recovery.
A Garda may ask you to produce the vehicle’s registration document at a named Garda station.
Any Fire Brigade or Ambulance personnel at the scene of a collision the driver has been involved in.
Any person with whom the driver is involved in a collision.
explanation: A Garda may demand to see your driving licence at any time, and you should always carry this with you when driving. A Garda may also examine your insurance disc, tax disc and NCT disc (if applicable). A Garda may ask you to produce other documents (including the vehicle’s registration document) at a named Garda station within 10 days.

text: What does this sign mean?
options: Straight ahead only.
Height restriction ahead.
Motorway ahead.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must proceed straight ahead. This sign is usually displayed on the entry to a one-way street.

text: What effect does carrying a load have on a vehicle’s braking ability?
options: It increases the efficiency of the brakes.
It increases the distance required to stop.
It reduces the distance required to stop.
It has no effect provided the brakes are good.
explanation: When driving a vehicle which is carrying a load, the driver should be aware that the forces acting on the vehicle will increase the distance required to stop. The driver should allow for this by increasing the distance from the vehicle in front.

text: What effect does towing a loaded trailer have on stopping ability?
options: It increases the efficiency of the brakes.
It reduces the stopping distance.
It increases the stopping distance.
It has no effect on stopping distance.
explanation: If you are towing a loaded trailer, you need to be aware that your braking distance could be considerably greater, depending on the weight and size of the trailer. The driver should allow for this by increasing the distance from the vehicle in front.

text: Which of the following statements is true in relation to tyre pressure and driving on a motorway?
options: The driver should increase the rear tyre pressure in order to cope with sustained high speed.
The driver should reduce tyre pressure because high speeds will cause them to heat up.
The driver should ensure that tyre pressure is correct, in line with the manufacturer’s recommendations.
The driver should increase the front tyre pressure in order to cope with sustained high speed.
explanation: The driver should ensure that the tyre pressure of their vehicle is correct at all times. Correct tyre pressure is especially important when travelling long distances, on motorways and at speed.

text: What should a driver do when involved in an incident where nobody is injured but the vehicles are causing a danger or obstruction on the road?
options: Halt all traffic until it has been established who is at fault.
Take care when moving damaged vehicles and make every effort to warn other traffic.
Move all passengers and put a red warning triangle on the road.
Wait for the Gardaí to arrive before moving the vehicles.
explanation: In a collision where nobody is injured and there is only minor damage to vehicles, the vehicles should be moved to the side of the road to ensure that they do not cause an obstruction or endanger other road users.

text: What should a driver do if involved in an incident where there is damage to property only?
options: There is no need to report the incident if there is no damage to the vehicle.
It is only necessary to report the incident to the Gardaí within 10 days.
It is not necessary to report it to the Gardaí provided it has been reported to the property owner.
Report the incident both to the property owner and the Gardaí within 48 hours.
explanation: If the incident causes damage to property only and there is a Garda present, it must be reported to the Garda. If there is no Garda present, the owner or the person in charge of the property must be informed. If neither are present then the relevant information must be provided at a Garda station as soon as possible.

text: What should a driver do where a person has been injured in a collision?
options: Move the victim only if there is a risk of fire or further injury.
Always move the victim and the vehicles.
Move the victim to the side of the road.
Move the vehicles out of the way to avoid causing obstruction.
explanation: Never move an injured person at the scene of a collision unless there is a risk of fire or further injury. Moving an injured person could add to their injuries. Trained personnel know best how to attend to injured persons. Call the emergency services (on 999 or 112) or make sure that someone else has called them.

text: What type of drink should be given to a person who has been injured in a collision?
options: A hot drink.
A cold drink.
A non-alcoholic drink.
No drink should be given.
explanation: A person who has been injured in a collision should not be given anything to drink, as this could cause them to choke. Ideally trained personnel should be consulted before attending to an injured person. Call the emergency services (on 999 or 112) or make sure that someone else has called them.

text: What should a driver do to assist a person who is unconscious following a collision?
options: Try to keep the person warm with a blanket or overcoat.
Move the person to the nearest hospital immediately.
Try and get the person to drink something warm.
Raise the person’s head and hold it in that position.
explanation: If a person is unconscious following a collision, a driver should try to keep them warm with a blanket or overcoat until the emergency services arrive. Call the emergency services (on 999 or 112) or make sure that someone else has called them.

text: If a driver is involved in a serious collision with an uninsured motorist, where nobody is injured, who should it be reported to?
options: The National Driver Licence Service (NDLS).
The local Motor Taxation Office.
The Irish Insurance Federation.
The driver’s insurance company and the Gardaí.
explanation: If you are involved in a serious collision, you should always report it to the Gardaí and to your insurance company.

text: What should a driver do if involved in a collision with another vehicle where nobody is injured?
options: Submit a written report to the Insurance Bureau of Ireland.
Give their name and address only to the other person.
Exchange all relevant details with the other driver.
Exchange no details but report the incident to the Gardaí.
explanation: If a you are involved in a collision with another vehicle where nobody is injured, you should exchange all the relevant details with the other driver – including name, address, vehicle registration, make and model and all insurance details.

text: What should a driver do if they arrive at the scene of a collision involving a vehicle carrying hazardous materials?
options: Keep well clear and call the emergency services.
Try to move the vehicle to a safe place.
Contact the haulage company who own the vehicle.
Try to prevent any further leakage of hazardous materials before raising the alarm.
explanation: If a driver arrives at the scene of a collision involving a vehicle carrying hazardous materials, they should keep well clear of the scene. Call the emergency services on 999 or 112 and give them as much information as you can about the marking labels on the vehicle. You should also warn other road users about the danger. Allow the emergency services to do any rescuing.

text: How does the driver know the vehicle’s total load-carrying capacity?
options: By referring to the vehicle manufacturer’s specification.
By measuring the size of the boot.
By counting the number of seats.
By checking the horse power of the engine.
explanation: Design Gross Vehicle Weight is the term used by manufacturers for the weight of the vehicle together with the maximum load it is designed to carry. Drivers must understand the carrying capacity of their vehicle. Overloading your vehicle will make it more difficult to control, and its an offence.

text: What determines the maximum allowed towing capacity of a vehicle?
options: The size of the tyres on the vehicle.
The combined weight of the vehicle and its trailer.
The manufacturer’s specifications.
The strength of the tow bar.
explanation: The maximum weight that your vehicle can safely tow is specified by the manufacturer, and is usually set out in the driver’s handbook for the vehicle, and in some cases on a plate attached to the vehicle. This is the safe towing limit for the vehicle and you should not exceed it.

text: What effect can overloading a vehicle have on its road-holding?
options: Provided the load is evenly distributed, it improves the stability of the vehicle.
The load can make the vehicle more difficult to control.
The load can make the vehicle more difficult to control, but only when going downhill.
The load can make the vehicle more difficult to control, but only when reversing.
explanation: Overloading your vehicle will make it more difficult to control. Remember: It’s an offence to overload a vehicle.

text: What would be the effect of overloading a vehicle with passengers or goods?
options: It would improve the vehicle’s road-holding ability.
It would not have any effect provided speed is reduced.
Overloading will not reduce the ability to control the vehicle.
It would reduce the driver’s ability to control the vehicle.
explanation: Overloading your vehicle will make it more difficult to control, and will increase the risk of a collision.

text: What effect could an unevenly distributed load have on a vehicle?
options: It could make the vehicle unstable while turning.
It could cause the clutch to slip while accelerating.
It could cause the vehicle to overheat.
It could cause the gear box to overheat.
explanation: When loading a vehicle you should ensure that the load is distributed evenly. An unevenly distributed load may change the vehicle’s centre of gravity and this could affect the braking and steering.

text: Why is it important to ensure that the vehicle headlights are correctly aligned?
options: To increase the lifespan of the headlights.
To enable the driver to see properly.
To reduce battery consumption.
To enable the driver to drive faster in the dark.
explanation: A driver should ensure their headlights are properly aligned so as not to dazzle oncoming drivers and also to see properly themselves.

text: In general, how frequently should a vehicle’s lights be checked?
options: When wintertime approaches.
Daily before driving.
At major service intervals.
At minor service intervals.
explanation: A driver is responsible for their vehicle’s roadworthiness and they should check it daily before driving. Among the checks they should make are that all the lights are clean and in working order.

text: What effect can a broken lens have on headlights?
options: It can cause the bulb to overheat.
It can reduce and distort the beam.
It can increase the brightness of the beam in the other headlight.
It can cause other bulbs to blow if not fixed immediately.
explanation: A driver is responsible for their vehicle’s roadworthiness and they should check it at regular intervals. Among the checks they should make are that all the lights are in working order. If they find defects in the lights, such as a broken lens, they should have them repaired or replaced as soon as possible.

text: A driver wishes to drive at night, but the offside (right-hand side) headlight bulb is blown. What should the driver do?
options: Not drive until the bulb is replaced.
Replace it temporarily with the brake-light bulb.
Drive with the hazard lights on.
Replace it temporarily with the nearside (left-hand side) bulb.
explanation: A driver is responsible for their vehicle’s roadworthiness and they should check it at regular intervals. Drivers must not drive on the road unless their vehicle’s headlights are in good working order, adjusted properly and clean.

text: How would a driver know that a brake-light bulb is not working?
options: They would notice the brake pedal become firmer under pressure.
They would notice the brake pedal getting softer under pressure.
By standing at the rear of the vehicle and checking as another person presses the brake pedal.
By standing at the rear of the vehicle and getting another person to turn on side lights.
explanation: In order for a driver to know that the rear brake lights are working correctly, they should stand at the rear of the vehicle and check that the brake lights come on while another person presses the brakes.

text: What does this light mean?
options: The gear box is over-heating.
The oil level is too low.
The engine is over-heating.
The battery is not charging.
explanation: If the battery warning light comes on whilst driving, it means there is some kind of problem with the electrical charging system of the vehicle and the battery is not being charged properly. The driver should get this checked by a professional as soon as possible. It is important to understand the meaning of your vehicle’s warning lights, information on which can be found in the vehicle’s handbook.

text: What does this light mean?
options: The high-beam headlights are switched on.
The reversing light is switched on.
The headlight beam should be dipped.
The number plate light is faulty.
explanation: All vehicles are fitted with warning lights to alert the driver to different things. This light comes on when the full beam headlights are turned on. It is important to understand the meaning of your vehicle’s warning lights, information on which can be found in the vehicle’s handbook.

text: What does this light mean?
options: Low engine oil level.
Low engine coolant level.
Low brake fluid level.
Low battery fluid level.
explanation: If the engine oil warning light comes on, it means that the engine oil level/pressure has dropped. You should not drive the vehicle until the problem is fixed. If the light comes on while driving, pull over and stop in a safe place as soon as possible. It is important to understand the meaning of your vehicle’s warning lights, information on which can be found in the vehicle’s handbook.

text: What does this light mean?
options: Right-hand fog light on.
Directional indicator on.
Brake light bulb blown.
Headlight bulb blown.
explanation: All vehicles are fitted with warning lights to alert you to different things. This light tells you that the directional indicator is on. If this light is still on after you have completed your manoeuvre, cancel it to avoid misleading other road users. It is important to understand the meaning of your vehicle’s warning lights, information on which can be found in the vehicle’s handbook.

text: What should a driver do if a system warning light lights up on the dashboard of their vehicle whilst driving?
options: Continue for a distance to see if the light goes out.
Continue to drive and listen for any unusual sounds.
Carry on and check the problem later.
Stop and check the problem.
explanation: If a system warning light lights up while you are driving, you should stop in a safe place as soon as possible and investigate the problem before deciding what action to take. It is important to understand the meaning of your vehicle’s warning lights, information on which can be found in the vehicle’s handbook.

text: What should a driver do if a red system warning light lights up on the dashboard of their vehicle?
options: Continue on and see if it goes out.
Stop and investigate the cause.
Drive to the nearest garage and have it checked.
Continue on and listen for any unusual sounds.
explanation: If a red system warning light comes on while you are driving, you should stop in a safe place as soon as possible and investigate the problem before deciding what action to take. It is important to understand the meaning of your vehicle’s warning lights, information on which can be found in the vehicle’s handbook.

text: What is the purpose of the red reflectors at the rear of a vehicle?
options: They warn the driver behind to switch to main beam.
They reflect light at night to make other road users aware of the vehicle.
They warn pedestrians of the vehicle’s location.
They are a substitute in case of brake-light failure.
explanation: Motor vehicles are fitted with red reflectors to make it easier to be seen by other road users. Drivers should keep reflectors clean, intact and check them by shining a light on them to make sure that they are working effectively. Whilst driving, drivers should be cautious as red reflectors may be an indication of both parked/stationery or moving vehicles ahead.

text: If, when driving along, the driver notices that the engine power is lower than normal, what should they do?
options: Switch to a different fuel.
Have the vehicle checked by a competent person.
Replace the engine oil filter.
Adjust the fuel mixture control mechanism.
explanation: If the driver notices that the vehicle seems underpowered when driving, this could present a number of problems, e.g. lack of power when overtaking. The driver should have it checked by a competent person as soon as possible as there may be a number of causes, some of which may deteriorate further.

text: While driving, the driver notices the vehicle temperature gauge showing red. What should they do?
options: Stop in a safe place and have the problem investigated.
Drive to the nearest service depot and top-up the water in the radiator.
Remove the filler cap from the radiator and check for leakage.
Do not drive until an anti-waxing agent is added to the coolant.
explanation: Many vehicles are fitted with various warning lights and gauges. A warning light or a red zone on a temperature gauge means the engine is starting to overheat and the vehicle should not be driven until the problem is rectified. Refer to the vehicle handbook for further information and guidance or seek advice from a competent person.

text: What should a driver do if they notice steam rising from the engine compartment?
options: Remove the filler cap from the coolant bottle.
Increase speed to increase the air flow into the engine compartment.
Stop where safe and investigate the cause.
Top up with anti-freeze immediately.
explanation: If a driver notices steam rising from the engine compartment of their vehicle, they should stop where safe and only investigate the cause once it has cooled down. Do not remove a radiator or header tank cap when the engine is hot. Steam rising from the engine is an indication that the engine is overheating and it should not continue to be driven. Refer to the vehicle handbook for further information and guidance or seek advice from a competent person.

text: If a driver notices that structural parts of their vehicle’s body have been affected by rust, what should they do?
options: Have paint sprayed over it of the same colour.
Have it repaired by a competent repair shop.
Have it sandpapered and keep the affected area dry.
Treat the area with grease and paint over it.
explanation: Over time vehicles may become affected by rust to various degrees. Drivers should inspect their vehicles periodically and if they find signs of rust they should have it assessed and repaired if necessary to prevent further deterioration. A weakened vehicle structure may have serious consequences in the event of a collision.

text: After changing a wheel on a vehicle, which of the following should be checked soon afterwards?
options: The wheel nuts.
The tyre tread depth.
The air valve.
The brake pad clearance.
explanation: After changing a wheel on a vehicle it is recommended to check the wheel nuts after a short period of driving to ensure they are still properly secured.

text: In general, how often should a driver check the tyre pressure of a vehicle?
options: Monthly.
Six monthly.
Annually.
Regularly.
explanation: Drivers have a legal responsibility to make sure that their vehicle is roadworthy. To do this, they should carry out regular, weekly and periodic checks, including a weekly tyre pressure check. Incorrectly inflated tyres may cause vehicle instability, uneven tyre wear and longer stopping distances.

text: What is the main reason for maintaining the correct tyre pressures?
options: To help provide optimum road holding.
To reduce engine wear.
To stop the vehicle from sloping to the left.
To help maintain the correct ground clearance.
explanation: The vehicle manufacturer specifies the pressure to which tyres on a vehicle should be inflated. This is the pressure that gives the best performance in road holding, efficient braking and fuel consumption. Some manufacturers specify different pressures for front and rear tyres.

text: A fault in which component may lead to uneven or excessive tyre wear?
options: Clutch.
Suspension.
Accelerator.
Gearbox.
explanation: If a vehicle has a worn suspension it may lead to uneven or excessive tyre wear. If drivers notice that their tyres are unevenly worn, they should investigate the reason and have it repaired by a competent person.

text: What can be affected by driving on under-inflated tyres?
options: Oil pressure.
The exhaust system.
Fuel consumption.
The coolant system.
explanation: Incorrect tyre pressure adversely affects many of a vehicle’s systems, including brakes, suspension and steering. In particular, under-inflated tyres can increase the vehicle’s fuel consumption. Check tyre pressures regularly and ensure they are inflated as per manufacturer’s recommendations.

text: When should tyre pressure be checked?
options: When the tyres are part-worn.
When the tyres are cold.
At service intervals only.
When the tyres are hot.
explanation: Drivers should check the tyre pressure in their vehicle at least once a week and before commencing a long journey. For accuracy, do this when the tyres are cold and using a reliable gauge. Tyres should always be inflated according to the vehicle manufacturer’s guidelines, information on which can be found in the vehicle handbook.

text: During a weekly check, a driver notices a badly worn front tyre. What should the driver do?
options: Have the worn tyre replaced.
Fit the worn tyre on one of the rear wheels.
Reduce speed when driving on wet roads.
Check the tyre pressure to ensure it remains constant.
explanation: The tyres are the vehicle’s only contact with the road, the area of contact is small and, if worn, will not grip properly and safely. The quality of the tyres on a vehicle is an important factor in the vehicle’s road holding and braking ability. Drivers should check their tyres regularly and if they notice that a tyre is badly worn, they should replace it immediately. Whilst the minimum legal tread depth for tyres on most vehicles is 1.6 mm (1 mm for motorcycles), drivers should replace a tyre before it becomes this worn.

text: What does worn tread along the edge of the inside of a tyre suggest?
options: Air pressure is high.
The vehicle has been driven too fast around corners.
Air pressure is low.
Steering alignment may be faulty.
explanation: If a driver notices the inside edge of the tyre is worn, this may indicate a problem with the steering alignment. This is a potentially dangerous problem, and should be fixed by a competent person as soon as possible. Failure to do so may result in a blow-out and loss of control of the vehicle.

text: With regard to tyres, what should a driver do before starting a long journey?
options: Check the tyres are inflated to normal air pressure.
Increase the air pressure in the tyres.
Reduce the air pressure in the tyres.
Reduce front tyre air pressure and increase rear tyre air pressure.
explanation: It is important to check the tyre pressure before starting a long journey as incorrect air pressure can adversely affect many of the vehicle’s systems, including brakes, steering, suspension and fuel consumption. Tyres should always be inflated according to the vehicle manufacturer’s guidelines, information on which can be found in the vehicle handbook.

text: What should the driver do to secure the vehicle when changing a front nearside (left-hand side) wheel?
options: Point the front wheels away from the kerb.
Ensure that the vehicle cannot roll when jacked up.
Ensure the gear lever is in neutral.
Point the front wheels towards the kerb.
explanation: If a driver has to change a front nearside (left-hand side) wheel, make sure to do it in a safe place on level ground. Take care, wear high-visibility vest/jacket, use a warning triangle and hazard warning lights as appropriate. The vehicle should be secured by applying the parking brake (handbrake), switching off the engine, engaging a low gear and using a wheel chock if necessary. If unfamiliar with how to change a wheel seek assistance from a competent person.

text: What is the most common cause of heavy steering?
options: Over-inflated tyres.
Badly worn brakes.
Under-inflated tyres.
Poorly oiled steering.
explanation: Heavy steering is when a driver needs to use more effort than usual to turn the steering wheel, this may be as a direct result of under-inflated tyres. Check your tyre pressures but be aware there may be other causes of heavy steering such as low power steering fluid level. Seek advice from a competent person and have this investigated immediately.

text: Which of the following is a driver required to keep in good condition?
options: Seatbelts.
Radio.
Paintwork.
Upholstery.
explanation: Drivers are responsible for their vehicles’ roadworthiness and should check them at regular intervals. Among the checks they should make are that all the seatbelts (drivers and passengers) are clean, untangled and in good working order.

text: What should a driver do if condensation is affecting the vehicle’s windows?
options: Drive for a few kilometres with a window open.
Make sure that all demister vents and windows are closed.
Wipe the windows with the back of the hand.
Dry the windows with a cloth and then use the demister system.
explanation: Make sure the windows are clear and clean at all times so that the driver can see the road and traffic conditions all around. Condensation on the window can seriously impair your ability to make proper observations. Drivers should familiarise themselves with how to correctly set the vehicle’s ventilation system in order to keep the windows clear.

text: What should a driver do if the right-hand headlight bulb fails when driving at night?
options: Drive with the hazard lights on.
Have the bulb replaced immediately.
Replace it temporarily with the left-hand headlight bulb.
Replace it temporarily with the brake light bulb.
explanation: Vehicles (except motorcycles) are required by law to have right and left headlights. Faulty lights should be repaired immediately. A vehicle with only one headlight can cause a hazard to other road users or be mistaken for a motorcycle.

text: A driver has stalled in the middle of an unguarded level crossing and cannot restart the engine. The warning bell is ringing. What should the driver do?
options: Stay at the vehicle and warn the approaching train.
Walk clear of the crossing and phone the signal operator so that trains can be stopped.
Push the vehicle clear of the crossing.
Try to restart the engine in first gear.
explanation: In this situation, the driver and all passengers should get out of the vehicle and immediately use the emergency phone at the crossing to contact the signal operator so that trains can be stopped. If necessary, warn other motorists. Do not return to the vehicle until instructed by the signal operator or emergency services.

text: When attaching a trailer to their vehicle, what must a driver check?
options: That the load is positioned to the rear of the trailer.
That the load is evenly spread.
That the load is positioned to the front of the trailer.
That the trailer has a spare wheel.
explanation: Proper weight distribution helps to ensure the stability of both the towing vehicle and the trailer. In the trailer, the bulk of the load should be over the axles. If a heavy load is positioned at the front of the trailer, this will result in too much nose weight on the hitch of the towing vehicle and make it difficult to steer. If a heavy load is positioned at the rear of the trailer, this will result in reduced weight on the rear axle of the towing vehicle, which will make it more unstable.

text: When attaching a trailer to their vehicle, what must a driver check?
options: That the trailer coupling is attached securely.
That the load is positioned to the front of the trailer.
That the trailer springs are well greased.
That the trailer has a spare wheel.
explanation: Before towing a trailer or a caravan, check that the tow bar is securely attached to the towing vehicle, that the trailer coupling is properly attached to the tow bar and locked in place, and that the breakaway cable is properly connected.

text: What effect do the hazard warning lights have on the brake lights?
options: They have no effect.
They cause the brake lights to switch off completely.
They cause the left and right brake lights to flash alternately.
They cause the brake lights to flash repeatedly.
explanation: The hazard lights work independently of the other lights on the vehicle (except the direction indicators), and have no effect on the brake lights. Use the hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead, when your vehicle is broken down and causing an obstruction, or when you needs to slow down sharply on a motorway.

text: When should a driver use their hazard warning lights?
options: When the brake lights are not working.
When the vehicle has broken down.
When about to pull in and stop.
When parking for a short time on a single yellow line.
explanation: Use the hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead. For example, if a driver’s vehicle has broken down and is stopped on the hard shoulder, they should use the vehicle’s hazard warning lights to warn other road users of their presence.

text: When should a driver use their vehicle’s hazard warning lights?
options: When a following vehicle is too close.
When double parking.
When the brake lights are not working.
When causing an unavoidable obstruction.
explanation: Use the hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead. For example, if a driver’s vehicle is causing an unavoidable obstruction such as being broken down, they should use the vehicle’s hazard warning lights to warn other road users of their presence.

text: When should a driver use their vehicle’s hazard warning lights?
options: When parked at a bend or corner.
When reversing onto a narrow road.
When moving slowly in traffic.
When broken down and causing an obstruction.
explanation: Use the hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead. For example, if a driver’s vehicle is causing an unavoidable obstruction such as being broken down, they should use the vehicle’s hazard warning lights to warn other road users of their presence.

text: What lighting must be on a two-axle car-trailer?
options: Indicators, brake lights, rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights.
Indicators and rear number plate lights only.
Flashing rear tail lights.
Brake lights and indicators only.
explanation: All vehicles, including trailers, must have rear indicators, brake lights, a rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights.

text: In general, how should children under 3 years of age be secured in a vehicle?
options: They should always be placed in the front passenger seat wearing a seat belt.
They should always be carried in an adult’s lap.
They should always sit on the rear passenger seat.
They should always be secured in the correct child seat.
explanation: Safety belts are designed mainly for adults and older children. Children under 3 years of age must be restrained in an appropriate child restraint system. Warning: Never use a rearward facing child car seat in a seat protected by an active frontal airbag.

text: Can a child under the age of 3 years be carried unrestrained in the vehicle’s front passenger seat?
options: No, unless the child is using a child booster seat.
Yes, provided the infant is held securely by an adult.
No, an infant must always be restrained in the correct child seat.
Yes, but only if the vehicle is fitted with active airbags.
explanation: Generally, children must never travel unrestrained in a vehicle. Children under 3 years of age must be restrained in an appropriate child restraint system. Warning: Never use a rearward facing child car seat in a seat protected by an active frontal airbag.

text: If a vehicle breaks down, where should the driver stop?
options: As far to the left as possible.
As far to the right as possible.
In the lane where the problem occurred.
The nearest exit ramp.
explanation: When a vehicle breaks down it is important to move as far in to the left as possible for the convenience of other road users and the safety of the vehicles occupants.

text: What is the quickest way to warn other traffic of a crash?
options: Use hazard lights.
Place a large object in the centre of the road.
Stand in the road and wave arms.
Call local radio station.
explanation: If you arrive at the scene of a crash, find a safe place to stop so that you don’t endanger yourself or others, warn other road users of the incident by using hazard lights.

text: In order to inform the emergency services of a crash what telephone number should be called?
explanation: If a driver arrives at or is involved in a crash it may be essential to obtain the assistance of the emergency services as a matter of urgency. The common European emergency number is 112 however in Ireland you may also use 999.

text: When calling for help on an emergency telephone on the motorway, who does the call go to?
options: National Safety Council.
Road Safety Authority.
National Roads Authority.
The Gardaí.
explanation: The emergency telephones at the side of a motorway are linked directly to An Garda Síochána in order for them to respond appropriately as soon as possible. The Gardaí know precisely the location of each call using these phones.

text: Where an injured person is discovered lying in the road, when should they be moved?
options: If the person is cold.
If the person needs CPR.
If the person has broken bones.
If the person is bleeding.
explanation: If a person discovered lying in the road is not breathing, it may be essential to move them in order to safely carry out emergency CPR. It may also be necessary to move them under other circumstances but an urgent assessment of the situation should be carried out first.

text: When dealing with crash victims, remember A B C. What does A stand for?
options: Airway.
Arms.
Accident.
Assist.
explanation: In assessing a crash victim’s vital signs, the following basic procedure should be used: First check the victim’s Airway is clear, then check they are Breathing and then check their Circulation (ABC).

text: What is good basic first aid for a person who has been burned?
options: Apply warm water to the burn.
Apply cold water to the burn.
Remove clothing covering the burn.
Apply grease to the burn.
explanation: When a person has been burned firstly check the person for shock, then try to cool the burn if you can. Try to find water or other liquid that is clean, cold and non-toxic to pour on it. The cool liquid may cool the affected area down and reduce damage. The person should be advised to seek medical advice as soon as possible.

text: What effect could hitting or mounting the kerb have on a vehicle’s tyres?
options: It could strengthen the sidewalls.
It could damage the sidewalls.
It could increase the air pressure.
It could wear the tread.
explanation: Drivers should avoid hitting or mounting the kerb as it causes damage to the sidewalls of the tyre. The damage caused could cause the tyre to blow-out later. If this happens at high speed the driver may lose control of the vehicle with dangerous consequences.

text: Who should first be contacted where a person has been injured in a collision?
options: The person’s relatives.
The injured person’s insurance company.
The emergency services.
explanation: Where somebody has been injured in a collision, it is important to call the emergency services immediately on 999 or 112. Trained emergency services personnel know best how to attend to injured persons.

text: While driving, a driver notices a strong smell of fuel. What should they do?
options: Drive at a reduced speed.
Turn on the fan to clear the air.
Stop where safe and investigate.
explanation: A strong smell of fuel is usually an indication that something is wrong, and drivers should stop and investigate as soon as possible. Leaking or spilling petrol can be dangerous because it is so combustible, and leaking diesel fuel can make the road very slippery.

text: What would make a pedestrian more visible to a driver at night?
options: Wearing a waterproof jacket.
Wearing headphones.
Wearing a hi-vis jacket.
explanation: Even with the best vehicle headlights, drivers can see less at night than during the day, pedestrians as vulnerable road users are extremely difficult to see in the dark. Wearing reflective clothing makes pedestrians more visible. Pedestrians should always wear bright and hi-vis clothing during the day and reflective clothing at night when walking outside built-up areas.

text: Why should a driver adjust their head restraint before starting a journey?
options: To improve rear passengers view of the road ahead.
To provide support to the neck in the event of a collision.
To prevent glare from the headlights of following vehicles.
explanation: Vehicle seats are fitted with head restraints to help reduce injury such as whiplash in the event of the vehicle being involved in a collision. Drivers and passengers should ensure that head restraints are adjusted to provide maximum protection. The top of the head restraint should be in line with the top of the head. The centre of the head restraint should be roughly in line with the top of the ears.

text: What is the purpose of daytime running lights on a vehicle?
options: To give the vehicle extra light when driving at night.
To illuminate the road in bad weather conditions in daylight hours.
To increase the vehicles visibility in daylight hours.
explanation: Daytime running lights refer to the white lighting systems on the front of a vehicle that automatically come on during daylight hours. The purpose of daytime running lights are to increase the visibility and presence of the vehicle to other road users.

text: What is the immediate effect of a head-on collision between two cars at speed?
options: All persons in each vehicle are thrown violently backwards only.
All persons in each vehicle are thrown violently forward.
Only front seatbelts will activate.
explanation: In a head-on collision passengers in both vehicles are propelled forwards, and if they are not wearing seatbelts they may go through the windscreen. It is the driver’s responsibility to ensure that all passengers under the age of 17 wear seatbelts. Older passengers are themselves responsible for wearing seatbelts.

text: Is it allowed for a vehicle to be driven on a public road when the brake lights are not working?
options: No, it is never permitted to be driven.
Yes, during lighting-up times.
Yes, outside of lighting-up times.
No, unless driving in a built-up area.
explanation: A driver must always ensure that their vehicle’s brake-lights are clean and working correctly before driving on a public road. Never drive a vehicle when the brake lights are not working properly.

text: Under what circumstances would a driver increase the air pressure in the tyres?
options: When the tread depth on the tyres is below 2 mm.
When taking a journey with additional passengers.
When the journey exceeds 200 km.
When higher speeds are expected on motorway driving.
explanation: Before starting a journey with extra passengers or loads, drivers should check the air pressure and when they inflate the tyres, they should increase the vehicle’s tyre pressures in accordance with the vehicle manufacturer’s recommended tyre pressure. This information can be found in the vehicle manufacturer’s handbook.

text: How can sunlight affect visibility in a car with dirty windows?
options: It can enhance visibility.
It can seriously reduce visibility.
It can cause objects to seem further away than they are.
It can cause objects to seem closer than they are.
explanation: It is essential that all vehicle windows are clear and clean at all times so that drivers can see road and traffic conditions all around. Dirty windows are a particular hazard when the sun is low in the sky. Dirty windows also decrease visibility during hours of twilight and darkness.

text: How does driving at high speed affect a vehicle’s road holding?
options: The suspension compensates for any unevenness in the road surface.
The wheel alignment keeps the tyres in full contact with the road.
The road holding ability of the vehicle is increased.
The road holding ability of the vehicle is reduced.
explanation: Driving at high speed is a factor that affects road holding. At higher speeds the airflow under a vehicle reduces tyre grip on the road and when you are approaching a bend or corner, the momentum of the vehicle makes it more difficult to change direction.

text: What effect could incorrectly aligned headlights have?
options: They could cause a fire.
They could reduce battery life.
They could wear out the bulbs prematurely.
They could dazzle oncoming drivers.
explanation: A driver should ensure their headlights are properly aligned so as not to dazzle oncoming drivers and also to see properly themselves.

text: What should a driver do before towing a caravan?
options: Ensure all passengers are securely seated in the caravan.
Have extended mirrors fitted to the towing vehicle.
Have an extended mirror fitted to the driver’s side of the vehicle only.
Ensure that only adult passengers are seated in the caravan.
explanation: If a driver intends towing a caravan, they should fit extended mirrors to both sides of the towing vehicle. This will allow the driver to better observe the traffic situation behind and to the sides.

text: Generally what lighting must a car, tractor or works vehicle have when driving?
options: Headlights, front and rear side lights, rear number plate light, red rear reflectors, brake lights and indicators.
Headlights and a reversing light.
Headlights, number plate and rear reflectors only.
Headlights, brake lights and indicators only.
explanation: In general all cars, tractors and works vehicles are required by law to have headlights, front and rear side lights, rear number plate light, rear reflectors, brake lights and indicators. There are some exceptions to this, such as electric cars with a maximum speed of 38 km/h.

text: What danger could be associated with driving a tractor and trailer over a humpbacked bridge?
options: The tractor’s suspension could smooth out the bump.
The trailer could become detached.
The trailer could jack-knife.
The trailer’s parking brake could automatically engage.
explanation: Before towing a trailer, a driver should ensure that the tow hitch has sufficient ground clearance. If this hits the road, for example when travelling over a humpbacked bridge, there is a danger that the trailer will become detached. Drivers should also plan and carry out their journey with an awareness of this risk.

text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down on an automatic railway level crossing?
options: Walk along the track to give warning to any approaching trains.
Get passengers clear of the crossing and phone the signal operator so that trains can be stopped.
Try to push the vehicle clear of the crossing as soon as possible.
Turn on the warning bells at the crossing.
explanation: In this situation, you and all passengers should get out of the vehicle and immediately use the emergency phone at the crossing to contact the signal operator so that trains can be stopped. If necessary, warn other motorists. Do not return to the vehicle until instructed by the signal operator or emergency services.

text: What danger can arise from the power take-off shaft of a tractor?
options: If it is not disengaged, the steering will lock.
If it is not covered, clothing can get caught in it.
If it is not covered, the tractor will speed up rapidly.
If it is not disengaged, the battery will run flat.
explanation: If you are working at the rear of a tractor, you should bear in mind that if the power take-off shaft is not covered, loose clothing might get caught in it and lead to injury or death.

text: When changing a wheel on a public road, what should a person do to ensure their own safety?
options: Ensure the vehicle is in reverse gear and front wheels are facing the roadway.
Ask a bystander to warn traffic by beckoning them from the middle of the road.
Wear reflective clothing and switch on the vehicle hazard warning lights.
Ensure the vehicle is in first gear and the wheels are facing the roadway.
explanation: When changing a wheel at the side of the road, switch on the vehicle hazard warning lights, and wear reflective or light-coloured clothing. This will help other motorists to react and slow down when passing.

text: What should a driver do when requested to drive a vehicle that they feel is overloaded?
options: Drive the vehicle only if accompanied.
Ensure that the load is properly restrained.
Drive at a slower speed than normal.
Refuse to drive the vehicle.
explanation: You should not take a vehicle that you believe to be overloaded onto a public road. Overloading is dangerous, as it affects the stability and braking capabilities of the vehicle.

text: How could towing an overloaded trailer affect a vehicle?
options: It could improve braking ability when going downhill.
It could improve road holding on bends.
It could impair the vehicle’s steering and braking.
It could improve the vehicle’s fuel consumption.
explanation: You should not take an overloaded trailer onto a public road. An overloaded trailer impairs the stability, steering and braking of the towing vehicle.

text: What should a driver do to secure the towing vehicle before unhitching a trailer?
options: Disconnect the electrical supply to the trailer lights and lower the jockey wheel.
Apply the handbrake, switch off the ignition and engage a low gear.
Lower the jockey wheel and then switch off the ignition.
Apply the handbrake, lower the jockey wheel and switch off the engine.
explanation: Before unhitching a trailer, apply the handbrake, switch off the ignition and engage a lower gear, so that the towing vehicle does not move while you are unhitching the trailer.

text: What lighting must be on a tractors trailer during lighting-up hours?
options: Indicators, brake lights, rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights.
Indicators, two white or yellow headlamps and rear number plate lights only.
An unloading light.
Brake lights and indicators only.
explanation: A trailer being towed by a tractor must have rear indicators, brake lights, a rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights whilst being towed on a public road.

text: What should a driver do to reduce the risk of neck injury in the event of a rear-end collision?
options: Use a properly adjusted head restraint.
Ensure the vehicle has a rear spoiler.
Use a properly adjusted seat belt.
Ensure the vehicle has anti-lock brakes.
explanation: It is essential that head restraints be properly adjusted for both the driver and the passengers. Head restraints are designed to protect the neck and spine in a collision and thus prevent or reduce whiplash. If head restraints are not properly adjusted there is an increased risk to the vehicles occupants.

text: What is the minimum legal tread depth for tyres on cars?
options: 1 millimetre
1.6 millimetres
2.6 millimetres
0.6 millimetres
explanation: All road vehicles, except motorcycles and vintage vehicles, must have a minimum tyre tread depth of 1.6 mm over the main tread. However, for safety reasons, you should replace the vehicle’s tyres before they become this worn.

text: What does the load index of a tyre indicate?
options: The maximum load of the vehicle.
The maximum load per axle.
The maximum air pressure of the tyre.
The maximum load a tyre can carry.
explanation: The load index indicates the maximum weight that a tyre can support safely. When replacing a tyre on your vehicle, you should make sure that the new tyre maintains the proper load index for the vehicle.

text: A driver notices that the wiper blades are worn. What should they do?
options: Wipe the windscreen with newspaper.
Have the blades replaced as soon as possible.
Roll down the window and drive slowly.
Use the windscreen washer system while it is raining.
explanation: Use the windscreen wipers to keep the windscreen clear of rain, spray, snow or fog. Check them regularly to ensure that they are in good working order, and replace them when they become worn, before they become ineffective.

text: When a wiper blade fails to clear the windscreen what should the driver do?
options: Have the wiper blades replaced as soon as possible.
Switch the wiper control from high speed to low speed repeatedly.
Apply a light film of oil to both of the wiper blades.
Bend the wiper arm to apply more pressure on the windscreen.
explanation: Use the windscreen wipers to keep the windscreen clear of rain, spray, snow or fog. Check them regularly to ensure that they are in good working order, and replace them when they become worn, before they become ineffective.

text: If a vehicle breaks down on a motorway, what should a person do?
options: Place a red warning triangle on the motorway to warn other drivers.
Use a roadside phone to contact Gardaí and never try to carry out repairs yourself.
Ask a passenger to stand on the road to warn other traffic.
Turn on the full beam headlights to alert other drivers.
explanation: When a vehicle breaks down on a motorway, a driver should move the vehicle to the hard shoulder, use the roadside phone to contact the Gardaí, and do not place a warning device on the motorway. The driver should never try to do repairs themselves in the hard shoulder.

text: Who is responsible for ensuring that a passenger over 17 years of age is wearing a seat belt while travelling in a car?
options: The driver when the passenger is in the front seat.
The passenger only.
Both the driver and the passenger.
The driver only.
explanation: Where the passenger is over the age of 17 and travelling in a car it is their legal responsibility to comply with the seat belt regulations. Below that age, it is the driver’s responsibility.

text: Who is responsible for ensuring that a passenger under 17 years of age is wearing a seat belt while travelling in a car?
options: The driver only.
The driver, but only when the passenger is in the front seat.
The passenger only.
The passenger’s parents.
explanation: Where the passenger is over the age of 17 and travelling in a car it is their legal responsibility to comply with the seat belt regulations. Below that age, it is the driver’s responsibility.

text: Who is responsible for ensuring that a child wears a child restraint system in a vehicle?
options: The driver only.
Any adult passenger.
The child, if over 12 years of age.
The parents of the child only.
explanation: Where the passenger is over the age of 17 and travelling in a car it is their legal responsibility to comply with the child restraint regulations. Below that age, it is the driver’s responsibility.

text: How should a child restraint system be fitted in a vehicle?
options: It should be placed on a front passenger seat only.
It should be left unsecured.
It should be placed on the floor.
It should be fitted in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.
explanation: It is recommended to fit the child seat correctly, according to the manufacturer’s instructions, it is safer to fit the seat in the back seat of the car and to buy a child car seat only from a retailer who will check that it fits both the car and the child.

text: On a motorway, when should a driver use the hazard warning lights?
options: When parked in the hard shoulder to take a phone call.
When another vehicle is following too closely.
When the vehicle has broken down.
When towing another vehicle.
explanation: Use the hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead. For example, if your vehicle has broken down and is stopped on the hard shoulder, you can use the hazard warning lights to warn following vehicles of your presence.

text: If a vehicle breaks down on a motorway, what should a person do?
options: Turn on the full beam headlights.
Ask a passenger to stand on the motorway to warn other traffic.
Place a red warning triangle to the left of the vehicle.
Move the vehicle to the hard shoulder.
explanation: Move the vehicle to the hard shoulder. Park as near to the left as possible. If this is not possible, take steps to warn other drivers, such as switching on the hazard warning lights.

text: If a vehicle breaks down on a motorway, what should a person do?
options: Turn on the full beam headlights.
Ask a passenger to stand on the motorway to warn other traffic.
Place a red warning triangle to the left of the vehicle.
Wear a high-visibility vest.
explanation: Move the vehicle to the hard shoulder. Park as near to the left as possible. If this is not possible, take steps to warn other drivers, such as switching on the hazard warning lights. Wear a high-visibility vest. Always carry at least two in the vehicle.

text: Where safety belts are fitted to a car when must adult occupants wear them?
options: Only when instructed to do so by the driver.
When travelling on long journeys.
At all times.
explanation: The driver and all passengers in a car must wear a safety belt or, in the case of a child, a suitable restraint system.

text: What should a driver be alert to in this area?
options: Pedestrians may be hitch-hiking.
Parked vehicles may have trailers attached.
Pedestrians may cross between parked cars.
There may be refuse bins between the parked vehicles.
explanation: When driving in a built-up area, you should drive with caution and be prepared to react to pedestrians crossing from between parked vehicles.

text: The silver car is overtaking the parked red car, what should the driver do in this situation?
options: The driver should drive on if he does not hit the ball.
The driver should move closer to the red car.
The driver should drive on at the same speed.
Reduce speed considerably and be ready to stop.
explanation: You should read the road and be extra careful while driving through an area where children might be playing. When a ball bounces out on the road you should expect that a child might follow to retrieve the ball.

text: How should a driver overtake the cyclist in this situation?
options: Overtake the cyclist, but without crossing any of the lines.
By sounding the horn to warn the cyclist they intend to pass.
By straddling both lines and keeping close to the cyclist.
By crossing the broken white line.
explanation: Where there are two lines in the centre of the road, you must obey the one closest to you. So, if the closest line is a broken white line, by law you may overtake, so long as it is safe to do so.

text: Why might it be dangerous to drive on a poorly-lit street?
options: Drivers can only see the traffic coming against them.
Drivers can only see the traffic in front of them.
It may be difficult to make out poorly lit vehicles in the dark areas.
Traffic lights will not be working.
explanation: When you are driving along a poorly-lit street, you should take extra care and be prepared to react to hazards such as unlit parked vehicles.

text: What should a driver do on the approach to this situation?
options: Increase speed in order to clear the bridge before the oncoming car.
Reduce speed and stop if necessary.
Give way only if you are towing a trailer or caravan.
Drive on because the oncoming traffic must wait.
explanation: When road priority is unclear you might have to yield to oncoming vehicles. Never drive a vehicle into an area that it might not be able to clear or where it could cause an obstruction or bottleneck.

text: Why must a driver be particularly careful here?
options: The vehicle coming from the right has the right of way.
The vehicle coming from the right is not required to signal.
Because there is an increased danger of skidding.
Because a vehicle could come from the left.
explanation: Where there are fallen leaves on the road surface, your tyres might have reduced grip on the road surface and your braking distances might be greater.

text: What should a driver do when turning right at this junction?
options: Proceed ahead of both cars.
Allow the blue car to proceed.
Allow the red car to proceed.
Allow both cars to proceed.
explanation: When you are turning right from a main road into a side road, you must give way to oncoming traffic on the main road even if they are turning left into the same road.

text: What should a driver be aware of when driving at night along a shopping street with many different light sources?
options: Parking spaces may be difficult to notice.
Traffic lights may be difficult to distinguish from the other bright lights.
Other vehicles do not need to use their head lights.
It is easier to see pedestrians because of the bright lights.
explanation: When driving at night in an area where there is a variety of light sources, you need to be extra careful, as potential hazards might be more difficult to see.

text: In this situation who should wait?
options: The driver behind the stopped van should wait.
Neither vehicle should wait.
Whichever vehicle is furthest away from the van.
The oncoming vehicle must wait.
explanation: When you are overtaking a parked vehicle or obstruction, you should yield to oncoming vehicles so that they don’t have to slow down or take evasive action.

text: In this situation, who should wait?
options: Neither driver should wait.
Both drivers should wait.
The driver in the red car should wait.
The driver on the main road should wait.
explanation: A vehicle driving on the main road has priority over vehicles emerging from side roads. However, you must understand that the right of way is not an absolute right of way and you should be considerate of other road users at all times.

text: What should a driver be aware of in this situation?
options: A minor road to the right ahead.
A sharp dip in the road ahead.
A dangerous right-hand bend ahead.
A minor road to the left ahead.
explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations – in this case paying attention to the warning sign clearly indicating a right-hand bend ahead.

text: Which vehicle is in the correct position to make a right turn from the major road into the minor road?
explanation: The correct position from which to turn right from a major road to a minor road is just left of centre. You should take up the correct position in good time and avoid cutting the corner or swan necking – that is going beyond the turning point as car 2 is in the picture.

text: Which vehicle is in the correct position to make a right turn from a minor road onto a major road?
explanation: The correct position from which to turn right from a minor road to a major road is just left of centre of the road. You should take up the correct position in good time and complete the turn by entering the left-hand side of the major road.

text: What should a driver do if they see a red warning triangle on the road?
options: The driver should remove the triangle as it is causing an obstruction on the road.
The driver should stop and await instructions.
The driver should maintain speed, carry on and avoid the triangle.
The driver should slow down and expect a hazard up ahead.
explanation: Warning triangles are used to alert approaching traffic that there is a vehicle breakdown or collision ahead. When you come across a warning triangle, you should slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary. Do not allow yourself to be distracted by the incident.

text: What should drivers be aware of if they meet horses with riders on the road?
options: Drivers should be aware that horse riders are obliged to dismount and control their horses while traffic is passing.
Drivers should be aware that all horse riders are experienced at handling horses.
Drivers should be aware that loud noises from their vehicle may frighten the horses and cause them to bolt.
Drivers should be aware that loud noises from their vehicle will not frighten the horses.
explanation: You must know your responsibilities towards animal traffic on the road. Horses are easily startled and any sudden noises or activity could cause them to bolt.

text: There are pedestrians on the footpath ahead and there are pools of water on the road. What should a driver do?
options: Reduce speed and try to avoid the pools of water so as not to splash the pedestrians.
Sound the horn as a warning to the pedestrians and continue on.
Flash the headlights as a warning to the pedestrians.
Brake suddenly as you approach the pools of water.
explanation: During wet conditions, you should be aware that surface water can affect the stability of your vehicle. This is particularly so where the water lies in pools. As you drive through surface water, you should show consideration to pedestrians and cyclists and try not to splash them as you pass.

text: When is it permitted to force oncoming traffic onto the hard shoulder on the opposite side of the road while overtaking?
options: When the hard shoulder is wide enough.
When none of the oncoming traffic is overtaking.
When the vehicle being overtaken is driving too slow.
It is not permitted to force oncoming traffic onto the hard shoulder while overtaking.
explanation: Overtaking in the manner described here is dangerous. You should overtake another vehicle only when it is safe to do so, both for you and for all other traffic. Before you overtake, make sure the road ahead is clear and that you have enough room to complete the overtaking manoeuvre and return to your own side of the road without forcing any other road user to alter speed or course.

text: What does a 2-plus-1 road have?
options: Two non-motorway lanes in one direction and one non-motorway lane in the opposite direction.
Two motorway lanes and one non-motorway lane in two directions.
Two motorway lanes in one direction and one non-motorway lane in the opposite direction.
Two non-motorway lanes and one motorway lane in two directions.
explanation: A 2-plus-1 road consists of two lanes in one direction of travel and one lane in the other direction. The two-lane section allows for safe overtaking and alternates with a one-lane section roughly every 2 kilometres.

text: Where may a driver overtake on a 2-plus-1 road?
options: In the two-lane stretch.
In the one-lane stretch if there is no oncoming traffic.
In the one-lane stretch.
In either the one-lane stretch or the two-lane stretch.
explanation: A 2-plus-1 road consists of two lanes in one direction of travel and one lane in the other direction. When you need to overtake, you should wait until you reach the 2-lane section which occurs approximately every 2 kilometres.

text: At road junctions, what type of road users are particularly vulnerable?
options: Car drivers.
Pedestrians.
Tractor drivers.
Van drivers.
