Heater-fan revolutions.
explanation: The rev counter measures the speed of the engine, in revolutions per minute. Generally, the higher the revs, the more fuel the engine is using, so drivers should keep an eye on the rev counter to help drive in a more eco-friendly manner.

text: What should the driver be able to see in the vehicle mirrors when they are properly adjusted?
options: The passenger area of the vehicle.
The position of all the wheels.
The position of the left-side wheels.
The area behind and to each side of the vehicle.
explanation: Properly adjusted vehicle mirrors enable drivers to see the road behind and to the sides. This helps drivers to take into account what’s happening behind them, so that they can make informed, correct and safer decisions.

text: What should the driver be able to see in the exterior mirrors of a vehicle when they are properly adjusted?
options: The sides of the vehicle only.
60% angled to the vehicle and 40% to the road.
The area to each side of the vehicle.
The back of the vehicle only.
explanation: Exterior mirrors enable drivers to see the area on each side of the vehicle. Drivers must take into account all visible hazards in order to make informed, correct and safer decisions.

text: The vehicle’s exterior mirrors are covered by a film of mud and dust. What should the driver do?
options: Angle the mirrors towards the front for a distance in order to clean them.
Clean them with a cloth or tissue before starting their journey.
Drive in the slip stream of other traffic, as this will eventually clean the mirrors.
Continue on and clean them after reaching the destination.
explanation: The purpose of mirrors is to increase the driver’s view to the rear and sides of the vehicle and to enable them to take into account all visible hazards. Proper use will enable drivers to make informed, correct and safer decisions. Drivers should ensure that all mirrors, including the exterior ones, are clean and properly adjusted at all times to ensure optimum view.

text: What effect can wet weather have on a vehicle’s exterior mirrors?
options: Water droplets can make the reflected object appear closer than it really is.
Water droplets help to keep them clean.
Water can cause a short-circuit in the electrically heated mirrors.
Water droplets can obscure the reflected image.
explanation: When driving in wet weather conditions, small water droplets can form on the glass of the exterior mirrors. This could make it more difficult to see the road behind and to the sides. Switch on the mirror demisters, if they are fitted. If necessary, stop and clear them.

text: What does blue smoke coming from the vehicle’s exhaust generally mean?
options: The catalytic converter is worn out.
The engine is burning oil.
The air filter needs to be replaced.
The engine is overheating.
explanation: A vehicle can give off blue smoke from the exhaust when it is burning oil. Poor maintenance and worn engines are typical causes. This blue smoke is harmful to the environment and may be costly. Drivers should have the vehicle checked by a competent person.

text: What is the effect of a worn exhaust?
options: The filtering of fumes is reduced and engine noise is louder.
Fuel efficiency is increased as the fumes escape more quickly.
Gear-changing is more difficult.
The engine overheats.
explanation: A worn exhaust system can have a number of effects, including increased noise from the engine and more environmentally damaging fumes (as they are not filtered properly). There are requirements to ensure vehicles are compliant with EU and Irish legislation. Vehicles are tested for compliance during road worthiness testing.

text: What effect can a faulty exhaust system have?
options: It can increase the vehicle’s noise and pollution levels.
It can reduce the vehicle’s engine noise.
It can increase wear on the vehicle’s engine.
It can improve the vehicle’s fuel consumption.
explanation: A worn exhaust system can have a number of negative effects, including increased noise from the engine and more environmentally damaging fumes (as they are not filtered properly). There are requirements to ensure vehicles are compliant with EU and Irish legislation. Vehicles are tested for compliance during road worthiness testing.

text: What is the purpose of a catalytic converter?
options: It allows the engine to quickly reach its normal operating temperature.
It increases engine power.
It decreases engine power.
It filters exhaust gases and reduces air pollution.
explanation: The purpose of a catalytic converter (CAT) is to remove toxic or polluting gases such as carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxide and unburned hydrocarbons from the exhaust emissions. When the CAT is faulty, an engine management warning light illuminates on the dashboard and drivers should seek advice from a competent person.

text: How does harsh acceleration affect fuel consumption?
options: There is no effect provided the engine is properly tuned.
There is no effect if a high gear is engaged.
Fuel consumption decreases.
Fuel consumption increases.
explanation: Harsh acceleration increases fuel consumption. Smooth acceleration helps to reduce fuel consumption and the emissions from vehicles. Try not to over-rev the engine and use the appropriate gear for the speed of the vehicle. When slowing down, take your foot off the accelerator and allow the vehicle to slow progressively before you brake.

text: How does continuous high-speed driving affect fuel consumption?
options: It reduces fuel consumption as long as the road is straight.
It reduces fuel consumption.
It increases fuel consumption.
It uses the same consumption of fuel as lower speed driving.
explanation: Driving at continuous high speeds increases your fuel consumption. Vehicles driving at 112 km/h consumes approximately 30% more fuel than a vehicle travelling at 80 km/h.

text: How can fuel efficiency be improved?
options: By using an anti-waxing agent only in freezing conditions.
By accelerating hard up through the gears to reach the desired speed as quickly as possible.
By using gentle acceleration and making gear changes appropriate to speed.
By driving the vehicle in a lower gear for as long as possible.
explanation: A driver can contribute to their vehicle’s fuel efficiency by reading the road ahead and driving smoothly. This is achieved by accelerating gently, using the most appropriate gear for the speed they are travelling at and avoiding harsh braking.

text: What effect does a worn exhaust have on a vehicle?
options: It causes the water coolant to leak from the engine.
It causes noise and gas pollution levels to increase.
It decreases fuel consumption.
It causes oil to leak on the road.
explanation: A vehicle with a worn exhaust will probably be noisier and will produce more polluting emissions. There are strict regulations governing the noise and emission levels of vehicles, and these are rigorously checked during a vehicle’s NCT.

text: When is the use of the horn prohibited?
options: Between 11:30 pm and 6:00 am on any road.
At all times in a built-up area.
Between 10:00 pm and 6:00 am in a built-up area.
Between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am in a built-up area.
explanation: Drivers are not permitted to sound the horn in a built-up area between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am unless there is a traffic emergency. Only sound the horn to warn other road users of oncoming danger or if they need to be made aware of your presence for safety reasons. Sounding the horn does not give the driver an automatic right of way. Never sound the horn to provoke a reaction from or to rebuke another motorist.

text: What can a driver do to maximise fuel efficiency while driving?
options: Reduce pressure in all tyres.
Avoid carrying unnecessary weight.
Fit a roof rack.
Increase road speed.
explanation: The more extra weight is in your vehicle, the more fuel you use. Using a roof rack or a roof box increases wind resistance and this also increases fuel consumption – by as much as 15%. Remove roof racks and roof boxes when not in use.

text: Which action is likely to cause an increase in fuel consumption?
options: Driving at a constant speed.
Harsh acceleration.
Turning off air conditioning.
Looking ahead and anticipating traffic flow.
explanation: Harsh acceleration increases fuel consumption. Driving smoothly reduces wear and tear and also improves fuel consumption. Use the highest gear possible without causing the engine to labour.

text: How are emergency vehicles identified?
options: By continuously lit red lights.
By flashing green lights.
By flashing amber and white lights.
By flashing red or blue lights.
explanation: If you hear or see an emergency vehicle approaching sounding its siren or flashing lights, be extra careful and give way if it is safe to do so.

text: After a heavy downpour, why should a driver keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front?
options: Because tyre grip improves when wet.
Because wheels rotate at a greater speed after rain.
Because wheels rotate at a slower speed after rain.
Because the required stopping distances is greater.
explanation: On a wet road surface, your tyres do not grip the road surface as well as in dry conditions and your required stopping distance is increased. Because of that you should slow down during or after rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

text: At traffic lights, a driver should take particular care for which road users coming up on the left?
options: Tractors.
Motorcyclists.
Vans.
Cars.
explanation: Before moving off at traffic lights the driver should be aware of traffic, particularly cyclists and motorcyclists, coming up on the left, especially where there is an advanced stop line for cyclists ahead of that which applies to other road users.

text: When a driver intends to make a left-hand turn at a junction where there are pedestrians and cyclists present, what should a driver do?
options: Sound the horn while proceeding to warn the other road users of the intention to turn.
Check your mirrors and watch for cyclists or pedestrians on the left.
Check the right-hand mirror, make the turn and then signal.
Signal left, watch the right-hand mirror and make the turn.
explanation: The vehicle does not have a greater right-of-way than any other road user. As a driver you should pay particular attention to vulnerable road users such as pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists and be aware that they are entitled to use the road in safety.

text: Which of the following road users are most vulnerable in slow-moving city traffic?
options: Cars.
Taxis.
Motorcyclists.
Vans.
explanation: In slow-moving city traffic, you should be aware of and check your blind spots before any manoeuvre. Motorcyclists can easily become hidden in a blind spot, and in slow-moving traffic, they might be moving faster than you are.

text: Which of the following road users are most vulnerable in slow-moving city traffic?
options: Cars.
Taxis.
Vans.
Pedestrians.
explanation: In slow-moving city traffic, you should be aware of and check your blind spots before any manoeuvre. Pedestrians can easily become hidden in a blind spot, and in slow-moving traffic, they might be moving faster than you are.

text: What should a driver do when driving at night on an unlit road?
options: Watch out for unlit cyclists.
Drive close to the left and switch on front fog lights.
Drive at least 30 km/h below the posted speed limit.
Keep well out from the left-hand side of the road.
explanation: While driving at night and even with the best headlights, it can be very difficult to see all the hazards that you might come across – for example, stray animals or livestock on the road. At night you should drive at a speed that will enable you to stop safely within the distance you can see to be clear ahead.

text: What can be achieved by the driving style known as ‘Eco-Driving’?
options: Improved road safety.
Reduced journey times.
Increased journey times.
Increased emissions.
explanation: The advantages of eco-driving include improved road safety, improved fuel consumption and reduced emissions. The eco-conscious driver becomes a more efficient driver because they learn to read the road further ahead and display better anticipation skills. This reduces the need for harsh acceleration and braking which results in a more economical style of driving and a smoother drive.

text: What can be achieved by the driving style known as ‘Eco-Driving’?
options: Increased fuel consumption.
Increased journey times.
Increased emissions.
Increased fuel efficiency.
explanation: One of the many advantages of an eco-driving style, includes: Increased fuel efficiency, reduced emissions and improved driver safety. The eco-conscious driver becomes a more efficient driver because they learn to read the road further ahead and display better anticipation skills. This reduces the need for harsh acceleration and braking which results in a more economical style of driving and a smoother journey.

text: Which action contributes to eco-driving?
options: Maintaining a steady speed.
Braking harshly.
Driving with the windows open.
Driving in a low gear at high speed.
explanation: One of the many advantages of maintaining a steady speed includes: Increased fuel efficiency, reduced emissions and improved driver safety. The eco-conscious driver becomes a more efficient driver because they learn to read the road further ahead and display better anticipation skills. This reduces the need for harsh acceleration and braking which results in a more economical style of driving and a smoother journey.

text: Which action contributes to eco-driving?
options: Driving in a low gear at high speed.
Braking harshly.
Looking ahead and anticipating.
Reducing tyre pressure.
explanation: One of the many advantages of an eco-driving style, includes: Increased fuel efficiency, reduced emissions and improved driver safety. The eco-conscious driver becomes a more efficient driver because they learn to read the road further ahead and display better anticipation skills. This reduces the need for harsh acceleration and braking which results in a more economical style of driving and a smoother journey.

text: When a driver intends to make a left-hand turn on a busy city street junction and there are pedestrians and cyclists around, what should the driver do?
options: Signal left, watch the right-hand mirror and make the turn when it is clear.
Stay close to the left to prevent cyclists or pedestrians coming up on your left side.
Watch for cyclists or pedestrians who may try to cross the road in front of the vehicle.
Keep to the right to make room for cyclists to pass.
explanation: When making a left-hand turn on a busy city street, drivers should pay particular attention to vulnerable road users such as pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists who may appear unexpectedly and may not be aware of the vehicle’s intention.

text: Before exiting the vehicle on a busy road, what should the driver ensure?
options: That the gear lever is in neutral.
That the wheels are positioned straight ahead.
Before opening the door the driver should check it is safe to do so.
That the passengers open their door first.
explanation: When exiting from a parked vehicle on a busy road, the driver should check it is safe to do so before opening the door, as there could be cyclists or other traffic passing closely by.

text: When towing a high and wide-bodied trailer what should a driver do?
options: Drive with hazard warning lights flashing at all times.
Make use of extended mirrors to check for following traffic.
Drive with a red flag to the front right-hand side of the trailer.
Drive with a red flag at the rear left of the trailer.
explanation: When towing a high and wide-bodied trailer, a driver should use extended mirrors on both sides of the towing vehicle. This will allow the driver to better observe the traffic situation behind and to the sides.

text: If the vehicle’s windows are covered with ice, what should the driver do?
options: Fully clear ice from all windows.
Drive slowly until the heater and demister have cleared the ice.
Use boiling water to clear the ice.
Clear enough space in the windscreen to be able to see ahead.
explanation: Make sure all the windows are completely clear of ice so that the driver can safely observe road and traffic conditions all around. This is especially important when driving in slippery conditions. It is good practice to carry a can of de-icer in the vehicle and if possible to fill the washer reservoir with a de-icing agent.

text: What should a driver do if the vehicle’s windows and mirrors are covered in ice?
options: Drive at a reduced speed until the heating system has cleared the ice.
Switch on the heating system and use a scraper to clear the ice before driving.
Use boiling water with salt to clear the ice.
Switch on the windscreen wipers.
explanation: Make sure all the windows and mirrors are completely clear of ice so that the driver can safely observe road and traffic conditions all around. This is especially important when driving in slippery conditions. It is good practice to carry a can of de-icer in the vehicle and if possible to fill the washer reservoir with a de-icing agent.

text: What specific observations should a driver make before reversing their vehicle?
options: Look over both shoulders and behind.
Look over right-hand shoulder.
Look in door mirrors only.
Look in interior mirror only.
explanation: Before reversing, look over both shoulders and to the rear to check all around that there are no children or other road users around the vehicle and that it is safe to reverse.

text: What specific observations should a driver make before reversing a vehicle fitted with an external audible warning device?
options: Observations should be made by opening the driver’s door and looking behind.
Observations should be made only in blind spots.
Observations should be made to the front, sides and rear of the vehicle, including blind spots.
No specific observations needed, as bystanders will be aware of the vehicle.
explanation: Drivers should not rely solely on an external audible warning device to warn others that their vehicle is reversing. Before reversing, drivers must make sure it is safe to do so by taking all appropriate observations to the front, sides and rear of the vehicle, including the blind spots. Never assume it is safe to reverse just because the vehicle has an external audible warning device.

text: What should a driver do when they intend to reverse into a side road?
options: Focus totally on the left-side door mirror while reversing.
Check carefully all around before and during the reverse.
Open the left-side door fully to look behind.
Angle the door mirrors down before reversing.
explanation: Before and while reversing into a side road, check all around to make sure it is safe and clear to carry out the manoeuvre, paying particular attention to pedestrians crossing behind the vehicle and any other road users.

text: What should a driver do if they intend to reverse their vehicle into an area which they cannot see?
options: Open driver’s window and look behind.
Open driver’s door and look behind.
Ask someone to guide you when reversing.
Look in nearside (left) mirror when reversing.
explanation: Do not attempt to reverse into an area that you cannot see into properly. You should get assistance from somebody who can guide you safely into the area.

text: What should a driver do in order to keep alert during a long journey?
options: Increase speed to shorten the journey.
Keep the radio turned on and windows closed.
Increase the air circulation and stop if necessary.
Turn up the heater to maintain driver comfort.
explanation: While on a long journey, a driver should take regular rest breaks. A short walk and a caffeinated drink (tea or coffee) can help to revive them. The vehicle should be kept cool and well ventilated with a steady flow of fresh air.

text: When should rear fog lights be used?
options: In dense fog or falling snow.
Only in light fog.
When the vehicle behind is too close.
Always when driving at night in an unlit area.
explanation: A driver must only use rear fog lights in dense fog or falling snow. Using fog lights in normal road and weather conditions can dazzle or blind following motorists. Also, fog lights may make brake lights harder to see.

text: When should rear fog lights be used?
options: When driving in dense fog or falling snow.
Rear fog lights should always be used.
When both the rear tail lights are broken.
Rear fog lights should be used only at dawn and dusk.
explanation: A driver must only use rear fog lights in dense fog or falling snow. Using fog lights in normal road and weather conditions can dazzle or blind following motorists. Also, fog lights may make brake lights harder to see.

text: What should a driver do if dazzled by headlights reflecting in the rear-view mirror of their car?
options: Use the night driving mode on their rear-view mirror.
Adjust the mirror to reflect the light back towards the following driver.
Switch the lights off and on to remind the following driver to dip their lights.
Turn on the rear fog lights to signal to the following vehicle to turn off their headlights.
explanation: If a driver is being dazzled by the lights of following traffic, they should adjust their rear-view mirror to the night driving mode. This will allow them to concentrate on the road ahead and not be distracted by lights from following traffic.

text: At night, what effect could driving with a single headlight have on oncoming drivers?
options: It could dazzle them.
They could mistake the vehicle for a motorcycle.
It could enable them to see the vehicle more clearly.
It would have no effect on oncoming drivers.
explanation: Motor vehicles (except motorcycles) are required by law to have two headlights. A vehicle with only one headlight could be mistaken for a motorcycle and other road users could believe that it is in a different position on the road than it actually is. Vehicle lights should be checked on a regular basis and repair faulty lighting immediately.

text: What is meant by the term jack-knifing?
options: When the trailer is too heavy to be drawn by the tractor.
When the vehicle slides due to ice or water on the road.
When the jack is not strong enough to lift an axle.
When the trailer is travelling faster than the drawing vehicle.
explanation: Towing a trailer or caravan dramatically reduces the stability of the towing vehicle. If a driver brakes sharply or slows down quickly, the trailer may pivot around the tow hitch coupling, causing both vehicles to go off course, and possibly overturn.

text: When should a driver use the vehicle side lights?
options: When driving in foggy conditions.
When parking at all times.
When driving in an unlit area at night.
When parking on an unlit road.
explanation: When leaving a vehicle on an unlit public road at night this creates a potential danger for other road users. Drivers should therefore leave side/parking lights on, so that the vehicle can be seen by other road users. Drivers should not leave headlights on when parked as this may cause other road users to become disoriented.

text: What is a possible effect of over-filling the engine with oil?
options: It could burst the oil filter.
It could damage the oil pump.
It could damage the catalytic converter.
It could reduce the oil pressure.
explanation: It is essential that the vehicle’s engine is not over filled with oil as this can permanently damage the catalytic converter, which is part of most vehicles’ exhaust systems and removes up to 75% of the carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxide and hydrocarbons from the vehicle’s exhaust. Damaging this increase exhaust emissions.

text: What safety precaution should a driver take when getting out of their vehicle?
options: Check all around for approaching traffic and pedestrians before opening the door.
Ensure the gear lever is in neutral.
Open the door and try to get out as speedily as possible.
Ensure all valuables are secured and out of sight.
explanation: Before opening any door, check for other road users passing, and in particular look out for pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists. Exit the vehicle only when it is safe to do so, and close the door as soon as possible. Passengers should exit on the side nearest the kerb wherever possible.

text: On a busy road, how should a driver allow passengers out of a vehicle?
options: Stop and allow them to get out from whichever side of the vehicle they are sitting.
Stop and allow them to get out on the side nearest the kerb.
Stop and encourage them to get out as quickly as possible.
Signal to following traffic to overtake before allowing the passengers to get out.
explanation: Before allowing any door to be opened, check for other road users passing, and in particular look out for pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists. Passengers should exit on the side nearest the kerb, without getting in the way of pedestrians.

text: How should a driver apply the brakes in an emergency if the vehicle is fitted with anti-lock brakes (ABS)?
options: Press the brake pedal only lightly.
Press the brake pedal firmly and hold.
Press and release the brake at rapid intervals.
Press and release the brake at slow intervals.
explanation: If your vehicle is fitted with ABS, brake firmly. ABS will not stop the vehicle more quickly, it will only prevent the wheels from locking. This helps you to maintain control of the vehicle.

text: What effect could a front-tyre blow-out have on a vehicle?
options: The wheels will lock up and stop rotating.
The steering wheel will stay in the straight on position.
The steering wheel will pull to one side.
Anti-lock brakes will be automatically disengaged.
explanation: If a front tyre on the vehicle you are driving blows out, you will feel the effect of it through the steering wheel. The wheel will generally pull to the side of the blown-out tyre.

text: What should a driver do when suddenly confronted by a hazard on the road?
options: Decelerate and apply the footbrake firmly.
Slowly brake and switch off the ignition.
Apply the handbrake and the footbrake together.
Depress clutch and switch off the ignition.
explanation: To stop your vehicle in an emergency, apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping.

text: When driving along and required to stop suddenly, what should a driver do?
options: Depress the clutch and then apply the handbrake.
Apply the handbrake and the footbrake together.
Apply the footbrake firmly.
Steer sharply to one side and apply the handbrake.
explanation: To stop your vehicle in an emergency, apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping.

text: When required to stop in an emergency, what should a driver do?
options: Press the footbrake and engage a higher gear.
Apply both the clutch and handbrake.
Apply firm pressure on the footbrake.
Apply gentle pressure to the footbrake.
explanation: To stop your vehicle in an emergency, apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping.

text: When required to stop in an emergency, what should a driver do?
options: Apply the footbrake firmly.
Switch off the ABS system.
Apply the footbrake and engage a higher gear.
Depress the clutch pedal and engage a lower gear.
explanation: To stop your vehicle in an emergency, apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping.

text: What can a driver do to stay alert on a long journey?
options: Roll down the window and allow fresh air in.
Stop, park in a safe place and have a cup of coffee.
Turn up the temperature in the vehicle.
Listen attentively to the radio.
explanation: If a driver continues to drive fighting sleep it can be the same as being over the drink driving limit. Stopping the vehicle in a safe place, drinking caffeine and taking a nap for 15 minutes will revive the driver allowing them to continue for a short period.

text: What effect can wet weather have on the vehicle’s exterior mirrors?
options: It has no effect.
It can short-circuit the electrically heated mirrors.
It can keep them clean.
It can distort the rear vision of the driver.
explanation: When driving in the rain, water droplets can adhere to the exterior mirrors and obscure the driver’s view to the side and rear of the vehicle. If the vehicle has heated mirrors, turn them on to clear them. Alternatively, stop periodically to clear them manually.

text: What should a driver do before starting a journey in bad weather?
options: Reduce tyre pressure to ensure better grip on the road.
Top up the windscreen washer reservoir.
Increase tyre pressure to ensure better grip on the road.
Top up the gearbox with coolant.
explanation: Before starting a long journey in adverse weather the driver should ensure that there is sufficient fluid in the windscreen washer bottle in order to keep the windscreen clear in these conditions.

text: What should a driver do to secure the vehicle before leaving it?
options: Apply the exhaust brake and switch off the engine.
Leave the engine running with the parking brake on.
Apply the parking brake and switch off the engine.
Leave the engine running with the exhaust brake on.
explanation: Before you leave your vehicle, apply the parking brake and switch off the ignition. Check to make sure that you can open the door safely without endangering others, and alight when it is safe to do so.

text: Before entering a tunnel, what should a driver do in order to improve vision?
options: Wear sunglasses to prevent glare from the lights.
Take off sunglasses.
Drive close to the vehicle in front.
Pull down the visor to eliminate overhead light glare.
explanation: Be aware that there is considerably less light available in a tunnel, even with the tunnel lights on. To improve your vision remove your sunglasses before entering the tunnel.

text: When a vehicle is stopped in a tunnel due to congestion what should a driver do?
options: Walk to the nearest emergency exit.
Switch off the engine and leave the vehicle.
Keep close to the vehicle in front.
Switch on hazard warning lights.
explanation: If, when driving a vehicle through a tunnel, you meet traffic congestion, leave a safe distance between you and the vehicle in front and switch on your hazard warning lights when stationary.

text: When a vehicle is stopped in a tunnel due to congestion what should a driver do?
options: Switch on the fog lights.
Switch off the engine.
Only give hand signals.
Keep the engine ticking over in a low gear.
explanation: If, when driving a vehicle through a tunnel, you are halted in stationary traffic for any length of time, you should switch off the engine to reduce fumes in the tunnel and conserve fuel.

text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down in a tunnel?
options: Hitch a lift to the nearest service area and get help.
Flag down a passing motorist and ask for help.
Use the emergency telephone to call for help.
Walk to the end of the tunnel to call the Gardaí.
explanation: If a driver’s vehicle stops in a tunnel due to a breakdown, switch off the engine, switch on the hazard warning lights, check the radio for instructions and use the emergency phone at the emergency station to call for help, check all electronic signs in the tunnel for information.

text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down in a tunnel?
options: Wait in the vehicle for help to arrive.
Beckon other traffic to overtake.
Reverse the vehicle to the exit.
Switch on the hazard warning lights.
explanation: If a driver’s vehicle stops in a tunnel due to a breakdown, switch off the engine, switch on the hazard warning lights, check the radio for instructions and use the emergency phone at the emergency station to call for help, check all electronic signs in the tunnel for information.

text: If a vehicle being driven through a tunnel goes on fire, what should the driver do?
options: Leave the vehicle immediately and use the emergency phone at the nearest emergency station.
Stay in the vehicle and phone the emergency station to report the fire.
Drive to the nearest emergency exit as quickly as possible.
Wait for the tunnel traffic radio to announce the fire drill.
explanation: If there is smoke or fire in the vehicle, switch off the engine, leave the vehicle immediately, go to the emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator and leave the tunnel by the nearest available exit.

text: When joining a motorway from a slip road, what should a driver do?
options: Adjust speed to match that of the motorway traffic, and merge into a suitable gap.
Drive on the hard shoulder for a distance until a suitable gap appears in the traffic.
Stop on the slip road until a suitable gap appears in the traffic.
Use the size of the vehicle to assert its position on the motorway.
explanation: When joining a motorway from a slip road, drivers should adjust their speed to that of the motorway traffic on the acceleration lane and merge into a suitable gap in lane 1. Do not force other traffic to swerve or slow down to avoid your vehicle.

text: What would a lightness in the steering MOST likely indicate?
options: Gravelled surface.
Icy surface.
Smooth surface.
Wet surface.
explanation: Lightness in steering indicates a loss of traction. This generally happens when the road surface is icy. Ice provides a harder, smoother surface than rain, or snow so it is difficult to avoid skidding and drivers should allow up to 10 times the normal braking distance in order to stop safely.

text: What are the drink driving penalties for a learner driver with a blood alcohol concentrate (BAC) of 20 mg to 80 mg per 100 millilitres of blood?
options: €200 fine and 5 penalty points.
€200 fine and 6 months driving disqualification.
€200 fine and 3 months driving disqualification.
€200 fine and 3 penalty points.
explanation: Alcohol is a major factor in crashes that lead to death and injury. Research proves that even small amounts of alcohol affect your judgement and ability to drive. It is illegal to drive with alcohol levels above the legal limits.

text: What are the drink driving penalties for a professional driver holding a full car licence and found to have a blood alcohol concentrate (BAC) of 20 mg to 80 mg per 100 millilitres of blood?
options: €100 fine and 6 months driving disqualification.
€200 fine and 3 months driving disqualification.
The penalties only apply over 80 mg (BAC).
There are no penalties below 50 mg (BAC).
explanation: Alcohol is a major factor in crashes that lead to death and injury. Research proves that even small amounts of alcohol affect your judgement and ability to drive. It is illegal to drive with alcohol levels above the legal limits.

text: What are the drink driving penalties for a driver with a blood alcohol concentrate (BAC) of 80 mg to 100 mg per 100 millilitres of blood?
options: €200 fine and 3 months driving disqualification.
€400 fine and 3 months driving disqualification.
€200 fine and 6 months driving disqualification.
€400 fine and 6 months driving disqualification.
explanation: Alcohol is a major factor in crashes that lead to death and injury. Research proves that even small amounts of alcohol affect your judgement and ability to drive. It is illegal to drive with alcohol levels above the legal limits.

text: What is the penalty for a driver who refuses to give breath, blood or urine samples as evidence for a second offence to An Gárda Síochána?
options: Automatic disqualification for 12 months.
Automatic disqualification for 3 months.
Automatic disqualification for 4 years.
Automatic disqualification for 6 years.
explanation: Alcohol is a major factor in crashes that lead to death and injury. Research proves that even small amounts of alcohol or drugs affect your judgement and ability to drive. It is illegal to drive with alcohol levels above the legal limits, or while under the influence of drugs. It is an offence to refuse to give a breath, blood or urine sample.

text: Can An Gárda Síochána conduct roadside testing for drugs and alcohol in the mornings?
options: They can check for alcohol only.
They can check for drugs only.
No, they can’t check until after midday.
Yes, they can check at any time.
explanation: It is against the law to drive a car, motor bike, truck, bus, pedal bike or an animal-drawn vehicle while ‘under the influence of an intoxicant to such an extent as to be incapable of having control of the vehicle’. Intoxicants include alcohol and drugs, whether taken separately or together. The word ‘drugs’ here includes legal prescribed and Over-The-Counter (OTC) medicines.

text: Along with an impairment test, what may a Garda request if they suspect a driver of driving under the influence of drugs?
options: An insurance certificate.
A saliva sample.
A driver’s licence.
A breath sample.
explanation: If a driver is stopped at a roadside check, they should be aware that, along with the impairment test, Gardaí can also request a saliva sample if they suspect the driver is driving under the influence of drugs.

text: What is the maximum penalty on conviction for drug driving?
options: €5,000 fine and 6 months in prison.
€3,000 fine and 12 months driving disqualification.
€3,000 fine and 12 months in prison.
€5,000 fine and 6 months driving disqualification.
explanation: Drivers should be aware of the severe penalties if they chose to drive having taken drugs and are detected. Drug driving is extremely dangerous due to the effect drugs have on the brain.

text: Do the limits for drink and drug driving differ if detected in the morning?
options: Yes, they are lower in the mornings.
No, unless tested after 10:00 am.
Yes, they are higher in the evening.
No, they are the same at all times.
explanation: The limits for drink and drug driving do not change depending on the time of the day drivers are checked. Drink and drugs remain in the body for a period of time. A driver should think carefully before driving a vehicle the morning after taking drink or drugs, and be aware that they could still be well over the limit.

text: What should a driver do when an emergency service vehicle approaches with flashing blue lights?
options: Increase speed to prevent obstructing the emergency service vehicle.
React quickly, safely and carefully to allow the emergency service vehicle to pass.
Brake suddenly to allow the emergency service vehicle to pass.
Do nothing and ignore the emergency service vehicle.
explanation: A driver needs to know what to do when they see an emergency vehicle. A driver must react quickly, safely and carefully to allow emergency service vehicles to pass. It is important to be alert and attentive at all times.

text: What should a driver never do when an emergency service vehicle approaches with flashing blue lights?
options: React quickly, safely and carefully to allow the emergency service vehicle to pass.
Clear the way as soon as possible.
Brake suddenly or block the road.
Pull over in a place which has enough space for the emergency service vehicle to pass safely.
explanation: A driver needs to know what to do when they see an emergency vehicle. A driver must react quickly, safely and carefully to allow emergency service vehicles to pass. It is important to be alert and attentive at all times.

text: Can a driver break a red light or break the speed limit to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass?
options: Yes, a driver may break the speed limit to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
No, a driver should never break a red light or speed up to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
No, except where the junction or road is clear, then a driver can break a red light or speed up to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
Yes, a driver may legally break a red light to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
explanation: A driver needs to know what to do when they see an emergency vehicle. A driver must react quickly, safely and carefully to allow emergency service vehicles to pass. It is important to be alert and attentive at all times.

text: If it is safe to overtake a cyclist in speed zones up to 50 km/h, what is the recommended minimum passing distance?
options: Allow a maximum of 1 metre.
Allow a maximum of 1.75 metres.
Allow a minimum of 1.75 metres.
Allow a minimum of 1 metre.
explanation: A driver should drive their vehicle far enough to the left to allow traffic to safely pass or overtake on the right, but not so far to the left that you are driving on a cycle lane or blocking or endangering cyclists or pedestrians. Where a driver wishes to overtake a cyclist and it is safe to do so, they should, if it is possible, give the recommended clearance depending on the speed limit area they are in.

text: If it is safe to overtake a cyclist in speed zones over 50 km/h, what is the recommended minimum passing distance?
options: Allow a maximum of 1.75 metres.
Allow a minimum of 1 metre.
Allow a maximum of 1.5 metres.
Allow a minimum of 1.5 metres.
explanation: A driver should drive their vehicle far enough to the left to allow traffic to safely pass or overtake on the right, but not so far to the left that you are driving on a cycle lane or blocking or endangering cyclists or pedestrians. Where a driver wishes to overtake a cyclist and it is safe to do so, they should, if it is possible, give the recommended clearance depending on the speed limit area they are in.

text: How can a pedestrian walking along a poorly lit road reduce the risk of an accident occurring?
options: Walk as part of a group.
Wear dark clothing.
Walk on the left-hand side of the road.
Wear high-visibility clothing.
explanation: Even with the best headlights, drivers can see less at night than during the day. Pedestrians and unlit bicycles are extremely difficult to see in the dark, particularly if they have to deal with the glare of oncoming lights. Pedestrians should always wear bright and hi-vis clothing during the day and reflective clothing at night when walking outside built-up areas.

text: What is a courtesy pedestrian crossing?
options: An uncontrolled pedestrian crossing place.
A pedestrian crossing with flashing amber lights.
A pedestrian crossing on a pedestrian street.
A pedestrian crossing with ‘look right’ painted on the roadway.
explanation: Pedestrians should only enter uncontrolled crossing places (courtesy crossing) ensuring that all traffic is aware of their presence if crossing the road. Motorists entering uncontrolled crossing places (courtesy crossing) should react by driving very slowly, and be aware of the potential dangers of pedestrians using the area.

text: What is the likely effect of motorists ‘rubbernecking’ at the scene of a traffic incident?
options: It can cause additional incidents as drivers become distracted.
It allows traffic to change course without attention.
It allows traffic to change speed without attention.
It can increase traffic flow near an incident.
explanation: When approaching or being near to the scene of an incident, motorists are often seen ‘rubbernecking’. This means turning your head and stretching your neck to get a better view of what’s happening. It can be the cause of traffic jams as drivers slow down to ‘rubberneck’. It can also cause road incidents as drivers become distracted and change their speed and/or direction while other drivers are also distracted.

text: How should a driver react to emergency services vehicles with flashing blue lights and/or sirens on?
options: Brake suddenly and stop to avoid causing obstruction.
Check their mirrors before looking for space to move aside.
Mount kerb on offside of the road to make room.
Only move aside if it is an ambulance.
explanation: If you see any emergency vehicle approaching with lights and/or sirens activated, check your rear view mirrors to gauge the speed of the emergency vehicle/s and also look out for pedestrians, cyclists, motorcyclists and other road users. Indicate your intention to pull over. Pull over only in a space that has enough space for the emergency vehicle/s to pass safely. Move off safely with appropriate observations and signals after the emergency vehicle has passed.

text: What is the penalty for a vehicle owner who allows a learner driver to drive their vehicle unaccompanied?
options: They will incur 2 penalty points on their licence.
They will be fined €2,000.
Their vehicle will be seized.
They will lose their driving licence.
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that driving unaccompanied in a vehicle, even where the owner has given their consent to drive, may result in the vehicle being seized.

text: A learner permit driver who receives 7 penalty points in a 36 month period (three years) will be banned from driving for how many months?
options: 9 months.
6 months.
12 months.
3 months.
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that there is a lower penalty point threshold for learner or novice drivers.

text: If the owner of a vehicle allows a learner driver to drive their vehicle, what is the maximum fine the owner could face?
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that driving unaccompanied in a vehicle which they do not own could see the owner facing a fine of up to €1,000 and having the vehicle seized.

text: Is a learner driver permitted to drive unaccompanied if they have the consent of the vehicle owner?
options: Yes, provided the vehicle owner has open drive insurance.
Yes, provided the vehicle owner has given their consent.
Yes, provided the owner is a family member and has given their consent.
No, a learner driver is not permitted to drive unaccompanied even with the owner’s consent.
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that, even with the consent of the owner of the vehicle, they are not permitted to drive unaccompanied.

text: For how long is a learner driver’s accompanying driver required to have held their full licence in Category B?
options: 3 years.
1 year.
2 years.
6 months.
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that not just anyone can be an accompanying driver. An accompanying driver has to have held a full licence for at least 2 years and have built up good driving experience.

text: When a learner driver has passed their driving test, are they permitted to drive unaccompanied as the holder of a Certificate of Competency?
options: No, a learner driver is not permitted to drive unaccompanied until they have been issued with a full driving licence in that category.
No, a learner driver is not permitted to drive unaccompanied on a Certificate of Competency unless they continue to display L plates.
Yes, a learner driver is permitted to drive unaccompanied on a Certificate of Competency once they have notified their insurance company.
Yes, a learner driver is permitted to drive unaccompanied on a Certificate of Competency once they have N plates displayed.
explanation: A learner driver who successfully passes their driving test needs to be aware that the rules that apply to learner permit holders still apply to them until they are in possession of a full driving licence in that category. A Certificate of Competency is not a full licence.

text: Can a learner driver drive unaccompanied if they are on their third or subsequent learner permit?
options: Yes, provided they display N plates on the front and rear of the vehicle.
No, unless they display L plates on the front and rear of the vehicle.
No, they cannot drive unaccompanied on any learner permit.
Yes, but not on motorways.
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that they are not permitted under any circumstance to drive unaccompanied regardless of the amount of learner permits held.

text: Can a person who has passed their car driving test within the last two years act as an accompanying driver?
options: Yes, as long as they have completed their Essential Driver Training (EDT).
Yes, as long as they have their full licence with them.
No, they must hold the full driving licence for a minimum of 2 years.
No, unless they are a qualified Approved Driving Instructor (ADI).
explanation: To be an accompanying driver for a learner driver, you must have a full driving licence for at least 2 years.

text: Are there any occasions when a learner driver can drive unaccompanied?
options: Yes, when driving to the test centre before the driving test.
Yes, when meeting an Approved Driving Instructor (ADI).
No, learner drivers must be accompanied at all times by a qualified driver.
Yes, after completing a driving test.
explanation: Learner drivers must be aware that they must be accompanied by a qualified driver at all times.

text: What should a driver do in the event of a breakdown or incident in a tunnel?
options: Beckon other traffic to overtake.
Reverse the vehicle if necessary to make room for overtaking traffic.
Switch off the engine and switch on the hazard lights.
Signal the vehicle behind to stop and ask the driver to summon help at the other end of the tunnel.
explanation: If your vehicle breaks down or is involved in a collision in a tunnel, switch on your hazard warning lights, switch off your engine, go to an emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator.

text: Is a driver allowed to sound the horn while driving in a built-up area at night?
options: Yes, but only for momentary use.
Yes, but between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am the horn may be sounded only in an emergency.
No, use of the horn is not permitted in a built-up area between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am.
Yes, but only between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am.
explanation: Drivers are not allowed to use the horn in a built-up area between 11:30 pm and 7:00 am unless there is a traffic emergency. Only use a horn to warn other road users of danger or if needed to make them aware of your vehicle’s presence for safety reasons. Using the horn does not give drivers an automatic right of way. Never use the horn to provoke a reaction from or to rebuke another motorist.

text: When driving on this one-way street with vehicles parked on both sides, what should a driver be prepared for?
options: Pedestrians crossing between the vehicles.
The truck may be a left-hand drive vehicle.
Oncoming traffic as the driver overtakes the truck.
explanation: When driving on a one-way street, you should be extra careful and be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

text: When driving late at night what should a driver be aware of?
options: That there is a danger of themselves or other drivers falling asleep.
That all pedestrians will be wearing high-visibility clothing.
That trucks may drive in the outside lane of a motorway.
That speed limits do not apply between midnight and 6:00 am.
explanation: Driving when tired can be very dangerous and driver fatigue is one of the main causes of serious road collisions. If a driver becomes drowsy while driving, they should stop in a safe place take a caffeine-based drink and take a short nap. After this they should then get some fresh air and stretch their legs for a few minutes before setting off again. The only cure for fatigue is proper sleep. Never ever drive when tired.

text: To whom should a driver report aggressive driving?
options: Local Garda station or Traffic Watch.
Transport Infrastructure Ireland.
Health and Safety Authority.
Road Safety Authority.
explanation: Report all aggressive driving incidents to Traffic Watch or a Garda station. They are the best people to deal with aggressive driving.

text: A learner driver who has been stopped by a Garda for driving unaccompanied faces a minimum fine of how much?
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that if stopped by a Garda for driving unaccompanied it will lead to a financial penalty.

text: What is the fine for a learner driver who drives unaccompanied?
explanation: A learner driver needs to know that there are fines for driving unaccompanied.

text: How many penalty points will an unaccompanied learner driver receive on conviction?
options: 3 penalty points.
4 penalty points.
2 penalty points.
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that driving unaccompanied increases the penalty points to 4 on conviction.

text: What should a driver do in this situation?
options: Continue ahead while indicating to overtake parked car.
Sound the horn as a warning and proceed.
Reduce speed and be prepared to stop as other children could follow.
explanation: Drivers should always be aware of other road users especially children, who can be unpredictable and show no road sense. Drivers should slow down and take extra care in areas where there are children about – for example, near schools, playgrounds and in residential areas.

text: What should a driver do in this situation?
options: Proceed promptly to clear the crossing.
Sound the horn to alert the pedestrian.
Allow the pedestrian to cross the road.
explanation: When approaching a zebra crossing, you must yield to pedestrians already on or about to cross the road.

text: What should the driver do when driving a vehicle they are not familiar with?
options: Initially drive with extra care and at a lower speed until fully familiar with the vehicle.
Drive with hazard lights on until fully familiar with the vehicle.
Drive at a normal speed as all vehicle’s features are the same.
explanation: You should know where to find and how to operate all the controls on your vehicle, including all of its safety features and warning lamps. When you are driving, you need to be able to concentrate on what’s happening around you and operating the vehicle controls should be second nature to you. When you sit into the driver’s seat of a vehicle you are not familiar with, you should do a thorough cockpit drill before you move off.

text: What should a driver do when approaching roadworks warning signs?
options: Maintain speed until signalled to slow down by a flagman.
Reduce speed and be prepared to stop for works vehicles or a flagman.
Increase speed and move to the centre of the road.
explanation: A driver should always approach roadworks with caution and reduce speed as there are many possible hazards to deal with – including road workers, works vehicles, uneven road surfaces and temporary traffic controls.

text: What should a driver do when they want to use a mobile phone?
options: Reduce speed, show caution, and be alert for other road users.
Pull in and stop in a safe place.
Keep the conversation short.
Allow a wider gap to open up with the vehicle in front and continue at normal speed.
explanation: It is illegal to use or handle a mobile phone while driving. Driving requires all of your attention, all of the time, so you should never use or handle a mobile phone while driving. If you want to use a mobile phone, the only safe thing to do is to find a safe place to stop.

text: Why is tailgating (driving too close behind the vehicle in front) dangerous?
options: The vehicle will exceed the speed limit.
The vehicle will not have enough distance to stop safely in an emergency.
The braking system is less efficient in the slipstream of the vehicle in front.
The engine may overheat because of restricted air flow over the vehicle’s engine.
explanation: If you drive too close to the vehicle in front and it brakes suddenly, you will not have enough time to react. For that reason you should always keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front. One way of calculating a safe distance in dry weather is the two-second rule: Allow at least two seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and your own vehicle passing a fixed point such as a lamp post or sign post.

text: What is the correct action to take in this situation?
options: Continue to drive at the same speed.
Keep a close eye on the children and be prepared to brake in good time.
Drive closer to the left-hand side (nearside) and sound the horn.
explanation: Because it is difficult to predict children’s behaviour, you should always be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation or to stop.

text: When approaching the pedestrian crossing, what should the driver do in this situation?
options: Maintain speed, because the pedestrians have not stepped on to the crossing.
Continue to drive on fast because the pedestrians have to wait.
Slow down in good time and be prepared to stop.
explanation: When there are pedestrians at or near a zebra crossing, you should slow down on approach and be prepared to stop to allow the pedestrians to cross safely.

text: What should the driver do if there are children playing at the edge of the roadway?
options: Accelerate and move to the right-hand side of the road to avoid the children.
Give a warning signal and drive past at the same speed.
Reduce speed, drive cautiously and remain ready to brake.
explanation: Because it is difficult to predict children’s behaviour, you should always be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation and be prepared to stop.

text: Why might it be dangerous to drive on a poorly-lit street?
options: Pedestrians crossing in a dark area might be difficult to see.
Drivers can only see the traffic coming against them.
Drivers can only see the traffic in front of them.
explanation: When you are driving along a poorly-lit street, you should take extra care – vulnerable road users such as pedestrians might not be so easy to see. You should always be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

text: What should a driver do if dazzled by the lights of an oncoming vehicle?
options: Accelerate to get out of range of light as quickly as possible.
Flash the oncoming vehicle and move to the left.
Look to the left-hand edge (nearside) of the roadway and slow down if necessary.
explanation: If you are dazzled by the lights of oncoming traffic, turn your eyes to the left edge (nearside) of the road. If necessary, stop and allow your eyes to recover before driving on.

text: What should a driver do in this situation when intending to turn left?
options: Proceed between both pedestrians.
Stop and beckon both pedestrians to cross.
Yield to pedestrians already crossing.
explanation: By law you must yield to pedestrians already crossing at a junction. Pedestrians are vulnerable road users and you should be extra careful driving at places where pedestrians are attempting to cross the road.

text: What should a driver do if they see a truck reversing into a side entrance on the left-hand side of the road ahead?
options: Sound the horn to indicate to the driver of the truck to stop.
Try to overtake it so as not to inconvenience traffic behind.
Stop and stay back safely and wait until the way is clear.
explanation: Always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to any traffic situation. You should be aware of the difficulties that drivers of large vehicles can have reversing into a side entrance. In this case, a large vehicle reversing could obstruct your view of the road ahead as you approach, and you should afford the truck driver adequate space to manoeuvre.

text: A driver who is about to undertake a journey is upset or angry. What should they do?
options: Drive slower than normal for a distance.
Being upset or angry does not affect driving.
A driver should not drive until they are calm.
explanation: If you drive when you are angry or upset, you are more likely to be involved in a collision, and more likely to react to other drivers bad behaviour. Take the time to calm down and compose yourself before you set out on a journey.

text: What should a driver be aware of when driving through a section of road where roadworks are ongoing?
options: That the area will be cleared for the driver so that there are no traffic delays.
That road workers are always aware of the movement of traffic.
Narrower lanes than usual and restricted shoulder areas.
explanation: When travelling through a section of roadworks, a driver needs to be extra careful, as the road surface area may be considerably reduced. It may be narrower, uneven, slippery or there may be loose chippings which may pose a danger for road workers and other road users.

text: When approaching a roundabout, to whom should a driver give way?
options: The driver must give way to traffic approaching from the right or already on the roundabout.
The driver approaching the roundabout always has right of way.
The driver must only give way to pedestrians and cyclists on the roundabout.
explanation: Drivers should always approach roundabouts with caution. They should be prepared to give way to traffic on the right, traffic already on the roundabout, pedestrians already crossing and to always stop if necessary.

text: What should a driver do when they see a slow moving vehicle up ahead being driven by a learner driver?
options: Maintain a distance behind to avoid undue pressure.
Drive close behind the vehicle to show your intention to overtake.
Overtake the vehicle as quickly as possible.
explanation: Show patience and courtesy when driving behind a learner driver. Learner drivers are not as experienced as other road users and may drive erratically when put under pressure.

text: When stopped at traffic lights, a driver should take particular care for which road users coming up on their left?
options: Cars.
Tractors.
Cyclists.
explanation: Before moving off at traffic lights and particularly when turning left you should be aware of cyclists and motorcyclists coming up on the left in general – in particular where there is an advanced stop line for cyclists ahead of that for other road users.

text: What should a driver do to minimise fuel consumption in their vehicle?
options: Use gentle acceleration and braking.
Use maximum acceleration between gear changes.
Drive gently in a low gear.
explanation: Driving smoothly will help reduce fuel consumption. Read the road ahead and adjust speed in good time, and avoid harsh acceleration and late braking.

text: What alternatives can drivers take to help protect the environment?
options: Use public transport.
Accelerate and brake harshly while driving.
Only use low gears.
explanation: Using public transport helps to protect the environment. Buses, trams and trains are a more environmentally friendly way to move large numbers of people especially in urban areas. Consider using public transport where possible – not only is it more environmentally friendly, but it can also be more cost-effective when you take the cost of fuel and parking charges into account.

text: A driver approaches a pelican crossing with a flashing amber light showing. There is a pedestrian still on the road. What should the driver do?
options: Beckon the pedestrian to move along as quickly as possible.
Wait and let the pedestrian cross at their own pace.
Sound the horn as a warning and proceed with care.
explanation: You must yield to pedestrians at a pelican crossing when the amber light is flashing.

text: When can a driver travel in the right-hand lane on a dual carriageway?
options: In order to keep a greater distance from the hard shoulder.
When overtaking a vehicle in the left-hand lane.
When following other traffic in the right-hand lane.
explanation: You must normally drive in the left-hand lane of a dual carriageway. You should not use the right-hand lane as a driving lane. You may use the right-hand lane when overtaking or when intending to turn right a short distance ahead.

text: What should a driver do when feeling tired within a short distance from their destination?
options: Stop in a safe place and take a break.
Continue their journey as they are near to their destination.
Speed up so they reach their destination sooner.
explanation: Do not be tempted to keep driving when you are tired when you are close to your destination. The driver should stop in a safe place and take a break. Many driver tiredness related collisions occur within a short distance of their destination as the body begins to relax.

text: When should a driver move into an auxiliary lane on a motorway?
options: To leave the motorway.
To allow other traffic to overtake.
To overtake slower traffic in other lanes.
explanation: Auxiliary lanes are found on some motorways and are to the left of the main motorway lanes. They link the off-ramp of the road you are leaving with the next available off-ramp or exit. If a driver is already in lane 1 of the motorway and they intend to take the next exit, they should enter the auxiliary lane to do so. The auxiliary lane is normally identified by a broken white line to the right of the lane, with markings that are shorter, closer and wider than the broken white lines normally seen in lane 1, 2 or 3.

text: When overtaking a cyclist what should a driver be aware of?
options: The cyclist is only permitted to use the bus lane.
The cyclist is not wearing a safety helmet.
The cyclist may suddenly change direction.
explanation: Cyclists are just as entitled to use the road as other vehicles, and drivers need to pay special attention to them. Cyclists are vulnerable road users and sometimes make sudden movements - for example, to avoid a pothole, some broken glass or other debris on the road. Sufficient clearance should be given when overtaking them to lessen the possible danger.

text: What should a driver ensure when overtaking a cyclist?
options: Overtake when the cyclist pulls in and stops.
Overtake only when the cyclist is in a cycle lane.
Overtake giving them plenty of space.
explanation: Cyclists are vulnerable road users. Motorists must give good clearance when overtaking cyclists.

text: Is a driver allowed to exceed the speed limit when overtaking?
options: The driver may not exceed the speed limit when overtaking.
The driver may exceed the speed limit briefly in order to complete the manoeuvre.
The driver may exceed the speed limit if the vehicle in front is turning left.
explanation: When overtaking the driver is not permitted to exceed the speed limit.

text: When is a driver allowed to overtake another vehicle on the left?
options: When on the motorway in fast moving traffic.
A driver is never allowed to overtake on the left.
When the driver is turning left.
explanation: Drivers must normally overtake on the right however they may overtake on the left when they have signalled that they intend to turn left and it is done in a safe manner relative to the traffic conditions.

text: At traffic lights a driver should take particular care for which road users coming up on the left side (nearside)?
options: Motorcyclists.
Trucks.
Cars.
explanation: Before moving off at traffic lights you should be aware of motorcyclists unexpectedly coming up on the left-hand side (nearside).

text: What should a driver do if their vehicle is forced to stop in a tunnel due to a breakdown or a crash?
options: Wait in the vehicle for help to arrive.
Beckon other traffic to overtake.
Call for help from an emergency station.
explanation: If there is a breakdown or crash in a tunnel, stop, switch off the engine, switch on the hazard warning lights, check the radio for instructions and use the emergency phone at the emergency station to call for help, check all electronic signs in the tunnel for information.

text: When may you pass another vehicle on the left-hand side?
options: When there is enough space to do so.
When a driver cannot pass on the right-hand side because of oncoming traffic.
A driver must never overtake on the left.
When the vehicle in front is signalling to turn right or in slow moving lanes of traffic.
explanation: Normally you must overtake on the right. There are, however, circumstances where you may overtake on the left – for example, when the vehicle has moved out and signalled to turn right.

text: What should a driver do if there is a large oil spill on the road?
options: Maintain normal speed in a lower gear and switch on hazard warning lights.
Reduce speed by gently applying the brakes and switch on the hazard warning lights.
Maintain normal speed and try to drive on the spill with the wheels.
Depress the clutch and brake sharply and switch on the hazard warning lights.
explanation: Where oil is spilt on the road, your tyres will have reduced grip, and you might be at risk of skidding if you brake sharply. If you do come across oil on the road, brake gently and switch on your hazard warning lights for a short period to alert other traffic to the hazard.

text: When should signals (for example, with indicators) be given to other road users?
options: When turning, except where road markings indicate your direction.
Clearly and in good time to let other road users know what you intend to do.
Only when it is necessary to warn following traffic.
explanation: Giving signals is a way of telling other road users what you intend to do. So, you should signal properly before moving off, turning right or left, changing lanes, overtaking, slowing down or stopping. Signal clearly and in good time, and keep in mind that giving a signal does not give you the right of way.

text: How does giving a late signal affect other road users?
options: They are not affected.
It only affects other road users at roundabouts.
They may not have been given enough time to react.
It only affects other road users at traffic lights.
explanation: Giving signals is a way of telling other road users what you intend to do. So, you should signal properly before moving off, turning right or left, changing lanes, overtaking, slowing down or stopping. Signal clearly and in good time, and keep in mind that giving a signal does not give you the right of way. Late signals may confuse other road users.

text: When driving behind a heavy goods vehicle that is signalling to turn right, what should a driver do?
options: Overtake it slowly on the inside by driving partly on the footpath if necessary.
See if the vehicle can complete the turn without stopping, and if not, overtake it yourself.
Stay behind until there is enough space to overtake it on the inside or until it has completed the turn.
Sound the horn and overtake the heavy goods vehicle on the right.
explanation: Heavy goods vehicles need extra space on the road, and when they are turning the overhang of the vehicle may swing out into the path of overtaking or passing traffic. For that reason, it is a good idea to stay back and let the heavy goods vehicle complete its turn unless there is sufficient space to overtake safely.

text: Where are the blind spots that a driver needs to be aware of when towing a loaded trailer?
options: Parts of the road ahead which are blocked by other large vehicles.
The area to the side and rear of the vehicle and the trailer that the driver cannot see.
The goods or cargo area on the back of the trailer.
The view to the front hidden by the sun-visor.
explanation: A blind spot is an area that a driver cannot see when looking forward or when looking in the mirrors. You should check your blind spots before changing direction or changing lane. The bigger the vehicle, the bigger the blind spots, and you should keep this in mind if you are driving behind a large vehicle, such as one towing a loaded trailer. In this situation, if you cannot see the towing vehicle’s mirror, then the driver of that vehicle cannot see you.

text: What should a driver do when overtaking parked vehicles in a residential area?
options: Keep close to the parked vehicles allowing maximum room for oncoming traffic.
Increase speed to overtake the vehicles as quickly as possible.
Move as far to the right as possible.
Allow enough clearance when passing.
explanation: When you are passing parked vehicles in a residential area, move into a safe overtaking position in good time and leave plenty of clearance between your vehicle and the parked vehicles to increase visibility of small children in the area and in case someone opens their car door in front of you.

text: How should a driver manage a steep hill or humpbacked bridge when the road is slippery?
options: Select neutral gear position.
Drive with extreme care.
Press the clutch and brake together.
Press the clutch only.
explanation: Be extra careful when negotiating steep hills or humpbacked bridges in slippery conditions. Slow down gently on the approach, select the appropriate gear for the speed of the vehicle and use gentle steering and acceleration.

text: What should a driver do when they see joggers ahead on the left?
options: Indicate and overtake allowing enough clearance.
Sound the horn and flash the lights to warn them of your presence.
Check the mirrors, indicate and overtake, allowing them enough clearance.
Expect them to move in out of the driver’s path.
explanation: People on the road are more vulnerable than vehicles so you should treat them with extra care. If you see people jogging ahead, use the Mirror–Signal–Manoeuvre routine and give plenty of clearance to the joggers when you are overtaking them.

text: What could happen if a driver parks on a footpath?
options: The tyres will lose air pressure.
The suspension will be weakened.
Pedestrians could be prevented from passing.
Traffic could be prevented from passing.
explanation: You should never park on a footpath. Pedestrians (including people with young children in pushchairs, prams and also wheelchair users) might have to go onto the road to get around your car, and this could put them in danger.

text: If a driver suspects that their vehicle indicators have not been seen, what should the driver do?
options: Use a clear, decisive hand signal as well.
The driver’s position on the road is enough of a signal.
It is unnecessary to give signals provided observation is taken.
explanation: If the driver is concerned that for whatever reason the indicators are not giving an adequate signal, they should use clear decisive hand signals as well to advise other road users of their intention.

text: What should a driver do before starting a journey in poor weather conditions?
options: Top up the windscreen washer reservoir with coolant.
Check the weather forecast for the planned route.
Increase tyre pressure to ensure better grip on the road.
Reduce tyre pressure to ensure better grip on the road.
explanation: Driving in adverse weather conditions is more dangerous and more tiring. Drivers should check the weather forecast and weather warnings and other sources for information on the expected conditions on the intended route, and allow extra time to complete the journey.

text: How should a driver manage a steep descent in snow or frosty weather?
options: Engage a lower gear early and use gentle braking applications to keep the speed down.
Keep the clutch depressed and use gentle braking.
Engage a higher gear than normal in order to avoid wheel-spin.
Always keep close to the left and use short, sharp brake applications to keep the speed down.
explanation: In snow or ice, a vehicle takes longer to stop. Before starting a steep descent in a large vehicle, the driver should reduce speed and select a lower gear, brake gently and only when needed. If the vehicle is fitted with a manually selectable retarder, engage it before starting the descent.

text: Before driving through a tunnel, what should a driver do?
options: Turn on side lights only.
Register at the first tunnel station.
Disengage the Global Positioning System (GPS).
Check that you have enough fuel.
explanation: If your route takes you through a tunnel, you must ensure that your vehicle has enough fuel to safely pass through.

text: When another driver is in a hurry and cuts in front what should a driver do?
options: Drive closely behind them so other vehicles cannot do the same.
Be patient and do not react.
Flash the headlights to express their annoyance.
Drive faster to make up for lost time.
explanation: If another driver behaves badly, you should not let it annoy you – show restraint and don’t react. Road rage only increases the risk of a collision.

text: What is the purpose of rumble strips on the sides of a carriageway?
options: To alert drivers that their vehicle is veering out of their lane.
To prevent livestock entering the carriageway.
To improve drainage of the carriageway in heavy rain.
explanation: Rumble strips are raised or grooved patterns on the roadway shoulder that provide both an audible warning (rumbling sound) and a physical vibration to alert drivers that they are leaving the driving lane. In addition to warning inattentive drivers, rumble strips help drivers on the road during inclement weather when visibility is poor.

text: What should a driver do if they feel tired before starting a journey?
options: Do not start the journey until they are rested.
Open the windows in the vehicle before they start their journey.
Bring a cup of strong coffee to drink in the vehicle during the journey.
explanation: A driver should not drive or begin a journey if they are feeling tired or fatigued. Research has shown that tired drivers are a major road safety risk, both to themselves and to others.

text: What should a driver do if they experience micro-sleep whilst driving?
options: Open all vehicle windows to reduce temperature.
Stop in a safe place.
Have a 20 minute sleep when they reach their destination.
explanation: A driver should not drive while tired or fatigued. Research has shown that tired drivers are a major road safety risk, both to themselves and to others. If a driver is tired and fighting sleep, they are likely to experience “micro-sleeps” these episodes can last up to 10 seconds and can be experienced even when eyes are open. During a micro-sleep of even 4 seconds, a vehicle can travel 100 metres (more than the length of a football pitch) without the driver being in control of the vehicle.

text: What should a driver do if they are taking a medication which can make them feel drowsy?
options: Continue driving until they begin to feel drowsy.
Only drive during daylight hours.
Do not drive a vehicle.
explanation: It is against the law to drive a vehicle while under the influence of an intoxicant to such an extent as to be incapable of having control of the vehicle. Intoxicants include alcohol or drugs, whether taken separately or together. Drugs include legally prescribed or Over-The-Counter (OTC) medicines.

text: When driving on a road that has a potholed surface and there is an e-scooter ahead, what should a driver do?
options: Expect the e-scooter to keep to the left and maintain speed.
Allow extra clearance in case the e-scooter swerves to avoid a pothole.
Maintain course and sound the horn to alert the e-scooter of their approach.
explanation: You should always be aware of how vulnerable e-scooters are. When you are driving on a road with potholes or bad surfaces, give plenty of clearance to the e-scooters when overtaking them. Take into account that they may swerve suddenly to avoid potholes.

text: What procedure should a driver follow when intending to overtake an e-scooter travelling in the same direction up ahead?
options: Signal, check mirrors, move out and overtake when safe to do so.
Check mirrors, signal and move out if it is safe to do so.
Signal, move out and check mirrors for following traffic.
explanation: The procedure drivers should follow the mirrors - signal - manoeuvre routine when overtaking. Drivers should overtake only when it is safe to do so. Give extra space to e-scooters when overtaking them, as they may need to move out to avoid a pothole, or they could be blown into your path on windy days.

text: When driving in the dark on an unlit country road, what should a driver be aware of?
