options: That e-scooter users have space in the margin of the road so that a driver can overtake them without moving out.
That e-scooter users all wear reflective belts, have the correct lighting on their e-scooters and are clearly visible.
That e-scooter users are much more vulnerable on dark roads.
explanation: Drivers should take extra care when driving on dark winter mornings and evenings – vulnerable road users such as cyclists, e-scooters and pedestrians (particularly schoolchildren) might not be so easy to see in low light conditions.

text: When stopped at traffic lights, a driver should take particular care for which road users coming up on their left?
options: Cars.
Tractors.
E-scooters.
explanation: Before moving off at traffic lights and particularly when turning left you should be aware of e-scooters coming up from behind.

text: What should a driver do when they intend to make a left-hand turn at a junction where there are cyclists and e-scooter users present?
options: Use your mirrors to check for cyclists and e-scooter users on the left before turning.
Signal left, check the right-hand mirror and complete the turn.
Sound the horn so as to warn the other road users of the intention to turn.
explanation: The vehicle does not have a greater right-of-way than any other road user. As a driver you should pay particular attention to vulnerable road users such as e-scooter users, cyclists and motorcyclists and be aware that they are entitled to use the road in safety.

text: When a driver intends to make a left-hand turn at a busy city junction and there are pedestrians, cyclists and e-scooter users present, what should the driver do?
options: Keep to the right to make room for cyclists and e-scooter users to pass.
Signal left, watch the right-hand mirror and make the turn when it is clear.
Watch for pedestrians, cyclists and e-scooter users who may try to cross the road in front of the driver’s vehicle.
explanation: When making a left-hand turn on a busy city street, drivers should pay particular attention to vulnerable road users such as pedestrians, cyclists, motorcyclists and e-scooter users who may appear unexpectedly and especially from the left and may not be aware of the vehicle’s intention.

text: In slow-moving city traffic, a driver should occasionally check their blind spots for which road users in particular?
options: Cars.
Vans.
E-scooters.
explanation: Drivers should be aware of and check blind spots before moving off and changing direction where appropriate. E-scooters can easily become hidden in a blind spot, and in slow-moving traffic, they might be moving faster than you are.

text: What action should a driver take on approach to the brow of this hill?
options: Reduce speed as possible hazards ahead.
Comply with the road markings.
Maintain normal speed.
explanation: On the approach to the brow of a hill you should be extra careful and be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

text: What should a driver do when driving at night on an unlit road?
options: Drive close to the left and switch on front fog lights.
Watch out for unlit e-scooters.
Drive along the centre of the road.
explanation: While driving at night and even with the best headlights, it can be very difficult to see all the hazards that you might come across – for example, unlit e-scooters on the road. At night you should drive at a speed that will enable you to stop safely within the distance you can see to be clear ahead.

text: Which type of road users are particularly vulnerable at junctions?
options: Car drivers.
Van drivers.
E-scooter users.
explanation: Cyclists, motorcyclists and e-scooter users are often difficult to see at junctions and may approach faster than you think.

text: What should a driver be aware of when making a left turn into a side road?
options: E-scooters may come up on the left (nearside).
E-scooters might come up on the right (offside).
Following traffic must have room to overtake.
explanation: When turning left, drivers should be aware that cyclists, pedestrians and e-scooters may come up on the left (nearside) . Always check to your left (nearside) before you make a left turn.

text: If there is no footpath, where must a pedestrian walk?
options: Right-hand side of the road.
1 metre from the edge of the road.
Left-hand side of the road.
There is no regulation.
explanation: Where there is no footpath provided, pedestrians should walk on the right-hand side of the road facing oncoming traffic. Drivers should be aware of the Rules of the Road for pedestrians, drive with caution and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.

text: When should pedestrians wear reflective clothing at night?
options: When in urban areas.
At night, when walking outside built-up areas.
When walking two abreast.
Only when it is raining.
explanation: Outside built-up areas, pedestrians should wear reflective clothing at all times when walking at night. This is particularly important where there is no street lighting and no footpath for pedestrians.

text: As the driver of the car, which conduct is correct?
options: A driver must give way to traffic on the left.
A driver must drive on the right-hand side to allow clearance to the motorcyclist.
A driver may proceed with caution.
Slow down and beckon the motorcyclist to cross the road.
explanation: You may proceed, but you should be aware of the presence of the motorcyclist. You should always be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation – for example, the motorcyclist might not have seen your vehicle.

text: What should the car driver do in this situation?
options: The driver must allow the cyclist to proceed.
The driver may turn right before the cyclist.
The driver must allow the motorcyclist to proceed.
The driver must stop and yield right of way to the other road users.
explanation: When you are turning right from a major road to a minor road, you must yield to oncoming traffic, and you should proceed only when it is safe to do so.

text: What should the driver do in this situation?
options: The driver must wait for the yellow car to stop.
The driver must yield to the yellow car on the roundabout.
As the driver is entering the roundabout they have right of way.
The driver may proceed onto the roundabout in front of the yellow car.
explanation: When you reach the roundabout, you must give way to traffic approaching from the right – unless signs, road markings or traffic lights tell you otherwise.

text: What should the car driver do in this situation?
options: The car driver is not allowed to turn right.
The car driver must allow the bus to proceed.
The car driver may proceed first.
The car driver must allow the motorcycle to proceed.
explanation: When you are turning right from a major road to a minor road, you must yield to oncoming traffic. You should proceed only when it is safe to do so.

text: What should the driver do in this situation?
options: The driver must allow the red car to proceed.
The driver must stop and allow all other traffic to proceed.
The driver must allow the blue car to proceed.
The driver may turn in front of the other two cars.
explanation: When you are turning right from a major road to a minor road, you must yield to oncoming traffic and only proceed when it is safe to do so. However, the drivers on the minor roads must give way to the traffic on the major road.

text: What should the driver do in this situation?
options: The cyclist must proceed first.
The driver must allow the van to cross the junction.
The driver may continue ahead with caution.
The cyclist must allow the other vehicles to proceed.
explanation: On approaching a crossroads you should check the road sign to see which traffic has priority and be prepared for emerging traffic from either side. Vehicles do not have an automatic right of way on the road. The overriding rule is to proceed with caution in all circumstances.

text: What should the driver do in this situation?
options: The driver must allow the orange car to cross.
The driver must turn left.
The driver is not allowed to turn right.
The driver may turn right.
explanation: You may turn right if there no oncoming traffic but you should also be aware that there might be traffic emerging from the minor roads.

text: What should the driver do in this situation?
options: The driver must allow the blue truck to proceed.
The driver must allow the red car to proceed.
The driver may proceed first.
explanation: When you are turning right from a major road to a minor road, you must yield to oncoming traffic and proceed only when it is safe to do so. You should also be aware that there might be emerging from the minor road.

text: What should a driver be conscious of in this situation?
options: People crossing the street at the rear of the bus.
The bus driver will always signal before moving off.
The bus may start to reverse.
Traffic emerging from the street on the left.
explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to the changing traffic situation. In particular, you should be aware that pedestrians might emerge at the rear of the bus. In this situation you should also look out for pedestrians making their way towards the waiting bus.

text: The driver is following these two vehicles and wishes to overtake - what must the driver consider before overtaking here?
options: The driver should overtake both vehicles together.
The driver of the silver car may decide to turn right.
The driver’s field of view is not good enough to allow safe overtaking.
The roadway markings forbid overtaking here.
explanation: You should always make sure that the road ahead is clear so that there is enough distance to allow you to overtake and get back to the correct side of the road without forcing any other road user to alter speed or course. In this case, the brow of the hill is too close to allow a driver to overtake safely.

text: What should a driver be aware of when approaching a vehicle which is attempting to park?
options: The vehicle may be parking at an area designated for loading.
The driver may have to stop and assist the driver parking the vehicle.
That there may be a driveway at the point where the vehicle is parking.
That the vehicle being parked may move out without warning.
explanation: When you approach a vehicle that is being parked on the roadway, you should be aware that its driver will probably be concentrating on parking the vehicle and may not be aware of moving out into the road to correct its position.

text: What should the driver of the silver car do before turning left?
options: Increase speed to be able to complete the left turn before the cyclist.
Overtake the cyclist on the left and complete the turn.
Allow the cyclist heading straight on to pass.
Sound the horn to alert the cyclist to the car’s presence.
explanation: Do not overtake a cyclist as you approach a junction at which you are turning left. The cyclist might be continuing ahead. Cyclists are vulnerable road users and may be unstable in slow-moving traffic and at junctions. Give them more room.

text: What lights should a driver use in dense fog?
options: Front and rear fog lights along with dipped headlights.
Front and rear fog lights along with side lights.
Front and rear fog lights along with main beam lights.
Front and rear fog lights along with hazard warning lights.
explanation: When driving in dense fog you should switch on your front and rear fog lights along with dipped headlights. You should not drive in fog with main beam headlights on.

text: What should the driver do?
options: The driver must stop and yield to all traffic.
The driver should allow the oncoming cyclist to turn first.
The driver should allow the yellow car to proceed.
The driver may turn left first.
explanation: At a cross junction of equal importance the traffic approaching from the right has priority. It is important to understand that the right of way is not an absolute right. You must proceed with caution while showing regard for other road users.

text: What action should the driver take?
options: Proceed in front of the bus.
Proceed in front of the cyclist.
Signal the bus to proceed.
Stop at the stop line.
explanation: By law you must stop at a stop line (or at a STOP sign if there is no stop line), and wait for other traffic to clear before proceeding.

text: The driver intends to turn left at this junction - what should the driver do?
options: Allow the van and cyclist to proceed.
Yield right of way to the van.
Allow the cyclist to continue before turning left.
Turn left in front of the cyclist.
explanation: Do not overtake a cyclist as you approach a junction at which you are turning left. The cyclist might be continuing ahead. Cyclists are vulnerable road users and may be unstable in slow-moving traffic and at junctions. Give them more room.

text: The driver intends to turn right at this junction - what should the driver do?
options: Proceed after the motorcycle and bus have passed.
Proceed after the motorcycle only.
Proceed in front of the bus and motorcyclist.
Proceed in front of the bus only.
explanation: When you are turning right at a junction, you should yield to traffic on the major road, and to oncoming traffic at the junction.

text: When intending to turn right as shown, what should the car driver do?
options: Continue with care as the driver has right of way.
Wait and allow the truck to proceed first.
Wait and allow the oncoming vehicle to pass.
Wait and allow the truck and the oncoming vehicle to proceed first.
explanation: When you are turning right from a main road onto a side road, you must by law give way to oncoming traffic on the main road.

text: What should a driver do when continuing straight ahead in the middle lane?
options: Slow down and allow the driver in front to change lanes.
Take any lane as convenient.
Take position in the right-hand lane even if proceeding straight ahead.
Overtake the other vehicles quickly on the right-hand side.
explanation: You should always keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front especially when it is slowing down or stopping.

text: When driving on a cobblestone road why should you take extra care?
options: The road surface is uneven and road grip varies.
The smoothness of the cobblestones helps to improve grip.
The road surface is particularly even and tyre grip is improved.
The gaps between the stones helps road holding and grip is improved.
explanation: Different road surfaces can affect your vehicle’s grip on the road and its stopping distances. You should be aware of this when driving on different surfaces.

text: When driving on this one-way street with vehicles parked on both sides, what should a driver be prepared for?
options: The truck may be a left-hand drive vehicle.
Oncoming traffic as the driver overtakes the truck.
A vehicle door may open on either side of the street.
explanation: When driving on a one-way street, you should be extra careful and should be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

text: When preparing to stop, a driver notices the vehicle behind is towing a trailer. What should the driver do?
options: Use the handbrake to slow down and stop.
Stop quickly keeping a close eye on the rear-view mirror.
Speed up temporarily to put distance between their vehicle and the vehicle behind.
Indicate in good time and pull in gradually to allow the vehicle behind extra stopping distance.
explanation: When you are slowing down or stopping, you should be mindful of the type of vehicle that is following you. For example, if the vehicle following you is a large vehicle or one towing a trailer, you should think of indicating a little earlier than normal to allow the following vehicle enough time to react safely.

text: What should a driver do when being overtaken by another vehicle?
options: Move to the right.
Continue at the same pace.
Slow down quickly.
Increase speed.
explanation: When you are being overtaken by another vehicle, you should continue at the same pace but be alert in case the overtaking vehicle suddenly pulls back in front you.

text: How does rain affect driving in this situation?
options: It increases tyre grip on the road.
It reduces the danger of skidding.
It increases visibility.
It increases the danger of skidding.
explanation: When it is wet, your tyres do not grip the road surface as well as when it is dry, your stopping distance is increased and you are more likely to skid. For these reasons you should slow down during or after rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

text: When should a driver use the vehicle’s rear view mirror?
options: Before moving off only.
Before reversing only.
Before changing direction.
Before switching on the rear demister.
explanation: You should use your mirrors to stay aware of traffic situations behind and around you. Always check your mirror before you change direction on a road, and before you signal or begin a manoeuvre.

text: What should drivers do if they become drowsy while driving?
options: Stop and have a good meal to boost energy levels.
Turn up the heating.
Open a window or turn on the air conditioning to let cool air into the vehicle.
Stop, take a break including a short walk if possible.
explanation: Driving when you are tired can be very dangerous, and tiredness is one of the main causes of serious road collisions. If you become drowsy while driving, stop in a safe place and take a short nap. Then get some fresh air and stretch your legs for a few minutes before setting off again. Taking a caffeine-based drink such as coffee may also help.

text: Which of the following affects the braking distance of a vehicle?
options: The use of unleaded fuel.
The brake-pad clearance.
The speed and weight of the vehicle.
The power of the engine.
explanation: The overall stopping distance of your vehicle depends on its speed and weight – faster and heavier vehicles require greater stopping distances.

text: What should a driver do when driving in dense fog?
options: Drive along the hard shoulder and watch for the reflective markers.
Drive along the central dividing line and watch for the reflective markings.
Reduce speed and use dipped headlights.
Reduce speed and use full headlights.
explanation: In dense fog you should reduce your speed and use dipped headlights and fog lights (where fitted). Sidelights are not strong enough in fog, and full headlights can reflect off the fog and make it harder to see where you are going.

text: When driving at night the full headlights of a typical car should enable the driver to see for a distance of how many metres?
options: 50 metres.
150 metres.
100 metres.
200 metres.
explanation: At night in good driving conditions the full headlights of a car will typically let you see 100 metres ahead. So, you should travel at a speed that allows you to stop within that distance.

text: When driving at night the dipped headlights of a typical car should enable the driver to see for a distance of how many metres?
options: 20 metres.
30 metres.
50 metres.
40 metres.
explanation: When driving at night in good driving conditions the dipped headlights of a car will typically let you see 30 metres ahead. So, you should travel at a speed that allows you to stop in that distance.

text: When driving at night, when must a driver dip the vehicle’s full headlights?
options: When driving at less than 50 km/h.
When meeting or driving behind other traffic.
When entering a motorway.
When there is no oncoming traffic.
explanation: When driving at night you should dip your headlights when you meet oncoming vehicles so that you do not dazzle them. And you should also dip your headlights when you are driving behind another vehicle so the driver is not dazzled by your lights in their mirror.

text: When meeting an oncoming vehicle at night, what should a driver do?
options: Avoid looking directly at the oncoming vehicle’s lights.
Increase speed to pass the oncoming vehicle.
Focus eyes directly on the steering.
Focus eyes directly on the oncoming vehicle’s lights.
explanation: If you are dazzled by the lights of an oncoming vehicle, look towards the verge until the vehicle has passed and/or slow down and stop if necessary.

text: When wishing to turn right at the end of a one-way street, where should a driver position their vehicle?
options: Drive occupying both lanes when approaching the end of the street.
Drive in either lane as there is no oncoming traffic.
Drive as close as is possible to the right-hand side of the road.
Drive as close as possible to the left-hand side of the road.
explanation: When a driver wants to turn right on a one way street, they should check their mirrors, signal right and manoeuvre into the right-hand side when it is safe to do so. Then complete the turn into the appropriate lane of the street they are entering.

text: In what direction should a driver turn when entering a roundabout?
options: To the left.
To the right.
To the right when controlled by a traffic light.
To either left or right.
explanation: By law you must enter a roundabout by turning to the left and giving way to traffic already on the roundabout.

text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down or they are involved in a collision in a tunnel?
options: Switch off all lights and remain in vehicle until help arrives.
Beckon other traffic to overtake.
Signal all other traffic to stop.
Switch on hazard warning lights and walk to emergency station to call for help.
explanation: If your vehicle breaks down or is involved in a collision in a tunnel, switch on your hazard warning lights, switch off your engine, go to an emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator.

text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down in a tunnel?
options: Wait in the vehicle until help arrives.
Flag down a passing motorist and ask for help.
Walk to the end of the tunnel and call the Gardaí.
Use the emergency telephone to call for help.
explanation: If your vehicle breaks down or is involved in a collision in a tunnel, switch on your hazard warning lights, switch off your engine, go to an emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator.

text: What should a driver do if their vehicle goes on fire in a tunnel?
options: Drive to the nearest fire exit.
Drive to the nearest emergency station.
Leave the vehicle and follow the emergency escape route.
Leave the vehicle and use the fire extinguishers provided in the tunnel to extinguish the fire.
explanation: If your vehicle goes on fire in a tunnel, you should stop the vehicle as soon as possible, evacuate any passengers to a safe place, go to an emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator.

text: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets a puncture on a motorway?
options: Pull in where safe on the hard shoulder and call for assistance.
Stop in the hard shoulder and get a passenger to warn traffic.
Drive on to the next service area and get assistance.
Stop in the traffic lane and switch on the hazard warning lights.
explanation: Don’t try to change a wheel on a motorway, as this could be very dangerous. Drive the car on to the hard shoulder, and when it is safe to do so, get out of the vehicle and move behind the barrier. Call for assistance from a motorway emergency phone or using a mobile phone (call the Gardaí).

text: When should a driver use hazard warning lights on a motorway?
options: When another vehicle is following too closely.
When driving on the hard shoulder.
When the vehicle is towing a trailer.
When the vehicle has broken down.
explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on a motorway, drive it to the hard shoulder and switch on the hazard warning lights to warn following traffic. When it is safe to do so, get out of the vehicle and move behind the barrier. Call for assistance from a motorway emergency phone or using a mobile phone (call the Gardaí).

text: When a driver is making a left-hand turn, what mirrors should they particularly concentrate on?
options: The right exterior mirror.
The interior and left exterior mirror.
The interior mirror.
The interior and right exterior mirror.
explanation: When turning left, drivers should in particular be aware that cyclists and other vehicles may come up on their nearside (left-hand side). For that reason, when checking mirrors, it is particularly important to check both the left exterior and the interior mirror before turning. Drivers must always use the Mirrors–Signal–Mirror–Manoeuvre routine when turning. They should be particularly careful if crossing the path of a bus and/or cycle lane.

text: How can a driver help the environment?
options: By braking harshly.
By increasing speed.
By harsh acceleration.
By reducing speed.
explanation: As a driver you can do less damage to the environment if you drive smoothly and avoid harsh acceleration and braking. Vehicles travelling at 110 km/h use up to 30% more fuel than those travelling at 80 km/h. However, you should not drive so slow as to inconvenience other road users.

text: What action should a driver take when they meet a vehicle with flashing blue lights?
options: Switch on the vehicle hazard warning lights.
Flash the headlights and drive up onto the footpath on the left.
Flash the headlights and come to an immediate stop.
Move to the left, reduce speed and stop if necessary.
explanation: When a driver notices an emergency vehicle approaching in the distance, they should check their mirror and move to the left to allow the vehicle to pass. On some occasions it may be necessary to stop.

text: What should a driver do if an ambulance is stopped up ahead with its flashing blue lights on?
options: Stop and offer assistance.
Move to the centre of the road to stop other vehicles from overtaking.
Reduce speed and prepare to stop if necessary.
Stop immediately to see what is happening.
explanation: When you come upon an emergency vehicle stopped on the road, you should slow down and be prepared to stop. Do not stop to see what is happening as this could be dangerous and you might cause an obstruction to the flow of traffic.

text: When driving on a road with tram lines why should a driver take extra care?
options: Driving on the tracks can improve braking.
Driving on the tracks can reduce tyre grip.
Driving on the tracks can improve tyre grip.
Driving on the tracks can improve steering.
explanation: Different road surfaces can affect your vehicle’s grip on the road and its stopping distances. You should be aware of this when driving on different surfaces.

text: In this situation, what should the driver in the right-hand lane of the dual carriageway be aware of?
options: Oncoming traffic.
Increased visibility.
The motorcyclist may perform a U-turn.
Crosswinds may blow the rider into their path.
explanation: When driving in wet and windy conditions, a driver should be aware that these conditions can affect the stability of vulnerable road users such as motorcyclists or cyclists. These road users may be blown into the driver’s path particularly in open and exposed areas.

text: What should a driver do if dazzled by lights at night reflecting in their interior mirror?
options: Switch on the rear fog lights.
Switch on hazard lights.
Temporarily adjust the angle of the mirror.
Adjust the mirror to reflect the light back towards the following driver.
explanation: If the lights of following traffic reflecting in your interior mirror are dazzling you, activate the night driving/anti dazzle mode. If the vehicle is not equipped with this feature drivers should temporarily adjust the angle of the interior mirror to relieve the glare and allow them to drive without distraction.

text: What lights should be shown on a parked car, tractor or works vehicle at night on an unlit public road?
options: At least one side lamp front and rear on the side nearest the centre of the road.
Tail lights only.
Dipped headlights.
At least one side lamp front and rear on the side nearest the kerb.
explanation: When leaving a vehicle on an unlit public road at night this creates a potential danger for other road users. Drivers should therefore leave side/parking lights on, so that the vehicle can be seen by other road users. Drivers should not leave headlights on when parked as this may cause other road users to become disoriented.

text: When are children allowed to stand with their heads up through an open sun roof?
options: When they are aged more than 12 years.
Children are never allowed to do so.
When travelling at speeds below 30 km/h.
When they are wearing eye protection.
explanation: When carrying children in a car or goods vehicle, it is the driver’s responsibility to make sure that they are suitably restrained.

text: When may the holder of a Category W learner permit carry a passenger on a tractor or works vehicle?
options: When the passenger holds a full Category M licence and has personal insurance cover.
When there is proper passenger seating and the passenger holds a full Category W licence.
When there is a need for their assistance.
When the passenger has personal insurance cover.
explanation: The holder of a Category W licence may carry a passenger in the vehicle only if: 1. the vehicle is designed to take a passenger, and 2. the passenger has held a full driving licence in Category W for two or more years.

text: When is a driver allowed to carry more passengers in a car than there are seat belts available?
options: It is always allowed.
When the driver’s visibility is not interfered with.
When the driver has the appropriate insurance cover.
It is never allowed.
explanation: A driver must make sure that each passenger in the vehicle has a seatbelt. Failure to wear a seatbelt is an offence. It is the driver’s responsibility to ensure that passengers under the age of 17 wear seatbelts. Older passengers are themselves responsible for wearing seatbelts.

text: When is a tractor most likely to overturn?
options: When turning sharply.
When reversing slowly.
When driving uphill.
When driving on the flat.
explanation: When you are driving a tractor, you should be aware that tractors are less stable than other vehicles and take extra care when manoeuvring.

text: When driving a tractor and trailer, what should the driver do on entering a roundabout to avoid possible roll-over?
options: Drive in a high gear.
Reduce speed.
Engage the parking brake.
Increase speed.
explanation: Drivers should always drive at a speed which is safe. In particular, when changing direction, such as entering a roundabout. If driving a tractor with a trailer, extra care should be taken due to their instability.

text: When is jack-knifing most likely to occur?
options: When trying to reduce speed sharply while travelling downhill.
When travelling sideways across a slope.
When travelling uphill.
When the trailer springs are over-greased.
explanation: Towing a trailer or caravan dramatically reduces the stability of the towing vehicle. If a driver brakes sharply or slows down quickly, the trailer may pivot around the tow hitch coupling, causing both vehicles to go off course, and possibly overturn.

text: What could a driver do in order to avoid excessive exhaust pollution from their vehicle?
options: Drive a diesel powered vehicle.
Use a fuel additive to increase the fuel octane rating.
Have the vehicle’s air filters changed regularly.
Drive at a higher speed in order to reduce the time spent on the road.
explanation: Drivers should have their vehicle serviced regularly in accordance with the manufacturer’s guidelines. A vehicle with a dirty air filter uses more fuel and creates more exhaust pollution. Air filters should be changed as part of normal servicing. If a vehicle is used in dusty conditions, the air filter may need to be changed more often. More information is available in the vehicle owner’s handbook.

text: In general how regularly should a vehicle be serviced?
options: As per the manufacturer’s recommendation.
Every 30,000 kilometres.
Once every year.
Every 30 months.
explanation: Drivers should have their vehicle serviced regularly in accordance with the manufacturer’s guidelines. This helps the vehicle to perform properly, and as a result saves fuel and reduces emissions. In addition, drivers should also carry out their own daily and weekly checks on fluid levels and tyres.

text: What is the purpose of a catalytic converter?
options: To reduce harmful exhaust emissions.
To curb exhaust noise levels only on petrol-powered vehicles.
To allow the exhaust system to be reconditioned.
To curb exhaust noise levels only on diesel-powered vehicles.
explanation: Catalytic converters are part of a vehicle’s exhaust system. They help to protect the environment by removing up to 75% of the carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxide and hydrocarbons from the vehicle’s exhaust.

text: What should a driver do before getting out of the vehicle?
options: Open the door and exit the vehicle without delay.
Check the interior mirror before opening the door.
Check their side mirror and look behind before opening the door.
Open the door part way and then look behind.
explanation: Before opening any door, check for other road users passing, and in particular look out for pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists. Exit the vehicle only when it is safe to do so, and close the door as soon as possible. Where ever possible, passengers should exit on the side nearest the kerb wherever possible.

text: How should a driver secure their vehicle before getting out of it?
options: Apply the parking brake, stop the engine and engage a low gear.
Engage a low gear and stop the engine.
Angle the wheels away from the kerb and stop the engine.
Angle the wheels towards the kerb and stop the engine.
explanation: Before leaving your vehicle, apply the handbrake, switch off the engine and engage a low gear. If the vehicle is fitted with automatic transmission, select P (park).

text: At what point is a vehicle load more likely to shift?
options: When reversing.
When braking gently.
When cornering.
When overtaking.
explanation: It is the driver’s responsibility to ensure that the load is properly secured and evenly distributed, so that the vehicle can be properly controlled when changing direction and when braking.

text: What should a driver do if a tyre bursts on the vehicle they are driving?
options: Continue at the normal speed and stop at the next garage.
Pull on the handbrake to bring the vehicle to a stop.
Hold the steering wheel firmly and pull in on the side of the road.
Apply the brakes as quickly as possible.
explanation: If a tyre bursts on your vehicle, keep a firm hold of the steering, slow down gradually and stop where it is safe to do so. Switch on the hazard warning lights.

text: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets into a four-wheel sideways skid?
options: Turn the steering wheel in the opposite direction to improve tyre grip.
Turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the skid and apply the handbrake.
Turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the skid and ease off the accelerator.
Turn the steering wheel in the opposite direction and apply the handbrake.
explanation: If your vehicle goes into a four-wheel skid, turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the skid and ease off the accelerator. This should help to bring the wheels back into line and allow you to regain control.

text: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets into a front-wheel sideways skid?
options: Release the accelerator.
Continue to accelerate.
Apply the handbrake.
Press the footbrake.
explanation: If your vehicle goes into a front-wheel sideways skid, release the accelerator and do not try to steer until the tyres regain some grip on the road.

text: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets into a rear-wheel sideways skid?
options: Turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the rear wheels are heading.
Turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the front wheels are heading.
Apply the handbrake to bring the vehicle to a halt.
Apply the footbrake to bring the vehicle to a halt.
explanation: If your vehicle goes into a rear-wheel sideways skid, turn the steering in the direction the rear wheels are heading. This should be done very gradually, as too much steering could cause the vehicle to skid in the opposite direction.

text: How should a driver in a vehicle without anti-lock brakes (ABS) deal with a front-wheel straight-line skid?
options: Press in the clutch and release the accelerator.
Press and release the footbrake at rapid intervals.
Turn the steering wheel gently from side to side.
Pull the handbrake and hold the footbrake down.
explanation: If your vehicle does not have ABS and it goes into a straight-line front-wheel skid due to braking, press and release the brake pedal repeatedly and rapidly. This will help to restore tyre grip and enable you to regain control.

text: What should a driver do if they get a tyre blow-out on the road?
options: Switch off the engine ignition to bring the vehicle to a halt.
Continue driving until they reach a garage.
Apply the footbrake gently and bring the vehicle to a halt.
Apply the handbrake immediately to bring the vehicle to a halt.
explanation: If a tyre on the vehicle you are driving blows out, slow down gradually and find a safe and suitable place to stop. Switch on your hazard warning lights and change the wheel or call for assistance.

text: What effect could a rear-tyre blow-out have on a vehicle?
options: The steering wheel will pull to the right.
The handbrake will automatically come on.
It could cause the wheels to lock and stop rotating.
It could cause the vehicle to sway from side to side.
explanation: If a rear tyre on the vehicle you are driving blows out, the vehicle may sway from side to side, and this will affect its stability. Slow down, pull in where it is safe to do so, and switch on the hazard warning lights. Change the wheel or call for assistance.

text: What action should a driver take if the engine in their vehicle cuts out suddenly when they are driving along?
options: Signal and steer the vehicle to the side of the road.
Check the handbrake is fully off.
Engage a lower gear.
Depress the accelerator and then release it.
explanation: If the engine in a vehicle cuts out when driving, it is important to signal and steer to the side of the road, switch on the hazard warning lights to warn other drivers, and contact the relevant breakdown service to get assistance.

text: How would hydraulic power steering be affected if an engine stalled in slow-moving traffic?
options: The steering would become heavy and difficult to operate.
The steering would become much lighter and easier to operate.
The steering wheel would automatically lock.
The steering fluid reservoir would lose all its fluid.
explanation: Hydraulic power steering is operated by a pump which is driven by the engine. If the engine stalls, the pump stops working, and the steering becomes heavy and requires much more effort to turn.

text: When driving along, a driver feels that the oncoming car may crash into their vehicle. What should they do?
options: Apply the handbrake immediately to help bring the vehicle to a halt.
Sound the horn to attract the attention of the other driver and take evasive action.
Apply the footbrake gently and bring the vehicle to a halt.
Switch off the engine ignition to help bring the vehicle to a halt.
explanation: If there is an oncoming vehicle in your path, take evasive action and sound your horn to alert the other driver. Bring your vehicle to a halt immediately.

text: What should a driver do to avoid having to make an emergency stop?
options: Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front.
Drive with the left foot covering the clutch pedal.
Keep the left hand available to apply the handbrake.
Drive with the left foot covering the brake pedal.
explanation: When driving in traffic, read the road ahead and keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front. Use the two-second rule to determine your safe distance from the vehicle in front.

text: What should a driver do to avoid having to make an emergency stop?
options: Drive with the left foot covering the clutch pedal.
Scan the road well ahead.
Keep the left hand available to apply the handbrake.
Drive with the left foot covering the brake pedal.
explanation: When driving in traffic, read the road ahead and keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front. Use the two-second rule to determine your safe distance from the vehicle in front.

text: Which of the following is a possible consequence for a learner driver if they drive after drinking as little as just one unit of alcohol?
options: A three month disqualification from driving.
A €90 fine.
A one month disqualification from driving.
A €60 fine.
explanation: The blood alcohol concentrate limit for novice/learner drivers is much lower than that of a driver who has held their full licence for more than two years (not a novice driver). Therefore as little as one unit of alcohol would result in the driver exceeding the lower limit.

text: During what time periods can a driver be tested for drugs at a road side checkpoint?
options: Only after an accident.
Anytime of day or night.
Only during night time hours.
Only during daylight hours.
explanation: The law allows for a driver to be tested at any time.

text: What must a driver be prepared for in this situation?
options: A child could turn back to collect the ball from the roadway.
The oncoming vehicle may swerve in your direction.
The ball could damage your vehicle.
The ball may burst after you have passed.
explanation: Because it is difficult to predict children’s behaviour, you should always be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation and be prepared to stop.

text: What should a driver do when travelling behind this vehicle?
options: Reduce speed and prepare to stop if necessary.
Overtake the vehicle in front.
Drive as close as possible to the vehicle.
Pass the vehicle slowly by mounting the kerb on the left.
explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to the changing traffic situation as you approach junctions.

text: When approaching a bus up ahead that is signalling to move off from a bus stop, what should a driver do?
options: Indicate and try to get past it promptly.
Stop immediately as the bus has the right of way.
Slow down and allow it to move out.
explanation: A driver should allow signalling buses back into the stream of traffic when they are moving out from a stop. Be careful of pedestrians getting on and off buses, particularly of children near schools.

text: What should a driver do if they are behind schedule in reaching a destination at an appointed time?
options: Be patient and do not exceed the speed limit so as to arrive safely.
Use hazard warning lights to encourage other road users to let you pass.
Exceed the speed limit if necessary to make up the time.
explanation: You should always drive at a speed that allows you to stop safely within the distance you can see to be clear. Being late for an appointment is no excuse for exceeding speed limits or for driving at an unsafe speed. Arrive alive.

text: What should a driver do when they see plant or machinery crossing the roadway at roadworks up ahead?
options: Slow down and prepare to stop.
Leave the carriage way as the road ahead is blocked.
Maintain the same speed along the road.
explanation: When you notice works vehicles ahead, slow down and be prepared to stop for the road works. If machinery is crossing you must stop if directed.

text: What should the driver allow for when following the bus on an icy road?
options: Same braking distance as in wet conditions.
A longer braking distance is required.
A shorter braking distance is required.
explanation: When driving in icy conditions, you should always reduce speed and allow a bigger gap to the vehicle in front in order to be able to stop safely if necessary.

text: A driver wants to pull out of a driveway and turn right onto the road. At the same time a cyclist is approaching from the right and a pedestrian wants to cross. Who must wait?
options: The pedestrian must wait.
The pedestrian and the cyclist must wait.
The driver must wait.
explanation: By law you must give way to other road users, including pedestrians and cyclists, when you are entering or leaving a driveway.

text: The driver intends to turn right at this junction - what should the driver do?
options: Stop in front of the bus.
Stop in front of the motorcycle.
Stop at the line.
explanation: You must stop at the line where a junction is controlled by a STOP sign and stop line. Do not proceed until it is safe to do so.

text: What should a driver be aware of in this situation?
options: Only buses may use this road.
There may be a car hidden from view in front of the bus.
The bus may be parked at a terminus.
explanation: On approach to an area with a restricted view you should be extra careful and be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

text: What should the driver do if they are driving and feel tired?
options: The driver should drive along the centre of the road and reduce speed.
The driver should stop and take a break.
The driver should drive on the hard shoulder where available.
explanation: Driving when you are tired can be very dangerous, and it may cause you to micro-sleep (or nod off momentarily). At 100 km/h you travel at 28 metres a second, so if you micro-sleep for just 4 seconds you would travel over 100 metres without being in control of the vehicle. Never drive if you are fighting sleep.

text: What should drivers do if they approach road works and there is earth-moving machinery moving about?
options: Reduce speed as there may be loose gravel or mud on the road.
Switch on headlights as a warning and carry on as normal.
Stop, turn the vehicle around on the road and find an alternative route.
explanation: Where earth-moving machinery is working, there are likely to be mud and gravel deposits on the road. Also the noise of such machines might make it hard for road workers to hear the approaching traffic. When you come across earth-moving machinery, slow down and proceed with extreme caution.

text: What effect does spilt diesel have on a road?
options: It makes the road more slippery.
It improves the vehicle’s braking ability.
It increases tyre noise.
explanation: Diesel spilt on the road can make the road surface extremely slippery, particularly if the road is wet.

text: What should a rider be aware of when crossing road markings such as lines or arrows?
options: Tyre grip is reduced.
Steering is improved.
Tyre grip is not affected.
explanation: Riding on just 2 wheels, riders need to be on the constant lookout for irregularities and other problems with the road surface. This can include all road markings.

text: What should a driver do if traffic comes to a halt in a tunnel?
options: Select a low gear and keep the engine running.
Switch off the engine.
Switch on front and rear fog lights.
explanation: If traffic comes to a halt in a tunnel, switch off your engine to prevent a build up of fumes in the tunnel. Stay patient and follow the instructions of the tunnel operators.

text: Why is it dangerous to allow children to stand in the space between the front seats of a car?
options: They could distract other drivers thus drawing attention away from the road.
They could be thrown backward if the brakes are applied suddenly.
They could be thrown forward if the brakes are applied suddenly.
explanation: When carrying children in a car or goods vehicle, it is the driver’s responsibility to make sure that they are suitably restrained.

text: How should a driver proceed if their view is blocked at a junction?
options: Move out slowly onto the road while watching carefully for other traffic.
Sound the horn several times and proceed.
Flash headlights on and off before moving out.
Ask a passer-by for guidance onto the other road.
explanation: At junctions where the view is blocked, move carefully into a position where you can see without interfering with other road users. Then assess the situation before you continue.

text: What should a driver do who wishes to turn a vehicle around on the road?
options: Drive onto a footpath if necessary in order to ensure that they have enough room to turn.
It is not allowed to turn a vehicle around on the road in any circumstance.
Drive into somebody’s driveway and reverse back onto the road.
Check ahead and behind for oncoming traffic and turn the vehicle around while still keeping a look out.
explanation: If you want to turn a vehicle around on the road, you must first choose a place where it is safe and legal to do so. Check all around for other road users and do not impede their right of way. Complete the manoeuvre efficiently and safely.

text: What should a driver do to avoid the need for harsh braking?
options: Drive with one foot resting on the brake pedal.
Drive with cruise control engaged.
Look ahead and be prepared for what others may do.
Drive with one foot resting on the clutch pedal.
explanation: You should know what speed you’re travelling at and you should always drive at a speed that is appropriate to the conditions you are driving in, and you should be able to stop smoothly and safely within the distance you can see to be clear ahead.

text: Are children allowed to be left unattended in a vehicle?
options: Only when there is enough ventilation.
Only when the vehicle is parked in a supervised car park.
Children should never be left unattended in a vehicle.
explanation: Children must not be left unattended in a vehicle, even for a short period of time. Children might interfere with the vehicle’s controls, and would not be able to deal with an emergency situation, such as a fire or electrical malfunction which could result in serious injury or death.

text: When must a driver use a red flag as a marker for a rear load overhang that exceeds one metre?
options: Only during the day.
At no time.
At all times.
Only during the night.
explanation: During daylight hours, you must use a red flag to mark any load that is protruding more than one metre. At night, you must use a red light.

text: How should a driver manage a bend when driving a fully loaded vehicle?
options: At a slower speed than when empty.
At the same speed as when empty.
By taking the bend more sharply than when empty.
explanation: Driving too fast on the approach to a bend and while driving through it with a fully loaded vehicle can lead to a loss of control. This can be prevented by driving in a safe and sensible manner and by reading the road ahead.

text: When a driver is at a junction where visibility is extremely limited, what should the driver do?
options: Move out with extreme care, watching carefully to the left and right.
Sound the horn and quickly proceed.
Move the vehicle out onto the road to enable other drivers to see you.
explanation: Where your view is obstructed at a junction, you should move carefully into a position where you can see, but without interfering with other road users. You should then assess the situation before you continue.

text: On a narrow busy road, what should pedestrians do when walking?
options: Walk two abreast.
Walk more than two abreast.
Walk in groups of no more than three.
Walk in single file.
explanation: Pedestrians should walk in single file on busy narrow roads. Drivers should be aware of the Rules of the Road for pedestrians, drive with caution and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.

text: A driver is automatically disqualified from driving for how long if, on a first offence, they refused to provide a member of An Garda Síochána with a sample of blood, urine or breath?
options: 4 years.
3 years.
2 years.
1 year.
explanation: It is an offence not to comply with a request from a member of An Garda Síochána to provide to provide a sample of breath, urine or blood.

text: What is the maximum disqualification period imposed in court when the learner driver has a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) level in excess of 80 mg?
options: One year.
Six years.
Two years.
Four years.
explanation: Where a learner driver has failed to pay a fixed penalty notice they will be summonsed to court where a judge can apply a disqualification period of between 1-6 years.

text: What advice should a driver give to passengers before opening doors?
options: Leave windows slightly open to allow circulation of air.
Make sure that you have proper clothing protection on.
Check all around and open door with caution.
Remove seat belt and exit vehicle immediately.
explanation: Before opening any doors, check for other road users nearby, in particular motorcyclists and pedestrians.

text: How do you make sure your vehicle is parked safely?
options: Drive into parking space as quickly as possible.
Park your vehicle opposite another vehicle on a narrow road.
Avoid reversing your vehicle into a space.
Don’t park it where it may endanger other road users.
explanation: When parking make sure you do not interfere with normal traffic flow and that your vehicle does not disturb, block or endanger other road users.

text: What should be considered when reversing out of a parking space?
options: Always reverse quickly to get out of space.
Check for pedestrians and vehicles all around.
Check behind using interior rear view mirror only.
Avoid switching on your rear wiper.
explanation: Some car parks are designed for you to park forwards to make it easier to load shopping. In these cases take extra care as you reverse out of the parking space because pedestrians and vehicles may pass behind you.

text: When a driver operates the indicator switch and hears a more rapid clicking noise than normal, what could this mean?
options: The hazard warning lights are on.
The voltage regulator is not functioning properly.
The hazard warning light switch is faulty.
An indicator bulb may have blown.
explanation: A rapid clicking noise when you turn on an indicator is usually a sign that one of the indicator bulbs has failed. Drivers are responsible for making sure that their vehicle is roadworthy. This should include a regular check that all lights, reflectors and indicators, are working properly.

text: What does Anti-lock Braking System (ABS) do?
options: ABS locks the brakes to prevent skidding during harsh braking.
ABS displays the name of the radio station playing on the car radio.
ABS prevents the wheels from locking under harsh braking conditions.
ABS deploys the airbags during a collision.
explanation: Anti-lock Braking System (ABS) is a type of braking system found in most modern cars. It comes into play automatically when the driver brakes harshly. In the wet it can help prevent the wheels from skidding so that, if necessary, the driver can continue to steer while braking. Be aware that ABS does not reduce the braking distance.

text: If the oil pressure gauge shows little or no pressure, or the warning light comes on, what could the problem be?
options: The oil level is too high.
The oil level is too low.
The oil is too cold.
The oil is too thick.
explanation: Drivers should check the oil level in their vehicle regularly, and if it is low, top it up. If it needs to be topped up very often, have the vehicle checked by a competent person to see if there is a problem.

text: What may happen if the vehicle’s engine oil is not changed as required?
options: The engine may overheat.
The vehicle’s fuel consumption may increase.
Parts of the engine may suffer increased wear.
The vehicle’s fuel consumption may decrease.
explanation: Engine oil becomes inefficient over time, losing its viscosity and lubricating qualities, and therefore must be changed as required in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendations. Failure to do so may result in costly and extensive engine damage. The oil change is usually done when the vehicle is being serviced.

text: If a vehicle is driven with low oil pressure, what effect does this have on its engine?
options: It increases fuel consumption.
It increases wear and tear on the engine.
It increases fuel efficiency.
It increases exhaust emissions.
explanation: Low oil pressure is usually related to low oil level or to a faulty oil pump. Low engine oil level should be topped up in accordance with the manufacturer’s recommendations. Failure to do so may result in costly and extensive engine damage.

text: What should a driver do before checking the engine oil level on a vehicle?
options: Make sure that the vehicle is in a low gear.
Make sure that the engine is switched off and cold.
Make sure that the engine is running.
Make sure that the engine is switched on and hot.
explanation: Drivers need a basic knowledge of the regular checks that should be carried out on their vehicle. Checking the engine oil level is important – do this with the vehicle parked on level ground with the engine switched off and cold for a more accurate reading. Refer to the vehicle handbook for further information and guidance.

text: What is the purpose of engine oil?
options: It lubricates the engine.
It lubricates the braking system.
It lubricates the exhaust system.
It lubricates the wheel bearings.
explanation: The purpose of engine oil is to lubricate and cool the moving parts of the engine. Refer to the vehicle handbook for further information and guidance.

text: When is it recommended to use coolant?
options: Winter only.
All year round.
In petrol engines only.
Summer only.
explanation: The purpose of coolant is to keep the engine cool during operation. Coolant is usually a mixture of water and anti-freeze – this ensures that the engine is kept cool and that the coolant does not freeze in very cold weather.

text: What happens if the vehicle has a flat battery?
options: The battery will leak acid into the engine.
The engine will not start.
The head light bulbs will have to be replaced.
The battery will have to be replaced.
explanation: All motor vehicles have a battery to supply power, primarily to start the engine. If the battery is flat, the driver will not be able to start the engine in the normal way. When the engine is running, it produces its own electricity to recharge the battery and run the various electrical components, including lights, heating, the radio and so on. If the battery is completely dead it will have to be replaced.

text: What is the primary purpose of the battery fitted to a petrol - or diesel - powered motor vehicle?
options: To start the engine.
To reduce fuel consumption.
To provide heat to the engine.
To provide braking.
explanation: The primary purpose of the battery is to start the engine. When the engine is running, it produces its own electricity to charge the battery and run the various electrical components, including lights, heating, radio and so on.

text: What effect would a weak battery have on a vehicle’s driving performance?
options: It would have no effect.
The headlights would not function.
The fuel would burn less efficiently.
Uphill acceleration would be reduced.
explanation: It might be difficult to start a car with a weak battery, but once the engine is running, it makes no difference. If the battery fails to charge or maintain its full charge seek advice from a competent person.

text: What effect can a worn shock absorber have on a vehicle?
options: It can trigger the release of the airbags.
It can increase fuel consumption.
It can cause an electrical short-circuit.
It can cause the vehicle to ‘bounce’ in an unstable manner.
explanation: A worn shock absorber can seriously affect the control of the vehicle especially on uneven surfaces or when cornering and can cause unnecessary wear and tear on tyres. It may increase stopping distance by not keeping the tyres in proper contact with the road under harsh braking.

text: Why should the valve be replaced when having a tubeless tyre fitted?
options: To ensure the tyre will remain inflated.
To ensure the wheel remains aligned.
To ensure the wheel nuts remain tight.
To ensure the wheel remains balanced.
explanation: When fitting a new tubeless tyre to a vehicle it is recommended to change the valve. This is because the old valve has been on the wheel since the old tyre was fitted. The old valve may break down, leak or cause air to escape.

text: What effect does low tyre-pressure have on a vehicle?
options: The brakes can overheat.
The engine noise increases.
The vehicle accelerates faster.
Braking and cornering are impaired.
explanation: Incorrect tyre pressure adversely affects many of a vehicle’s systems, including suspension, steering and fuel consumption. In particular, under-inflated tyres can affect the vehicle’s braking ability and its effectiveness when cornering. Tyres should always be inflated according to the vehicle manufacturer’s guidelines, information on which can be found in the vehicle handbook.

text: What is an effect of under-inflated tyres on a vehicle?
options: Increased wear on the vehicle’s engine.
Impaired braking and steering.
Improved braking and steering.
Improved fuel economy and braking.
explanation: Drivers should check their vehicle’s tyre pressures (including the spare) regularly at least once a week. Under-inflated tyres adversely affect many of a vehicle’s systems, including braking ability, suspension, steering, fuel consumption and premature tyre wear. Tyres should always be inflated according to the vehicle manufacturer’s guidelines, information on which can be found in the vehicle handbook.

text: While driving at higher speeds, what does a continuous vibration in the steering indicate?
options: Weight distribution is uneven.
The shock absorbers are worn.
The wheel balance is uneven.
The steering is out of alignment.
explanation: If a driver feels a continuous vibration in the steering, particularly at higher speeds, this could typically indicate that the balance of the vehicle wheels is uneven. This can lead to instability in the handling of the vehicle. If this is the case, have it investigated by a competent person.

text: After changing a wheel on a vehicle, which of the following should be checked after a short distance?
options: The tyre tread depth.
The tyre air valve.
The brake pad clearance.
The wheel nut tightness.
explanation: After changing a wheel on a vehicle, check the tightness of the wheel nuts or studs on the replacement wheel after driving a short distance to ensure they are securely fitted. If in doubt seek assistance from a competent person.

text: What can be affected by driving on under-inflated tyres?
options: Braking ability.
The exhaust system.
Engine temperature.
Climate control system.
explanation: Under-inflated tyres may adversely affect many of the vehicle’s systems, including its braking ability, suspension, steering and fuel consumption. In particular, under-inflated tyres can affect the vehicle’s braking ability and can result in premature tyre wear. Tyres should always be inflated according to the vehicle manufacturer’s guidelines, information on which can be found in the vehicle handbook.

text: In general, above what gross vehicle weight must a trailer have brakes fitted?
options: 500 kg
750 kg
850 kg
900 kg
explanation: Brakes must be fitted to a trailer if its gross vehicle weight exceeds either 750 kg or half the weight of the towing vehicle.

text: If the vehicle’s oil-pressure gauge is reading low or the red oil-pressure warning light comes on, what should a driver do?
options: Drive at lower speeds until the oil level is topped up.
Drive to a safe place, stop the vehicle and check the oil level.
Drive in a low gear until the oil level is topped up.
explanation: Oil circulation is essential for the safe running of the vehicle’s engine. If the warning lights or gauges indicate that the oil or the oil-pressure is low, the driver should stop as soon as they can in safe place, check the oil level, and top up if necessary. Continuing to drive may damage the engine. If the problem is not just related to the oil level, have the vehicle checked by a competent person.

text: If driving a vehicle with automatic transmission, what in particular should a driver be aware of?
options: That wheel-spin occurs more often.
That engine braking power is reduced.
That the gear box may overheat while being driven in low gear.
That driving on a motorway is not permitted.
explanation: When driving an automatic vehicle, it may not slow at the same rate as a vehicle with a manual gearbox when the driver releases the accelerator. Drivers should be aware of this, as they may need to apply the brake earlier in order to stop where required.

text: What effect does automatic transmission have on engine braking power?
options: It transfers the braking ability to the handbrake.
It increases it.
It reduces it.
It transfers the braking ability to all the wheels.
explanation: When driving an automatic vehicle, it may not slow at the same rate as a vehicle with a manual gearbox when the driver releases the accelerator. Drivers should be aware of this, as they may need to apply the brake earlier in order to stop where required.

text: When driving, where should a driver rest their left foot?
options: On the floor or foot rest.
On the clutch pedal.
Under the brake pedal.
Under the clutch pedal.
explanation: When driving a driver should rest their left foot on the floor or foot rest but not under the pedals. To do so may cause delayed response time in an emergency. Resting the foot on the pedal may result in coasting, which may inadvertently increase the speed of the vehicle, or clutch mechanism damage.

text: On a motorway, when should a driver use the hazard warning lights?
options: When slowing down quickly because of danger ahead.
When driving on the hard shoulder.
When towing another vehicle.
When another vehicle is following too closely.
explanation: Use the hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead. For example, if you have to slow down sharply because of a build-up of traffic ahead, you can use the hazard warning lights to warn following vehicles that they need to slow down.

text: What should a driver do if the fuel system becomes air-locked?
options: Loosen the fuel pump.
Tighten the injector pipes.
Bleed the air out of the fuel system.
Drain the fuel filter.
explanation: The fuel system can become air-locked if you let the fuel get too low or if there is a leak in the system. You should have the problem corrected before driving. The solution may be as simple as bleeding the fuel system to release the air.

text: Under what circumstances could both cross-ply and radial tyres be fitted to a vehicle?
options: When towing a trailer in snow.
When heavy loads are being carried.
When each type is fitted on a different axle.
When driving in slippery road conditions.
explanation: In general, you should fit the same type of tyres all round the vehicle. However if you need to fit a mix of cross-ply and radials, the tyres on any axle should be of the same type.

text: What does the warning light and/or red zone on a fuel gauge mean?
options: The level of fuel in the tank is low.
There is a leak in the fuel system.
The incorrect type of fuel is in the tank.
explanation: Many vehicles are fitted with various warning lights and gauges. A red zone or a warning light on a fuel gauge means the vehicle is low in fuel and should be refuelled as soon as possible.

text: What does the speed rating of a tyre indicate?
options: The minimum speed for which the tyre is designed.
The maximum speed for which the tyre is designed.
The maximum speed the vehicle can be driven at.
explanation: The speed rating of a tyre is the maximum speed for which the tyre is designed. This relates to the speed capability of the tyre. It does not relate to the speed at which the tyre should or could legally be driven.
